column3: Great wanton noodles!
$3.80 - 4.30 - Warning: the chilli is really spicy!
so you might wanna stick to just the black bean sauce or may ask them to put less.
- The wanton ares great but the cha sew needs works.
It doesn't taste as fresh and looks a tad but dark.
Dubious color.
Fried wantons $3.80 - So crispy!
love it.
People order these by the dozens.
It's a really no fuss place.
Kinda like a hawker centre/ food court.
The sitting area is casual, maybe even a little cramp.
***NOTE: I found the exact same noodles at Serangoon gardens (not chomp chomp but the other hawker centre.
there are 2 located there.)
Anyways, it serves exactly the same tasting wanton noodles and wantons (I am not sure if they are related) but the prices are much cheaper there since it's not air-conditioned.
$3 a bowl and $3 a plate of fried wanton.
This is a great location that falls just between the chaos of Vivo City and Sentosa.
This is a new location for Brewerkz that has been placed alongside the veteran wine restaurant next door on the waterside boardwalk.
On a Saturday night, the crowd was modest.
The outdoor seating along the waterside offered an impressively relaxed and intimate dining area.
This is a great place to escape the massive crowds that surround either side of the boardwalk.
On top of that, Brewerkz's food is of higher quality than your typical bar.
We tried the pizza and salmon salad and both were excellent.
I've also had a great bbq burger in the past.
Nevertheless, their specialty is drinks, so you can expect a large selection of many varieties, especially custom beers.
The service was attentive and friendly.
I recommend this location after a crowded day at Sentosa or Vivo City, where you can get some rest.
Want a great location for an evening meal?
You can't go wrong with Brewerkz located in the middle of Sentosa Boardwalk.
We chanced upon it while walking back to mainland after a day in USS.
Despite my headache, I agreed to 'seize the moment' and stayed in to have a few beers and snacks.
The drinks were the same as you would get in bars anywhere else and not exceptional (about 16 for a beer), though some of them are from their own microbrewery.
The snacks were also unexceptional but definitely satisfactory.
The onion rings were $9 for a fairly large basket, and desserts of brownie with ice cream and bread pudding with ice cream were $10 each with equally decent portions.
The best part is the view, which is really what you're paying for.
The sparkling lights on the floor to mimick the night sky above coupled with the serenity of the sea and the distant twinkling of the cable car lights was a simply divine combination.
At 9pm, we were unexpectedly treated to some sort of light show in the distance of a floating platform in front of Sentosa.
I'm guessing many already know about this but it looks like two birds fighting and ended off with loads of water, light and fireworks.
From our location, it was perfect, not too loud or crowded, and with the soft backdrop of the bar music.
We had actually just paid and were about to leave for the bus home but were mesmerised by the fireworks and abstract lights.
This is a very romantic location to bring a date, or just a laid-back environment to chill with friends.
Curiosity killed the cat!
Believe Watami was the restaurant before this and they probably revamped it to Nikku Kappo.
Thought the raw Sushi concept was interesting so gave it a try.
Ordered 3 or 4 varienties of raw beef and i can't say they were totally fresh.
Picture speaks for itsself.
now the miso beef sukiyai was a big disappointment.
The beef provided basically were not eatable.
they were chewy in texture and poor cuts of meat.
service was fine but again food taste ia supreme so .....
The restaurant is quite impressive with its signature yaki tetsu.
The beef was really tender and tasted great with the sauce.
However, I would recommend taking away the side dishes that tend to absorb too much sauce, as too much of it really does not taste good.
The food here is indeed unusual, with many  innovative dishes rarely found at Japanese restaurants outside Japan.
The meat sushi is interesting, but I still much prefer the seafood variety.
We also had the Yakitetsu Kobe; the meat is tender, and the miso and foie gras sauce is good but overly rich - it's unusual to feel so bloated after a Japanese meal.
Impressive sake and drinks lists; we were offered a complementary sake mojito, which was notoriously poor.
The staff diligently prepare many dishes at the table, but otherwise are a bit forgetful and not pro-active.
I'm typically not a fast food fan, but Mos Burger is one that I do go for on occasion.
I like the regular ole cheeseburger, which is basically your classic American fast food burger without any frills.
In an ever more complex fast food world, it is ironically tough to get this simple classic.
I have also tried one of their more strange creations, which consisted of a salmon patty and a bun made out of sticky rice.
It was quite tasty and didn't seem like eating fast food at all.
So, it seems the Japanese have conquered the American automobile and fast food burger.
What will they take over next?
P.S.
I'm pretty sure I was a direct cause of this location now accepting credit cards.
One time, I came by without cash, placed an order, and had to run to the ATM and back.
The next time I went by, the shop had a brand new PIN machine and were taking cards.
This newly-opened Western stall serves a range of barbecued food, usually accompanied by pineapple or white rice (you choose) and some achar (to complement the pineapple rice, I wager).
I decided to give it a try, going for the honey chicken leg that was priced at $4.80 for the smaller set (the larger set has a larger chicken leg at $5.20).
The stall also serves Yakitori as well as a fish-and-ebi (prawn) combo meal.
Most of these items are under $4.
You can also choose to purchase the items individually without the rice.
First up, the chicken: the honey glaze was done nicely, and the chicken was juicy but not too oily.
In comparison with the Cold Storage equivalent, however, this is not exactly up to par (though you should consider the price difference of +$3 for the latter).
The pineapple rice definitely needed more flavouring, as it was rather bland and visually not appealing enough.
The achar was average and forgettable, while the soup was tasteless.

Overall, I think the stall adds some much-needed variety to the hawker centre in this neighbourhood, and families looking for decent Western food that isn't fried (with reused oil) would appreciate the choices provided here.
Typical prata store in the mornings.
i had the kosong and the plaster.
I wanted it with fish curry but it had run out(in the morning??)
This prata is very crispy, and not very chewy/ So if you really like it that way, you will enjoy it here.
The mutton cury was okay.
but i always preffer the sourish fish curry.
They also have thosai which is pretty decent.
In addition to what the name suggests, This place als has fried carrot cake and fried oyster.
I have tried both the black and white carrot cakes I have to say that both are pretty good.
The black version is fried with a thick sweet sauce and egg.
You can taste the chai poh with it and the bits of egg goes very well The White version is savoury the chilli which they fry it with is very good.
I work in Marsiling , so when I am early, i will get breakfast from one of the nearby coffeeshops and this is one of my regular places.
This is your typical run of the mill beehoon/nasi lemak/ Fried kuay teow places, where you choose a carb(i usually choose the nasi lemak) and then you pick the dishes you want to go with it.
fried stuff, like chicken wings, sausages, luncheon meat, fish cakes, ikan billis.
Then there are some stir fried dishes like long beans, eggplant.
Most times there is a vegetable curry as well.
This place does all pretty well and from the picture you can see its popular too.
With Fish and Co., it's best to go old school with Fish and Chips.
Enjoy a delicious plate of deep fried battered dory fish and hugely cut fries with sauce that you can keep on coming.
There will be times that we go old school and this is the place with their Fish and Chips.
Sometimes, we order a salad to add some leafy balance to the meal.
But trust me, a plate of fish and chips is definitely filling with all that protein and carbs.
I also love how comfortable I am whenever I dine there-enough space for me to enjoy my food without worrying that I'l bump my knee under the table or kick the one in front of me.
It is priced affordable with a hint of pricey-ness.
Definitely best enjoyed with family or friends.
Come to think of it, would you rather enjoy that feast all to yourself?
This KFC is at the Zoo's kidzworld.
Although there are ample seating, there is usually no space available even on non-peak period.
The tables are occupied by parents waiting for their kids playing at the water play facilities right in front of the restaurant.
It might be better to walk outside to the other KFC at the zoo entrance if you are looking for food.
Sad about the price of good beer in Singapore?
Yeah, you and every other expat in the country.
craftbeer.sg to the rescue.
Sales to the public online only.
Cases (24x330ml) of Chimay red and Duvel delivered in 2-business days for S$160 tax and delivery included.
This is the best place in Singapore to get Gelato for a number of reasons.
The Gelato - tastes AMAZING.
Try the pistachio flavor!
It is my favorite :) 2.
The location - prime location and perfect for dates or even just to hang out with close friends.
You can sit and watch people walk by, enjoy music, while eating your gelato and conversing with friends.
They serve ALCOHOL!!!!
- They have this awesome champagne that your girlfriend will love.
Get it for her.
They mix the champagne with some strawberry and I think something else.
I can't remember.
Maybe it is their secret recipe?
lol.
Anyways, a must try.
Also, they have SHOOTERS!
I love to come here and drink a bunch of shooters before I go out to a club with my friends.
It is a great way to get the night started.
The Service - the team at Note di Sicilia is amazing.
Truly great people who love their customers.
They will smile for you, offer you samples, and show you how to enjoy the whole experience of gelato.
I urge you to try this place!!
Great boutique beers at reasonable price.
You can try cold beers there to see if you want more than 1.
Not as nice a drinking space as their other store but great selection and advice.
Great to have this in holland v. Its a little hard to find.
Take the escalators that are on the right side of cold storage to first floor.
Turn right, then right straight away then another right so you have basically done a u turn.
Not a very busy mall so there will not be any waiting.
Hopefully this store will survive as it's a great idea.
Check it out.
If you love beer and don't want to drink the same thing all the time then this is for you.
I can't believe I haven't yet dropped Thirsty HV (Holland Village) some Yelp review love?!
I'm certainly no stranger here as the friendly folks at Thirsty will tell you.
They're really more like family since I almost live here.
Maybe live is a bit of an exaggeration,  I am to Thirsty HV what Norm was to Cheers.
That should suggest to you that my review is likely to gloss over a wealth of minor sins in favor of the greater good and how dearly I love this secret jewel of a neighborhood watering hole!
This franchise is run by a small crew of knowledgeable, folksy characters who are passionate about beer and just want you to love the stuff as much as they do.

This passion runs through not only the staff here but also the regulars, which run the gamut from beer lovers, to connoisseurs and home brewers so be prepared to be given pretty passionate feedback about what you should have or which new bottles you should try.
If you're lucky you get to sit back relax with a beer while enjoying a lively debate on the relative virtues of different offerings and styles available at Thirsty HV.

So it's a bottle shop but you're also allowed to drink on site and more likely than not you'll get offers of a taste of whatever one of the regulars brewed at home, picked up from their travels or is having one out of the chiller.
While there are Thirsty's all over Singapore, Thirsty's HV is the den of a thoroughly lovable, slightly rowdy, marginally rude family of beer geeks.
Q Bread is located behind but directly attached to the Aljunied MRT Station.
This is a small bakery with a nice variety of baked goods.
There is no seating here so this is strictly grab and go!
I picked two items here, a bag of 6 small multi-grain breads and a package of several small dessert croissants.
I tried one of the croissants right away, it was light, flaky, and tasted very fresh.
I tried a bit of the bread later in the day and it was as good as the croissants.
Everything seemed reasonably priced.
One word of note, they don't like you taking photos, I took a photo of the outside of the bakery (the one I posted here) and they started waving their hands around saying "No Photos".
This place is a "spin-off" from Sprmrkt in McCallum Street and has been open for a few weeks.
It's kinda hidden away in the basement of the Hong Leong Building in an area crowded with lunch alternatives.
But, don't let the basement ambiance put you off.
The menu is much more sandwiches, wraps, muffins and cakes - all freshly baked - than Sprmrkt.
And, they brought the best from their other establishment: creative and great tasting food.
I don't normally give out five starts after one visit, but this time I'm taking the chance.
I don't think I'll have to go back and change it.
Black Sesame Carrot Cake Probably one of the only carrot cakes that I actually like other than Cedele's carrot cake.
I usually stray away from carrot cakes, because I find them too sweet and "heaty" but this cake was very moist with generous servings of nuts, raisins and carrot shreds.
The White Ombre prides itself in unique cakes and adding the black sesame to this carrot cake was definitely different.
However, I think it's more of a decoration as you cannot taste it in the cake.
You can clearly taste the dedication and passion the white ombre has to their cakes, as every cake is neatly placed into the cake cabinet and all are uniformly designed.
All the cakes looked so delicious and fresh.
Here's the variety of cakes and other sweet treats for sale.
Check out the huge baking wonderland, the White Ombre runs baking classes to teach people how to bake cakes, macarons and even more.
The staff are also very friendly.
Take note that the shop has no dining area, all cakes are packed in boxes and ready to take away.
Menu of cakes per slice, per whole cake.
Check out the macarons This shop faces a whole stretch of industrial shops.
The first retail kiosk of Barcook Bakery!
I love the raisin cream cheese bread here.
I think there is really no better alternative to this.
The amount of cream cheese is generous and does not taste too sweet.
The soft bun goes really well with coffee.
It tastes best when served warm.
You can either heat it up at home, or if you're lucky, you'll probably get your hands on the fresh warm bread!
There was once I got there at about 830pm, and I actually got bread right out of the oven!
I mean, where else can you get freshly baked bread at 830pm?!
I would also recommend the cranberry and raisin loaf.
I like the combination of cranberry and raisin; the bread tastes good on its own, you won't even need a spread.
However, since this is only a kiosk, it does not sell cakes.
Other than that, it's as good as it can get!
Enjoyed their hazelnut and custard sponge cakes.
They come individually packed, like a muffin, and make a great afternoon snack or desert after lunch.
The sponge is light and fluffy, and not too sweet - the first time I had it it was still warm which was heavenly :) Very reasonably priced with lots of other sponge cakes and varieties available.
Before the rise of bespoke cocktails bars such as 28 Hong Kong Street , there was Drink Culture, a cool white washed club like bar that caters to the slightly older and sophisticated crowd.
It looks very discrete even though it's located at the corner of the road.
The great thing is the ambiance and clients of course.
There is absolutely no worries of being harassed by drunken young punks.
It's just people wanting to sit back and nurse a delicious cocktail with friends.
If you have no idea what to order, simply tell the bartender what mood you are in or what flavors you want to have in your drinks.
He'll cook up something for you.
Fresh ingredients are used here and if you sit at the bar, you can see the guys at work.
I didn't see any syrup being used at all to flavor the drinks.
Did i also mention that the alcohol content is very high?
Heh.
What's good here: Cosmo.
The Choco Flambé Martini drinks like a dessert.
The top coating of milk foam is gently blow-torched until it caramelizes into a light, fluffy texture but the drink is left untouched.
I even had a smiley face on mine.
Pays to be friendly to the bartender.
Right after eating my dinner, I was looking for a dessert to satisfy my sweet tooth.
In my search, I found a shop called 'Berrylite Frozen Yogurt' that offered 100% fat free cold dessert.
It looks just like an ice-cream parlour.
Instead of ice-cream tubs on display ready to be scooped up upon a cone or cup, rows of multi-coloured toppings such as fruits, nuts, and cereals were provided.
Behind the staff, is a yogurt dispensing machine for him to serve the dessert.
I ordered one topped with fruits like strawberries and peaches filled in a cup.
Once readied, I ate a mouthful of the dessert and was shaken up with cool fruity flavour mixed with chilly yoghurt goodness.
The mixture of yoghurt and fruits swirling in my mouth complemented each other well as the taste exploded with rich flavour.
I became oblivious to the overwhelming experience that overcame me till the staff took notice and smiled.
We both knew I enjoyed the dessert incredibly.Berrylite Frozen Yogurt's opening hours: 11am - 10pm.
Spotted a few stalls offering steamed fish head  last week.
Returned with hubby to try the fish head on a Sunday but unfortunately, the stall (which seemed to offer more steamed fish head options) two doors away was closed.
So we tried this stall.
The wait was 50mins.
We had their signature fishhead  &  fried huang ti vegetable.
The latter was well executed.
The signature fishhead was OK but nothing to shout about.
The fish used was a river-fish and the chilli spices did not manage to mask the muddiness.
There was also too much bones for a fishhead.
Was inspired to try the steamed fish head after eating an awesome steamed fish head at Chinatown a few months back.
By the way, steamed fish head is full of collagen.
I'd come back here to try other dishes which are all reasonably priced.
Hock Heng You Tiao 福兴油条 is a stall located at Tanglin Halt Food Centre specialising in deep fried dough fritters.
This stall is located two units away from No.
1 Western Food 驰名西餐.
The Hungry Bunny recommended this stall since I was at Tanglin Halt Food Centre.
Hock Heng You Tiao sells a variety of deep fried dough fritters such as You Tiao, Salted Hum Chim Peng (Hum Jin Peng), Butterfly Bun and Lotus Paste Hum Chim Peng.
Everything at Hock Heng You Tiao are freshly made!
You may have noticed from the photos above, the owner was kneading, rolling and folding the dough preparing the next batch of Hum Chim Peng and You Tiao.
After which, his daughter would help to deep fry them.
The owner's wife also helps out at the stall.
Each item at the stall costs only $0.70.
Savory (Salted) Hum Chim Peng $0.70 I bought a Savory (Salted) Hum Chim Peng $0.70 to try out when I was there.
I must admit that it sure was good.
The Hum Chim Peng was soft, chewy and fluffy.
I especially love it when I reach the part which was savoury.
Having tried this out, I decided to purchase some home.
The Butterfly Bun $0.70 was fried with sesame seeds which gave it an extra fragrant.
It is similar to You Tiao except for the fact that it had a different shape and was sweeter in taste.
Anyway, my advice would be to have these deep fried dough fritters on the spot after buying.
It is best eaten when it is freshly fried.
Those that I bought home and ate the next morning became a tad too tough on the outside.
Nevertheless, Hock Heng You Tiao is worth a try.
Detailed review: foodiefc.blogspot.sg/201…
Chomp Chomp Food Centre (Hawker Centre) is located at located at Kensington Park Road, Serangoon Gardens.
The nearest MRT station is Serangoon and you would need to take a 10-15 minutes bus ride to reach this Food Centre.
The structure of Chomp Chomp is narrow with little walking space.
In terms of ventilation, it is pretty bad.
The low roof which keeps the smoke from the various barbecue stalls in, leads to a warm environment.
You are bound to smell and work up a sweat when eating at this food centre.
Unlike other Hawker Centre, Chomp Chomp is relatively small with just 36 stalls and limited seating capacity.
It a challenge getting seats especially if you are with a big group.
In the day time, most stalls are closed in Chomp Chomp.
It springs to life only in the evening (5pm) when the stalls start opening for business and customers start flocking in.
Despite these shortcomings, Singaporeans like myself love this place.
It is a food paradise with a wide variety of affordable local delicacies!
I visited Chomp Chomp on a Thursday night at 730pm thinking that since it was a weekday, there would not be many people.
Well, I was wrong.
Chomp Chomp was packed with people!
It was difficult getting a table for four person.
We had to strategically position ourselves (like vultures) at certain tables, hoping to 'secure' a table.
It was nearly 20 minutes later, before we got a table for four.
Do remember to take note of your table number.
This is because you would need this number when ordering as all the food (including drinks such as sugar cane) would be served to you at your table.
As for payment, some stalls would collect payment upon order while some stalls would collect payment only upon serving the food at your table.
Some customers maybe concerned about this, but I have never encountered any instances where by the food was not served after payment.
There were at least three barbecue (BBQ) Chicken Wing stalls at Chomp Chomp Food Centre.
We ordered ours from Daily Fresh BBQ Chicken Wings 夜鲜烧烤鸡翅膀 which was located next to Chomp Chomp Hai Wei Yuan Seafood BBQ 忠忠海味园BBQ海鲜烧烤.
Each piece of BBQ Chicken Wing from Daily Fresh BBQ Chicken Wings cost $1.20.
In fact, all the BBQ Chicken Wing stalls in Chomp Chomp sell their chicken wings at the same price.
The BBQ Chicken Wings from Daily Fresh BBQ Chicken Wings were tender and succulent.
I love the charred parts especially those near the tail end of the wings.
Like most people, I preferred to squeeze the lime over the chicken wings to give them an extra zest.
Having said that, I am of the opinion that the BBQ Chicken Wings were good, but not fantastic.
The natural flavour was not brought out and it lacked the fragrant aroma which is the hallmark of a well-executed piece of BBQ Chicken Wing.
The chilli sauce provided was quite good and played the perfect role as a dipping sauce, enhancing the overall taste up a notch.
Detailed review: foodiefc.blogspot.sg/201…
Terrible service the pics are deceitful and the shakes were horrible!
Please don't go there
I should preface this brief review by stating categorically that I'm on firmer ground with  Scotch Whiskeys and beer.
I just never got round to wine,  I guess, and on the few occasions where it was necessary socially to cross paths with vino, it was always uncomfortable, hoity-toity and inaccessible.
Which is why I appreciate the guys at Wine Culture being super patient with me and never hard selling me on anything.
I've read tips that other Yelpers have had bad experiences here and I'm sorry to hear that, but I'm guessing that might have been at the "old" Wine Culture (see pic labeled "Wine Cult?").
I have to admit that I've only ever stepped in here after they renovated and expanded.
Kenny has always been more than happy to share what he knows about their inventory and always glad to offer helpful suggestions based on what you're likely to need wine for.
I usually appreciate service providers who have good product knowledge and are happy to put that knowledge at your disposal.
I also like the fact that every visit for me is edifying.
Who says education costs money?
Ah one of my favorite duck rice places.
They sell braised duck only, but what I like is the whole set.
From the rice, to the duck to the sauce.
The rice is really really well done.
While it does not come across as strong tasting, it is fragrant for me.
It contains peanuts inside as well!
Besides that, the lean duck meat that they serve is really very tender and soft.
I absolutely love it and I feel that this place is one of the more unknown places that Singaporean foodies usually would have missed out when going on a food trail.
To top it off, their sauce is superb!
I like it as it is not too sweet and it is fragrant.
The whole plate comes together very nicely and at an affordable price $3.50.
The stall is operated by an old couple so do expect that the stall have slightly slower service.
But be patient!
Your patience will be rewarded with an excellent plate of duck rice.
Another good chicken rice place in Singapore with a long queue during meal hours.
Singapore just doesn't seem to run out of nice chicken rice places doesn't it?
Well, Seng Bee's stall is more popular for their Lemon Chicken RIce though.
The lemon sauce is sweet and the fried chicken is crispy enough to accompany the soft rice.
The price is also not that expensive as well, coming in at only $3.50 for a plate.
However, when I'm with friends, we would order half a chicken at $11 and several portions of rice.
One thing to add is their crispy tofu which is really well done as well.
It's nearly a staple for my friends and I when we eat at Seng Bee.
Don't worry about the long queue, their service is really quite fast and the food will reach you within 10 minutes of ordering.
One thing that my friends have told me about is that their curry chicken noodles are very good as well.
I have not hat the chance to taste it because I really prefer their lemon chicken rice.
For those who read it and prefer curry chicken, do try it out and leave a note if it's as good as my friends say!
We had our lunch here, was impressed by the staff who were attending to us.
We ordered the lunch special - pasta with stew beef which was well done n tasty.
The truffle mushroom fries were delicious although it wasn't impressive looking when it arrived on our table.
The price of the special lunch set was reasonable n affordable!
We will be back for ore :)
In the mass of satay stalls in this food centre, Teddy Bear stood out because it serves Chinese style satays - which means you get pork satays.
My personal favorite satay has always been chicken and I tend to like the Chinese style better as chunky pieces of meat is used rather than minced meat.
Teddy bear does it this way too.
They also serves up a good BBQ chicken wings.
Lean and succulent, nicely marinated.
The wings are not overly fatty so you can still eat up the crispy skin guilt-free (or as much as you'd like to believe).
They only open for lunch on weekends and public holidays.
In the evenings, they also have the tendency to run out by 8.30pm.
So get there early to avoid disappointment.
Good value good taste.
One of those stalls that provide good food at good price points typical of good hawker type foods.
Probably good enough for repeat customers, unlikely to become hawker legends.
The ingredients for a typical Kueh Chap is intestines!
But, I don't see intestines.

I see and ate tongue, pork belly, egg, skin, dao-pok (dried and fried soyabean squares), small side of green marinated vegetables (there's probably a name for it, I just don't know what) The taste is acceptable, but unmemorable.
The kueh chap (the flat square noodles) that comes with the order taste exceptionally good.
It retains its texture, shape, cooked just right.
It is soaked in the same brown sauce but diluted enough, not too salty, but still gives it flavor.
The chilli is good enough; vingearish and spicy enough.
Also quite common and forgetably average.
If you are not interested in Q-ing for food here, this stall can satisfy.
Fish soup with Bittergourd slices.
Another decent fish soup noodles or rice place at decent prices.
Anything good enough to generate a Q during lunch hour, is quite a safe bet.
Fresh fish slices.
Nice, comfort food.
I had a quick lunch here today, pleasantly surprised to discover the chinatown point branch, after having eaten at sunshine plaza a few times.
I had the liu sha bao, which was warm, gooey, sweet and salty at the same time.
Only point for improvement is the bun itself; it was not as soft and fine as the best buns should be.
On the side, I had fried prawn rolls.
Crispy, with a dipping sauce that cuts the oiliness and brings out the umami.
Service was fast and efficient.
No fancy ambience, just focus on the food.
Speedy service, busy atmosphere, fast food of subpar taste, rowdy children running amok, just like any other Mac Donald's outlet.
Love the close proximity to junction 8 and the surrounding HDB blocks...truly a good excuse to have a cheat day
In recent times I have been disappointed again and again after visiting a newly opened Japanese restaurant.
First it was Hajime in Atlanta which I had happily served them a 1 star rating and now Kotobuki Izakaya a 2 stars.
At least Kotobuki has friendly staffs and to go boxes!!
My sis wanted to take me out for lunch and suggested this newly opened Japanese restaurant yesterday.
The restaurant clearly looked like new.
The decor and ambience definitely looks authentic and amazing as well.
What so not amazing was the Tonkotsu ramen.
There is nothing Tonkotsu in my ramen.
Tonkotsu ramen's broth main ingredient is pork bone.
There is no sight of the rich white pork based style broth here.
The gyozas are alright and my sister complained her coffee tasted sour.
I just read the the restaurant's culinary team Master Chef originally hailed from Fukuoka.
He should know better than many about Tonkotsu since it is commonly used in Hakata style ramen common in Hakata district in the city of Fukuoka.
2 stars here from me is simply to give this restaurant a chance since it is so new and for the friendly staffs.
There's a reason they added an "Xtra" at the back of the name: this place is huge!
I think it takes up more than half of all available floor space in AMK Hub's basement, and houses virtually everything you can imagine a supermarket would carry.
But you can't possibly cram everything under one roof, so for things like electronics and furniture I still prefer to go to more specialised brands as the selection here is quite small.
And forget about buying clothes and shoes here, there's nothing good of that sort.
The fresh and frozen food section, on the other hand, is just marvellously comprehensive.
I'm not much of a chef, but I've always been able to find everything I need there.
Some of the cooked food are also great in a pinch, like the sushi.
The alcohol section is also pretty good.
They've recently added some self-checkout machines, but I don't think it has served it's intended goal of speeding up crowd dispersal.
Many people still stand confused in front of the machines.
Maybe it'll be better off in the long term, but for now try to avoid the evening peak period if you can.
Good if you are looking for cheaper prices and all Asian stuff.
But my informants told me that not all items are always cheaper than NTUC.
Some are a little more.
Perfect for the older generation as most of the cashiers/staff speaks mandarin.
The cashiers are also really helpful as they sometimes help carry the bags to the cars when the store is not too busy.
One star for that!
Also a wine shop with a wide variety of wines, Miss U Café serves Western cuisine at affordable prices.
It is a quiet and dimly lit café with tealight candles that is suitable for dates or gatherings.
The ambience is cozy, immediately making one feel at home.
They even have couches at the back of the café, for customers who prefer to have a more laidback meal or wish to lounge.
The chicken wings at Miss U Café are to die for!
Each wing was fried till crispy on the outside and juicy on the inside.
Every bite into the chicken wings created an explosion of flavor in my mouth; it was just that good.
Other dishes that are recommended and raved about include their Fried Calamari, Ham and Mushroom Pizza, Salmon Hollandaise and Lamp Chops.
Miss U Café also serves New Zealand All Natural ice cream, with an ice cream cooler with all the flavors on display at the counter.
Your dessert orders of the Brownie or Crepes would come with the ice cream of your choice.
With exemplary service, and warm and attentive staff, I really cannot find anything wrong with this place.
The McCafé at Tampines Mall deserves some honorable mention!
It has one of the most relaxing and chill environment a McCafé can get.
For this outlet, the McDonald's side and the McCafé is separated, which gives a sense of exclusivity as you enjoy a good cup of coffee.
Service wise, it's thumbs up!
Even if you order just a simple cup of flat white, the barista will at least bother to do a little latte art for you (this service is not consistently seen at other McCafé outlets).
On the downside, this is not a 24 hour outlet and it can be crowded on weekends and Friday evenings.
Other than that, thumbs up for the superb service!
I love to frequent McCafe for their MELTS.
Chocolate Melts, Cinnamon Melts.. ohhh so sinful.
It's not only cheap and affordable, the people here are nice.
I love their iced tea and their mango smoothie as well.
If you are looking for a good place to cram at McCafe here will be a good place.
On the downside for me, this place is sadly a little far...
NOT MY FIRST TIME HERE PRICE: OKAY I bought cheese fries at $4 but overall the menu price is quite standard like any other fast food restaurant but the snacker boxes are always value for money!
FOOD: AWESOME My cheese fries today were really good.
They were real hot even after waiting for about 10 min before i ate!
The cheese was also nice and warm which is really good, the cheese is not always hot so really good today!
Serving was a little small like it was not completely filled only about 4/5 of the way but its still okay for me.
OVERALL: GOOD just a small snack review today but hope I'll be going there again soon to have a meal and write more reviews!
I found a hair!
:( I want to like this place, but the hair and the odd pesto really makes it lose some points.
I was happy another place opened but sadly it doesn't quite cut it...
Yet.

It's small which means there is a longer line, but that is ok is you expect it, what is not though is seeing the same scoop being used for several toppings and the need to request sauce on the side instead of it being standard.
I was disappointed and I may try it again, however I'm still a fan of omnivore.
More expensive, but much bigger portions and better quality ingredients.
Its the happiest place since childhood.
Airport + McDonald Double Cheese Burger, the perfect combinations.
Carries so much memories!!
The definite stop over place arriving or departing Changi, never missed once :-)
Da Dong and I go way back, to even before I was born.
This is the place that my great grandfather used to bring his granddaughter, i.e.
my mum for dim sum when she was a kid.
So yeah, this place and I, we be homies yo.
It's since been acquired by the Fatty Weng group, which usually spells disaster for food quality.
However, I was pleasantly surprised that the dim sum is still decent, and in my opinion, better than the likes of a drink tea establishment located just opposite.
We swung by on a Tuesday afternoon, looking for lunch.
Strangely enough, we were the only table of locals, and the other customers were all foreigners milling about Chinatown, ordering dishes of chilli crab and jugs of beer.
*coughtouristscough* Our orders: Big bao, har gao, fried carrot cake, fried bean curd skin and shrimp chee cheong fun.
Big bao was so big, it had to be cut into quarters.
Fluffy bread, soft juicy chunks of chicken and an inch of chinese sausage graced the interior.
The chee cheong fun was silky and came tightly packed in a roll, rather than the limp flat thing that I'm used to outside.
Fried carrot cake was a smooshy goodness in a crisp fried exterior, and I gladly burnt my tongue in haste to stuff it into my eat hole.
The har gao was of generous proportion, but a bit of a miss as the skin got dry and hard when left aside for too long.
Fried bean curd skin was good, though the most ho hum of the lot.
I haven't been here in ages, but am impressed that the standard hasn't dropped at all, and that everything seems to be made from scratch.
The bill cometh, and for five items, it set us back $22.85 - rather affordable in comparison to the likes of the drink tea establishment nearby.
Need to return to Da Dong as soon as I can round up more dim sum kakis.
A Gem of a Find Ever since the gf and family moved to Cantonment, finding good, reasonably cheap food has been a bit of a challenge.
Not that there aren't good food around, just that with Maxwell and Chinatown about a 10-15 mins walk away, there are those days that you don't really feel like walking that far.

And when it comes to breakfast, the options get even slimmer, with most of the f&b outlets around the area being either higher end restaurants, hipster cafés or Korean restaurants (14 Korean outlets along Tanjong Pagar Rd).
So it was a great relief to us when we discovered Guangdong Porridge.
It isn't the first time we've seen this place but we never had the chance to try it till recently.
Tucked away in a small coffee shop (with quite frankly a pretty hipster name, Henly Huat Drink Food Court) is Guangdong porridge.
Located at the junction of Keong Saik Street and Neil Rd, the coffee shop is one of those places you'll never really take notice off, especially when driving.

No bright fancy lights, no huge crowds (essentially because there aren't that many seats to begin with), this little coffeeshop certainly has it's faithful followers (I've seen, who I would assume as one of Luxe Singapore's bosses, buying porridge 2 out of the 3 times I've been here).
They have around 4 stalls here (I think).
Yong Tau Foo, Fishball noodle (which looks pretty popular as well), I believe a Tze Char and of course, Guangdong Porridge.
I'll make it clear though, if you're a fan of the super smooth, Crystal Jade style of porridge, than this may or may not be your cup of tea.
While it's still a smooth bowl of porridge, it is definitely a more coffee shop, wholesome, heart warming, comfort food style porridge.
Century Egg and Lean meat porridge ($3.50) A staple of any porridge store, the century egg and lean meat porridge is fantastic.
It comes with a generous amount of century eggs that compliments the porridge perfectly.
Mixed Pork porridge ($5.00) Now this has to be one of their signature dishes.
Ingredients wise, very generous!
3 meat balls (which were so tender and juicy), lean meat, liver and intestines.
And best of all, none of these items were over cooked!
Everything was well balanced, well poached and added so much flavour into the porridge.
Only drawback would be that the lean meat is a bit tough and if you're not a fan of bloody liver, you might want them to cook it a little longer for you.

I'm very particular with my coffee shop porridges, from the claypot style frog leg porridges to these little one bowl wonders and nothing makes me happier than saying that Guangdong Porridge hits all the right spots.
To me, the key to Guangdong porridge is to not over complicate the dish, at the same time, ensuring that all the ingredients that go into the porridge are cooked absolutely perfect.

Be warned though, the lady taking the orders can be a little fierce, especially when you're undecided, but with the prices they're offering and the quality of food they're serving, I suppose they can afford to be that little bit fierce.
I'm already drooling writing this and I can't wait for this weekend's dosage.
Consistent quality, value for money, great taste!
This is another one of those local food made good which has multiple outlets now.
I always like it's lor mee, and now my favorite here is the fried fish lor mee.
The soup base is consistent with the other stalls, and the fried fish version $4 is my favorite for now.
The original version is only $2.50, and who sells at this price now?
Remember to add a table spoon of chilli, and a table spoon of garlic, and a few squeeze of vingear.
This will create a memorable event each time you eat here.
No need photos to recall.
From cold crabs, pork trotter jelly to yam-pumpkin and ginkgo nut paste, Lee Kui is the place to go to for authentic Teochew cuisine.
Established in 1968, it is still a popular place for birthday dinners.
The decor may be old school but the diners are here for the food than its ambience.
Sadly, Lee Kui will be closing its doors in mid-December.
It's summer!
And then you stumble upon an ice-cream parlour.
A Ben & Jerry's ice cream parlour!
Step right in, you will see two large ice-cream freezer displays with all the various flavours.
I was spoilt for choices.
I have always been a fan of Ben & Jerry's ice cream ever since I was a kid.
But eating those frozen desserts freshly scooped from it's parlour is something else.
Besides, they always have some special flavours which are not sold in those pints at your everyday supermarkets.
The place is one of the spacious B&J outlets I've been to.
It's great that they also have cold water dispenser.
I bought the "Mix & Match" combo, a choice of 3 scoops, served in a waffle bowl.
You should not NOT take advantage of those toppings available.
I chose peanuts and those colourful 100-thousands.
A real-deal of perfect sugar rush.
My companion bought a brownie that is served with 2-scoops.
Both of us chose the Cookie Dough flavour as one of our scoops, and gosh was it delish!
Been coming here for years and my fav was the goldrush.
Got a shock today for a change of flavor they charge $1 for that???
What's up with that?
Not asking for one more scoop or was it too much work to remember the change??
For this.....a bad star for you Swensen.
Also there seems to be a change in staff as everything seems a little slower.
Ice cream = yum!
I like Udders for its range of flavours (most places have one durian flavour--Udders has THREE) but mostly for its proximity to my house.
It's become a very convenient and welcome place for meetups with friends because hey, everyone likes ice cream, and it keeps the children entertained.

They're famous for their liquor flavours, though they're not really my thing; I find that sometimes the strength of the alcohol overwhelms the flavours, and sometimes the ice creams turn out icey rather than smooth.
But hey, everyone needs lemoncello sorbert and the sugary overload of snickers-mars-honeycomb once in a while!
Also: watch out for new flavours and ask the staff about them--sometimes they're testing new flavours and will give you a scoop to sample!
It has been years since I visited this store and now, they expanded another section where they serve all day breakfast dishes, pancakes, mille crepes, and more.
Prior to visiting this store, I ate quite a bit for dinner.
My friend called me out of nowhere and asked me whether I would like to join her and her boyfriend here.
As this place is pretty close in terms of proximity, I said yes without much hesitation.
As this store is located at a street, you could either parallel park your vehicle or head to the public carpark to park the car.
You would need parking coupons here till 10pm.
After 10pm, parking is free.
Walked into the store and I realized there is two sections for ice cream.
One with alcoholic related flavors and one without.
And on top of the ice cream display, you can find sundae menus.
Before deciding the flavor I would like to have, I browsed through the sundae menu and hence I ordered a scoop of Alphonso Mango.
It is more like a sorbet gelato than an ice cream.
My friends ordered three scoops of ice-cream with waffle.
As I was extremely full, I just took a picture of their food instead of trying out the waffle.
Space wise, it definitely had expanded.
The newer section had interesting fire extinguisher boxes which had different sayings on it.
Some tables had also shadow boxes that they use to contain stuff animals.
It does looks like a cafe after they extend the shopfront.
Since I didn't pay for my single scoop, I can't comment much on the price.

But I definitely like the interior design of the newer section of the store especially at the entrance door made of glass and pieces of broken glass inside the multi-layered glass door (forgot to take a picture of it).
Will try their other foods or desserts the next time round.

I am not good in writing, but I really enjoy hanging out at this place ... Cosy and conform place with crispy warm waffles... chilled by tasteful ice cream can't feel any better now... Do come to have a look and you won't regret...
$1.50 for ice cream???
Hell to the no!
Walk about 15 steps towards the Central and you'll find an Uncle selling it for $1.00--the proper Singaporean price for a slice of ice cream.
As we wondered around Clark Quay we found this gentlemen selling ice cream.
I purchased a cookies and cream and we sat on the bridge watching the night scene.
One for the budget traveller!
For $1.50 you receive a slab for ice cream and two biscuits sandwiched on top to make a ice cream sandwich.
One of my favourite moments in Singapore
Decent food decent price.
No Hawker Legend.
Not in the mood for Q today, settling for safe and comfort food.

No Mood for Spring After This Cuisine Yechun Express, a newly opened Chinese restaurant in Chinatown Point, was opened to celebrate Yangzhou's 2,500 year heritage, showcasing the best of Yangzhou Cuisine.
The name Yechun, apparently means to cultivate the mood for spring.
Unfortunately, the only mood this restaurant cultivated for us was disappointment.
The restaurant looked decent enough.
Tea house style setting, nothing overly fancy, but where it fails terribly is in its service and most importantly, it's food.
Because it's a newly opened establishment, I'll give the service some leeway, since every restaurant has its teething problems but the food, the food is one thing I can't forgive.
Salted Duck Soup.
One word.
Disgusted.
While it wasn't the worst tasting soup we've ever tasted, it certainly offered the biggest let down.
Served to us in a steaming bowl, we were initially pretty excited, however, once the lid came off, we thought we were pranked!
Inside the bowl lay 3 wolfberries, a couple of preserved vegetable and 3 miserable....
MISERABLE pieces of duck, which looked more like spare parts you take off the chopping board and threw it in for the sake of it.
While I can understand that the rent may be high and this is a way of saving cost, it's ridiculous to be paying nearly $10.00 for and duck soup when there's barely any duck in it.
In fact, it was almost an insult to be served it.
A quick check with the staff taking orders if this is the way it's normally served and the only response was "yes it's like that".
The taste?
3 words, MSG.
There wasn't much of a duck or salted veg flavour to it.
While it didn't reek of MSG, it certainly was present.
Pork Dumpling La Mien.
Free oil anyone?
While the dumpling were decent enough and the noodles were cooked well.
However the soup itself?
OOOIIILLLYYY.
While I'm not expert in China or Yangzhou cuisine, I'm pretty sure that he soup isn't meant to THAT oily.
Liu Sha Bao Hmmmm well...
I'll give it one positive remark, at least the custard "flowed" but that's about it.
It was too sweet and didn't have much of a salted egg taste.
The bun itself was really thick as well.
Not a favorite.
Steamed pork dumpling The only saving grace of the meal.
The bun's flour was the right thickness and the stock inside was really good.
Would have happily eaten 5 of these over the duck soup any day.
Overall... Way below par.

While the giant bun/dumpling was good, everything else was below average and it takes the cake that, while I'm questioning the staff and commenting out loud that the soup is a joke, the owner (maybe manager) just sits there, in the dining area, looking bored.
Excuse me but ermmmm..... Thats not very professional.
Will we be back... That's a very decisive N.O.
Very good rice dumplings!
At $3.50 a dumpling, it's very expensive.
Even when it taste great.
The pork portion is pretty decent, and it's soft in the mouth.
The flavours is abundant, and the glutinous rice is cooked just right.
The salted egg york sitting there on the mushroom begging to be devoured.
Will I come here again?
Yes.
Will I still pay $3.50 for a dumpling?
Probably.
I tried the chicken dumpling with salted egg yolk, mushroom and chestnut.
It is quite big and is soft.
That means it sticks to the leaves and it is hard to unwrap it whole.
It has tasty though I find it a bit on the salty side.
I do love the whole salted egg yolk.
Great place for breakfast!
We got some kaya toast, coffee and milk tea and it was amazing!!
The butter was plentiful and the drinks were strong; just the way I like it!
We tried the hokkien mee and char kway teow.
Unlike many places in Singapore, the flavors are right for this Penang, Malaysia dish.
However, the flavors are a bit dull and don't replicate their Penang counterparts well.
The hokkien mee has the right flavor overall, but doesn't pack the spicy punch you would expect of the dish.
Similarly, although much closer to the true dish, the char kway teoh has a bit of charred noodle flavor, but not quite enough excitement to make it excellent.
It seems as if the dishes and recipes are generally correct, but perhaps the ingredients aren't the best or the chef is not the most experienced.
This place is on the verge of having quite good food at a fair price, but it just falls a bit short in terms of flavor.
Walk along this little segment of Upper Cross Street and you'll inevitably be tempted by the sights and sounds of soy sauce chicken being served.

There are two very similar shops lined up not far from each other; this review is about the one further up Upper Cross Street, closer to People's Park Complex, mainly because this is the one my mom has been coming to for years now, and mothers always know best!
On the shop front you will see these greasy glistening golden brown chickens hanging as they would in the standard chicken rice stall.
The usual order here would be a plate of their famous soy sauce chicken noodles, which manages to balance tastes so that it is not too salty, not too oily, and yet a little bit sweet.
The noodles are not the springy sort, yet not too fine, and the texture of the whole thing just works a treat.
Of course the chicken is so tender, yet very meaty.
The chilli is a wonderful sort of spicy (even for me who is not the biggest fan of spicy), and even a little sweet as well.
A portion at $3.50 may not look too sizeable, but I always seem to feel stuffed even without wiping the plate clean, so such good value here!
You may even call in this shop to pre-order for takeaways, so you could drive by and they would deliver right to the car.
If not driving, they would have it prepared for your arrival anyway without any fuss.
As much as I know, no other frozen yoghurt chains around serves flavors that are as rich as what is served at Berrylite!
It's like, the flavors are so special I don't even know if they are still yoghurt or not.
They have many flavors, including strawberry cheesecake.
It is supposedly 100% fat-free, so it's the taste of happiness, minus the guilt!
What a win-win situation it is.
This is a rather small store, so there are really limited seats around.
More for take-away I think!

Once Upon A Milkshake (OUAM) has long enchanted milkshake lovers at their outlet at Maxwell Chambers with their gobsmacking range of creations, but you will be glad to know that they have graduated to Orchard Rd.
Grumbling Raisins or Agent Strawberry is sure to knock your socks off as alcoholic rum and rum-soaked raisins are in abundance.
Their milkshakes are not only creamy and thick - they are just plain dreamy.
There's no way you can walk into such a gaily coloured shop and still feel down.
On the flipside, there's no way you can walk into such a gaily coloured shop without gagging a little.
The Baskin Robbins at Nex in truth isn't very comfortable, but the ice cream is all you need to distract you from that!
The variety of flavours on display should bring out the kid in everyone.
Don't forget to ask the staff behind the counter for a small sample if you're unsure of which one to order.

I've never tried any of their cakes, but the way they stare at me through the glass fridge doors is just unsettling, and I may have to end up buying one one day just so I don't get an unexpected visit in the middle of the night by the cake mob.
Baskin Robbins formed a major part of my childhood and I was ecstatic when an outlet finally opened at Nex.
What I really adore about Baskin Robbins is its fun and colourful atmosphere.
Everything about the brand name reveals youth and pure joy.
Some ice-cream flavours I really like are Pistachio Almond, Coconut and the deliciously sweet Pralines 'N Cream.
I love ice cream, but I love smoothies and yoghurts even more.
Thakfully, the yogurt smoothies in Berry Burst and Mixed Berries flavours are blissfully rewarding.
Thick and flavourful, the smoothies gel both the creamy texture of yogurt and fruity flavour of berries to perfection.
Best enjoyed on a warm day!
Of course they are not to be outdone by Baskin's signature ice cream shakes.
Vanilla and strawberry flavours taste best to me.
Dine-in is available too although I would have preferred a few more tables and chairs to be placed around the "island" stall.
I thought the bubble tea bubble would burst.
Apparently not for Singaporeans.
Even popular foods get a chance at revival if you're really superb at it.
Following the footsteps of Koi bubble tea in leading the bubble tea revival, A gantea is a relatively unknown bubble tea shop.
Now, I must say that there are many shops that have popped out of nowhere and claim to have been the real deal in bubble tea business with a long history of bubble tea with real authentic skills.
A gantea seems to be one of them but I was actually convinced that they are actually not bad and might be here to stay to fight with Koi and Gong Cha.
I ordered their signature A gantea ($3.50 for large) and it tasted pretty good.
It wasn't so sweet and it had the tea fragrance.
While I still feel that it does not beat big players like Koi bubble tea in terms of the blend consistency, I feel that it was good enough for me to be a fan of theirs.
For those who are bored of Koi or Gong cha, do give them a try.
The prices are really quite cheap as well.
Step aside mainstream Japanese restaurant chains (not going to mention which, you know who they are!
), Kinsa's the new in restaurant when it comes to quick, easy, reasonably priced Japanese meals!
The location of the restaurant itself is very convenient (those who live in Hillview can attest to this.)
and it provides a good alternative to the regulars at Railmall which doesn't have a Japanese restaurant.
I am a huge fan of donburi dishes.
We ordered a beef donburi and unagi donburi.

The quality of the dishes is very good considering the price paid (60+ for two donburis, one sashimi and one sushi dish) as well as the serving time; it took less than 5 minutes for all our food to arrive!
Surprisingly, the food took just as fast to disappear from my bowl.
It was good enough to satisfy my daily craving for meat on rice.
Sibei Shiok lah!
The sushi roll ordered was only "ok-ok" you wouldn't miss out much if you skipped it.
That being said, the dishes served were not as warm as I would have expected, this is not to say they were cold but only lukewarm at best.
But that does not discount the fact that the food is still decently good!!!
To sum it up, Kinsa provides a much better and newer alternative for quick and convenient Japanese dinning, definitely worth the shot!
Place is often empty, if not, only a couple few tables occupied.
I can understand why this is so.
The menu has limited choices which u can choose from.
Took me around 15 mins to decide, would be better if they vary their selections.
Ordered a mixed seafood don but was pretty disappointed with the rice.
The seafood itself was alright, not super fresh but doable.
But the rice...
It's dry and hard.
The rice they use, if I'm not wrong, is a low grade Japanese rice (Similar to the texture of Vietnamese rice).
It feels like a combination of local economy rice together with sashimi, just doesn't work.
I always believe rice is the most basic/fundamental element to Japanese food and thus, shows how high or how low is the standard of a restaurant.
With this as a judging factor, I would rank this restaurant low on the scale.
I cook a lot and am also a fan of Japanese cuisine... the don I had here.. Hmm... Service wise, was good.
They were friendly, hospitable and accommodating.
Was done with the rice and wanted to order something more hence tried calling the service crew.
No one attended to me despite calling for 7 times.
I gave up and walked over to the cashier, told them I wanted to order more but no one came.
They apologised profusely (it seemed like the chef and waitress was having an intensive chat).
They don't charge GST, only service charge.
Overall, food quality wise, it's slightly below average.
With the price range, I would rather go for another chain instead of paying for something of a lower quality.
So the verdict is, doubt I'll be back again!
A place that looks so amazing has average food and high prices.
It's a little bit downhill from the beginning with this place for me.
The interior and exterior of this joint has a decent decoration with pretty Ganesha pictures.
It's lovely because it's spacious and has some very interesting benches just outside.
However when i came here for lunch and ordered, the safest bets for good food came out mediocre.
That included the gobi manchurian, paneer butter masala and mutton rogan josh.
The chicken biryani was the only thing i thought was genuinely pretty good.
The food here is solid.
My colleague who knows his Indian food swears by this place and says his friends also call it a favorite.
That's good enough for me.
Upon being seated, a big banana leaf is placed in front of you and a gentleman walks by with 3 containers full of food to slop off on the leaf.
You choose your main dish whether it's a fish curry, mutton this and that, chicken curry, masala, etc.
I chose the Masala Chicken.
They bring your choice on a small plate and another guy comes by with a big bowl of rice.
The rice guy is Chinese and I was so tempted to make some kind of inappropriate joke, but I held back.
"Why the rice guy gotta be Chinese?"
Didn't think it would fly w/ my coworkers.
Anyhoo they give you as much rice as you wish and always come by to give you more if you wish.
Also another guy comes by with your choice of curry sauce (fish or chicken) and drowns the rice in it.
I ate with my hand to go for the full experience.
Afterwards, they have a couple of nice sinks with good handsoap to wash off the turmeric stains from your fingers.
After your meal they bring you a small cup of warm tapioca pudding.
It was quite tasty with cashews and some other stringy ingredient (wasn't sure what it was).
Coworker also urged me to try the butter milk.
First time trying it and that was definitely not the taste I was expecting.
It's like drinking pureed cheese.
Not sure what the bill came out to as colleague generously paid for us 4.
I'd return for a nice Indian meal.
I was walking around the hood and stumbled on this place by accident.
I didn't really know what to expect, no one spoke English, and all I saw were my fellow blue collar friends from different mothers...awesome.
With my hand gestures and pointing, the waiter brought a banana leaf, and start dumping food on it...yogurt, curry, yellow rice, list goes on.
Funniest part was the rice, the waiter brought this helmet looking metal bowl full of rice.
As everyone else, I used my hands to dine.
I did smell like Indian food all day but so what!?
It was too much food and I had to fold the leaf as a sign that I had enough.
There was no desert, but I got a cup of coffee.
Paid about $9, which I think was great deal.
This is not a typical touristy joint, and surely not for everyone, but there is nothing wrong with taking a chance on the back alley of Singapore...
We had a long layover in Changi from Bali.
with the time change our meal schedule was super screwed up.
but, nonetheless we were hungry.
So, we sought out Michi from the directory.
There were no reviews on yelp, but we took a chance :) Kept it vegetarian with red curry and biryani and a side of garlic &  butter naan.
The curry had a mild spice to it, which was a nice surprise!
Also, our food was out pretty quick...
I would definitely recommend.
Get sizzling mix grill if you want some fiery flair on your food.
The waiter will dutifully pour some liquor and light the flame on the grilled food.

There is finally some proper interest in craft beer in Singapore, thanks to the twin events of the Straits Times article on craft beer by Ms. Anjali Raguaraman to coincide with Beerfest Asia 2016, all in the month of June 2016!

Don't get me wrong, this tsunami's been coming for a while, but the fact that there is enough interest in craft to devote print inches to coincide with a calendar event is for the want of a better word, big.

Hop Shop opened well before all this happened, but the point I'm trying to make here, as I also alluded to in my review of Mikkeller Bar's opening in Singapore, is that that there is enough interest in craft beer now in the middle of 2016 to ensure that those of us in the nascent beer geek movement in Singapore get ever more easy access to  supplies of fresh craft!

While I am not in any way endorsing their entire stock (they also do a trade in aromatherapy), I can vouch for the three beers that I had from the Hop Shop, all from La Débauche, all fresh and which I have not found anywhere else in Singapore yet.
These beers were fresh (I just cannot emphasize how excited I am about this simple, oft taken for granted fact), interesting and well worth all 1000 kCal or so of carbs.

I'm just happy that the business savvy in Singapore are realizing that it is well worth their while and the aggravation to import fresh craft beer into Singapore because there most certainly is a growing appetite and an almost urgent need to have fresh craft beers with an interesting and sometimes even hip palette of flavors and aromas.

That just means that grizzled beer geeks like myself get to ride the wave of hipster interest in craft beer all the way into the shore of the mainstream retail market,  on this surge of interest in craft beers, enjoying fresh beers without having to endure stale beers served up due to indifference or ignorance.

So, when you drop by, say Hi to Luc (the friendly dude behind the aromatherapy counter with the faint French-Singlish accent) and part with some of your precious wampum in exchange for what you might recall years later as your first step into the warm inviting amniotic sac of beer geekdom.
Recently I read an article saying that 'Mos Burger' is one of the brands from Japan that foreigners can't actually comprehend (because they also relate 'Mos' to 'moss').
Many might not know that 'Mos' actually stands for mountain, ocean and sun!
Back to Mos Burger, like aforementioned, it is a brand of burger from Japan.
Other than the usual bun burgers, they also have what you call the 'rice burger'.
This is probably not available anywhere else and is unique to Mos Burger.
I don't necessary love rice, but the rice burger at Mos Burger is irresistible!
With the nice Japanese meat patties and sauce to go along, it's a great great match!
The sides, such as the Mos chicken and butterfly prawns are also very delicious!
The Mos chicken in particular, is really crispy and juicy.
And it does not dirty your hand as they have a special paper packaging that keeps your hands clean.
I also like to order either the milk tea or the corn soup to go along to complete the meal.
Pretty good for a fast food!
I was at the mall and starving - never heard of MOS burger so a quick google search revealed it's history and I was of course instantly intrigued.
I tried the regular chicken burger along with a croquette.
The burger was much smaller than I expected and under $5, but I'd almost claim it as 'overpriced' for what the serving really was.
Pretty flavorful although I couldn't tell if the chicken was overcooked or not.
Nonetheless, still a quick enjoyable bite.
The croquette was soft (and greasy jeeeeez) but nothing personally to write home about.
I'd come back and try their other offerings during my next fast food fix... despite the first not as wonderful experience, I'd still definitely prefer this over McDonald's any day.
I have been wanting to try out Sushi Burrito since I am a huge fan of Sushiritto in San Francisco.
But i wont compare them because they are different although they have similar appearance.
I was a bit skeptical since I heard a lot of my friends that Sushi Burrito is just so-so.
The first bite, I tried to compare it with what I had in SF.
But i began to remove those thought as soon as I had my second bite.
They are different.
It taste so good and still fresh although i doubt it when i arrive at the stall and looking at those sushiburrito that already displayed.
They just took those premade sushi and served it.
Although it is still good, i wish they can make it fresh.
Idk how it works for people who order half size.
Maybe they will make the fresh version of that?
Perhaps.
So i just want to conclude my review that Sushi Burrito is a better version of handroll sushi that i usually have.
It taste better than normal sushi or hand roll.
It has good appearance.
But perhaps, maybe more experimental flavor/sauce in the future.
Note: the wasabi burned me
Meh.
The sushi burrito is alright.
I've had better and would not recommend this.
They have a display of their various sushi burrito options on the window for you to choose from.
You can either get a half burrito or full burrito.
The rice was bland and the veggies tasted old (not fresh).
I  got the rainbow shrimp burrito, which consisted of prawn tempura.
However the prawn tempura was mushy and soft on the outside.
You can tell that the burrito had been sitting out for a while and not fresh.
FYI: It's located at the Changi Airport in the Terminal 1 departure gate near gate C.
Was there yesterday afternoon.
It was many people having sushi as their lunches, so did I!
The best I think was the miso soup with tofu and salmon.
Sushi was ok ok lah with the price of $1.5 per plate(not included 10% service charge and 7% gst).
But I couldnt ingest the diced octopus one becoz the washabi smell is too strong.
Other than that, everything seems alright.
Everybody was both eating sushi and watching the loved sushi to pick running on the conveyer belt.
It feels like I needed to eat and needed to work as well haha.
To me it's affordable when it comes to sushi for my sushi craving.
Bottom line: I will come back again.
Not an amazing McDonald's , but at least they didn't charge me for extra pickles!
I love those things... Quarter pounder was a bit dry and the pickles were thrown at the burger, however flavour remained the same as all the others in the world.
They have this machine that transports food upstairs (I have no idea where as I didn't go up there...) which makes it seem Super high tech!
Good for a snack or meal when not much is open.
This is the only Western cuisine stall in the Hwa Chong Institution College Canteen, but its standard is far from satisfactory.
Most of its dishes have mushroom, which some people including me are allergic about.
As a result, we are left with no choice but to eat the tomato sauce spaghetti, fish and chips or another dish with butter and spaghetti.
The stall owner has used Italian names for almost all the dishes, and since I am not an Italian, I was unable to remember the names clearly.
To me, the tomato sauce spaghetti is the best the stall can offer.
It is quite delicious with suffient sauce poured onto the spaghetti.
It costs S$2.50, but it is too little to eat.
Even if you add 50 cents more to order a bigger plate of it, it is still not very sufficient.
Fish and chips is the stall's worst dish.
Fish fried till it is too stiff to cut, and french fries mixed until they are too salty to eat.
In short, this stall CMI!
(a very unique Singaporean acronym of "can't make it!")
Hopefully, next year a new vendor will replace this current vendor.
The million dollar questions: how are they the no.1 korean chicken chain, and how did they survive for 5 years here.
What a waste of precious calories.
This place exudes the kind of Southern country charm that the eponymous country singer Kenny Rogers possesses, serving up good ol' Americana at a rather reasonable price.
I know the place is famous for its chicken, but I was in no mood of that ubiquitous meat, so I ordered Baked Fish with Garlic Parsley Potatoes and Steamed Garden Vegetables as my sides.
The vegetables were standard fare, while the potatoes were rather excellent.
The purplish pink skin of the potatoes was intact, and the fragrance of garlic and parsley made this side dish a particularly appetising one.
The baked fish was good, though the way it was presented on the plate - without any garnish or sauce at all - was pretty austere.
Service was prompt, with my fish arriving in less than the 15 minutes that the waitress informed me it would take to prepare.
It's ok for when I have a sushi craving and don't want to spend much and I want it quick.
It's actually 2 counters side by side with the sushi display in the middle.
The left counter is for the sushi and they sell some rice bowls and chawanmushi as well.
The right counter is for udon.
I've been twice.
Both times the sushi selection was not much to speak of at all but it tasted decent.

They usually have things like inari (sweet beancurd), hana maki (salmon wrapped around rice with mayo - way too much mayo so I scraped off as much as I could), sometimes salmon sashimi, tamago, chuka hotate (seasoned scallop), crab stick.
The basic sushi are sold in pairs around $1.80.
They have sushi packed sets for about $6.80 to $11+, basic salad with salmon sashimi on top and small bowls of cha soba.
The rice was not hard and dry thank goodness.
I also tried the curry udon for about $5.
It was simple comfort food served piping hot.
They call out your number for you to collect when it is ready so you can start chomping on your sushi first while waiting.
You can choose to sit either side of the sitting areas as it's all the same company.
Meh...that is exactly how I felt.
Went for a late lunch and they are already out of sashimi.
I took a glance at the menu and it is mostly salmon anyway, not my favorite fish.
Ordered the oyako don.
It is at best food court quality.
There is more egg than meat, so much chicken skin (read: fat) in the bowl that I resorted to picking out the skin...not cool.
Food court quality Japanese at $9.
No like.
Richie's Cripsy Puff which is located in Jurong East operates around the clock.
Yes!
24 hrs and I'm not kidding.
They offer an interesting spread of variety ranging from the traditional chicken curry puff to durian.
Their puff comes in a standard size different from the typical ones (half an oval shape), like those from Old Chang Kee.
The crust was fried to perfection brown and was very crispy.
Sold for $2.40 for 2, customer can feel free to match any 2 flavours at the pricing.
The selling point of Richie's puff is its delicate handmade craftwork on each and every puff.
With such method, they have more control over the quality, thus its crispiness is of a different levels unlike the others.
The fillings comprised of egg, noticeable chicken chunks, mixed well in the fragrant curry flavou.
The curry was a little big mild for me, for those who do not like too much spice, this may fit the bill.
Muslims pal out there, no worries, this stall is Halal Certified.
What's more this is a good place to look out for snack when hunger pangs in the middle of the night where most eateries are already closed for the day.
Perfect for Morning shifts or night shifts workers too!
I had the luxury of strawberry shortcake not too long ago, when my colleagues decided that a birthday without a cake is not a birthday.
It's not hard to see why the strawberry shortcake is one of PG's bestsellers - airy sponge, light fresh cream, and succulent strawberries.
Most cream cakes are hard to go down after a couple of bites due to the cloying cream or sponge being too dry.
Not this baby though.
Even after a heavy dinner, we still managed to wolf an entire cake down, and no strawberries were spared.
Dainty is the word that comes to mind here, and you can envision yourself sitting with a mug of tea, pinky finger up while digging into the cake.
Third log cake of the year for me and this one is special!
It's a banana chocolate log cake!
At $64 for a 1.1kg cake it is quite pricey, more expensive than the 1kg $68 Mont Blanc log cake I had from Marriott just 2 days ago but I like this cake so much better!
The dark chocolate is not too bitter as the cream is fluffy and light!
The banana in the center is sweet and adds colour to the cake as well!
I really like how the cake has an "old" and "natural" tree, log look to it!
It is cute and delicious, definitely the first cake to score on both criterias!
I do not feel gerlat from eating this dark chocolate banana log cake like I did with the chocolate truffle prima deli log cake.
As a result, I couldn't help going for seconds with this log cake!!
A light and delicious way to end a Christmas party!
There is nothing good to say about the food at Burger King here.
Don't eat here unless you are desperate ... which I was !
Very decent and tasty Wagyu beef burger.
Kinda taste like overeasy's truffle beef burger but just a tad harder.
TOP $2 for cheese Fries instead of the regularly fries.
I like the herbs in their regular side Fries.
Also got an ABC fruit juice with no ice for $7.50.
Ordered pizzas which, am surprised they were hand made, not your typical refrigerated frozen pizza.
There's always just a couple of tables taken even though the food here is pretty good.
I'm guessing it's because of the restaurants overall look and feel (branding), it doesn't seem appealing...
This is a halal restaurant, great for people who are looking for alternatives!
They have bacon in their menu, but fret not, cos it's turkey bacon haha.I'll definitely come here again the next time I'm waiting for arrival flights.
Ice creams come in very local flavour i.e.
Chendol/Milo.
Would also love to try their ice lychee tea, seems Super appealing, pity I've got only one stomach!
Super good value with their $5 express lunches.
A hidden gem of a place at the outer fringes of the CBD.
The stall uncle happens to be one of disciples of the 4 heavenly kings of Singapore Cantonese cuisine.
That itself should speak about the quality of food here.
An added bonus?
One of the pioneers of roast - fatty ox; located just next door :) If you're here for ambience and service, don't expect any.
But if you're here for some delicious, restaurant standard cze char served in little claypots, you've come to the right place.
Recommendations include the sweet and sour pork ( made with real hawthorn!
), kong pao chicken (order this or you'll regret), seafood tofu, pork ribs, crab meat shark fin soup (it uses fish maw despite its name).
Absolute perfection for a cze char stall.
Only downside is it's in a hawker centre and you'll sweat eating hot claypot food.
Small Price to pay anyways.
My girlfriend and I have been regulars here since we moved to Singapore.
In fact, to call us regulars is a bit of an understatement.
We have come here at least 6 times a week for nearly a year and a half.
This place is a true gem.
Mrs. Seow's cooking talents are beyond belief, and Mr. Seow, who serves the food, is a wonderful, gracious and welcoming man.
The food served here is best described as Buddhist (meaning no garlic or onions), organic, vegetarian.
The menu is simple: each day there are 3-4 things written on a board outside.
The first dish on the menu is always a rice-set, which consists of brown rice and side vegetables which change each day.
The second item on the menu is a noodle dish, which also changes each day.
Other items include interesting (and generally quite healthy) desserts.
Some of my favorite dishes here are: Chinese pancake wraps, cold noodles, Sichuan noodle and thunder tea rice.
You'll have to call ahead to find out when these will be served, but show up for lunch or dinner any day of the week and you can't go wrong.
At $5.50 for the noodle dishes and $6.00 for the rice set, you can't go wrong.
If food is medicine, then this place will add years to your life.
value for money western food located in a popular coffee shop.
Crispy chicken wings.
soft buttery bun.
large portion fried rice.
well grilled lamb chop.
Giovanni L. is owning a repertoire of 102 international ice cream varieties.
Most of them are made with our own recipe.

Each year 2 to 3 new flavors of ice cream will be created and several of their gelato flavours are international award winners!Seattle Pike Chowder is under the same management as Giovanni L., and the gelato brought in directly from Germany and decorated in Singapore.
It is hard to turn down a scoop of delicious and fresh gelato!
At one glance, you will notice several different types of chowders and you can havethem with a bread bowl, or in a cup.
Seattle Pike Peak's chowder also offers sandwiches and a combo for a sandwich and a chowder.
They also have a small selection of cakes and pastries but the cakes looked abit dry and stale and I decided to get a muffin instead.
They also serve imported chilled beers which can go very nicely with gelato.
Chocolate Gelato Spaghetti $12.90 A very interesting creation that can only be found at Giovanni is gelato spaghetti.
They have a few flavours, namely, chocolate, vanilla and berries.
I decided to go with chocolates as it came with almonds, hazelnuts and walnuts.
That's a lot of nuts!
I was surprised at it's presentation, with 2 waffle biscuits at the side.
It was nothing like I've ever had before.
The gelato was nice with chocolate syrup drizzled over it.
The gelato here isn't very sweet and is generally milder in flavour, probably the lack of using artificial flavouring.
Underneath the gelato is whipped cream which gives the entire dish a light and creamy feel.
There were so much nuts that I had a nut in every spoonful.
A truly interesting dish, but even though it is gelato stringed into spaghetti, the ice cream melts too fast for you to twirl the ice cream spaghetti up like real spaghetti noodles.
