Apple Cinnamon muffin $3.90The apple cinnamon muffin is pretty sizable with a crunchy and almost crispy like top, that is filled with crusty cinnamon crunch.
The muffin on the inside was a dense with a cinnamon aroma and essence.
There were cubes of apples wrapped around in cinnamon sauce, similar to what you find in a McDonald's apple pie on the inside of the muffin.
It was surprise to me.
It was pretty good muffin and I'm definitely getting it again next time 3.
Smoked Salmon Chowder in a Breadbowl $12.90 This chowder very interesting, as a huge fan of smoked salmon I was intrigued by the tastes.
Seattle's Pike Chowder managed to capture the essence of the smoked salmon blend it in with cream cheese and TA-DA!
You have an amazing bowl of smoked salmon chowder.
I highly recommend this to any fellow smoked salmon lover!
The taste of the smoked salmon comes in strong, as an aftertaste.
This was a very creamy bowl of soup, not much to bite into, just good, flavourful chowder.
A good compliment to any sandwich.
Since this place is literally marketed with "Seattle" on the signboard, all their chowders come directly from Seattle on a daily basis, to ensure top-notch quality.
Their bread however is made locally.
The bread definitely isn't the same bread I had in Seattle.
It was alot fluffier and not as tough, it may suit the locals more, but it is definitely a change.
After Eight ice cream (single scoop) The After Eight was very rich and not as creamy as you would expect, it had a slightly rough texture which would indicate the mint bits embedded into the gelato.
As with any ice cream parlour in Singapore, they melt fast!
But the dining here at Fort Canning is well cooled with power air conditioning.
Having a wide range of gelatos gives me a feeling they are out to fight the already competitive gelato market.
They do not offer typical flavours such as matcha or cookies and cream, but rather very unique flavours like Amorena which is a vanilla gelato with amorena cherries.
It will blow your mind!
Think of a super awesome raspberry ripple!
The frozen yogurt chain is well known in Singapore and has been around for quite awhile.
Recently the chain has introduced the Splitz which one can have unlimited choices in flavours of frozen yogurt and toppings.
There is one kiosk outlet at ION Orchard.
There was 4 flavours of frozen yogurt available : natural, mango, peach, and macadamia nut.
There was a wide range of toppings priced from $0.95 for jelly bean to $2 for macaroon crunch.
As the weather was super hot and there was no queue at the outlet, I decided to order a Splitz as there was too many toppings which I wanted.
As I made my choices in toppings, a queue started to form behind me.
I'm surprised to find a queue stretched to next door by the time I finished making payment.

The Splitz ($5.90) I had selected 4 different flavours for my Splitz : Mango flavour yogurt, topped with French vanilla roasted oats, Macadamia Nut flavour yogurt, topped with caramel syrup & macaroon crunch, Natural flavour yogurt, topped with dried cranberries & strawberry syrup, Peach flavour yogurt, topped with peach.
The mango flavour yogurt tasted the best among the 4 flavours as it has most distinct flavour.
As for the toppings, I like the macaroon crunch the most as it tasted crunchy with hint of salty taste.
With pasta and risotto stalls opening up in Old Airport Road hawker centre, it is a sign that locals now enjoy western and local food all in one location!
Jogurtz is a newly opened stall at the hawker centre, located on the inner rows.
It has a brightly lit stall size with a cheerful logo and a simple menu, small frozen yogurt (froyo) or a large froyo.
The small serving is served with 1 fruit and 1 topping at just $3.50 and the large is served with 2 Fruits/Toppings, 2 fruits and 1 topping at $5.

At one glance, you will notice that they are priced lower than competitors at shopping malls, but one must also consider the lower operating costs and human traffic at this location I picked strawberries, which they gave a generous serving of them, but some strawberries were sweet and some were sour, it was an interesting mix as the froyo itself was icy and sourish.
I like the sour taste as I would rather than a sour tasting froyo than a super sweet and milky froyo, which goes to say how much sugar they toss into the machine!

I also got the Post cereal, Cranberry almond crunch which gave me a crunchy bite in every mouthful, a perfect combination for the soft froyo!I must admit, the small serving is alot larger than I expected, and I checked, both the small and the large serving have almost the same amount of froyo, the large just has more room for toppings.
The froyo started melting instantly once I was done snapping a couple of photos, this is expected as Jogurtz is situated in a hawker centre and our weather is not favourable to ice cold froyo.
But nonetheless, the froyo held up till I managed to scoop to the bottom.
It didn't melt into a froyo drink which was surprising!
Ben & Jerry's as usual very delicious.
There are mee siams and there is Glory mee siam.
and I love Glory mee siam.
More than any other mee siam.
Muslim Nasi Padang.
Basically Muslim mixed rice.
I couldn't have stumbled upon this place since it was quite hidden.
I had to ask for directions.
On the 3rd floor, beside the bridge across People Park and Chinatown Point, next to the UOB ATM.
The taste is authentic.
The curry chicken somehow looks "overnight" but a bite tells otherwise.
The sides are very surprisingly mild to the palate, not too spicy, just right.
Sweet is the word.
For $5.70 it is slightly pricey, but that's what we pay in town.
My fave store in this whole Food Court!
Not only is the food amazing, the options are huge, portions are huge and the service is pretty great.
I love the Aunties here - they are so sweet, homely and remind me of my own Grandmother - who always loves stuffing me with food like a goose.
Not only are there local Malay food - but they sell desserts too - from traditional Indonesian to Western tarts, pies and curry puffs - they really have quite the edge.
What I Love: Getting rice and all the yummy veggies and meat.

Ayam Masak Merah is so good, with Sambal Goreng, Lemak curry, and you can get add Paru, Sotong Sambal, or Ketchup Fish, eggs, bean sprouts, beans, tempeh, etc., and the list just goes on and on and on......
I've tried almost all their options - and it's just all so good.
Not particularly healthy - but just oh so good.
Have tried their Mee Siam, Mee Rebus and Lontong too.
Yummmmmm!
For a time, they had Tahu Goreng and I ate that EVERY DAY.
And they stopped doing it and I literally was crushed.
Oh well.
I decided to bury my sorrows by stuffing myself with sambal goreng - and the world is all right again!
What I Don't Love: Nothing!!!!
This place is poppin' at lunch time.
We went a little bit late so were able to grab seats without waiting.
The food is delicious and won't break the bank.
We both had Chinese tea which was ok. For food, we ordered: -Wasabi prawns.
This came in an edible basket.
The prawns weren't that spicy.
-Coffee pork ribs.
Yes, coffee.
It may some weird but it's really good.
It doesn't taste too strongly of coffee, just a nice of hint of coffee that gives these crispy pork ribs good flavor.
-Yang chow fried rice: can't go wrong with fried rice.
They did not skimp on the char siew or prawns either.
-Sambal kang kong: not too spicy either.
Amazing!
Overall, a great place for Chinese food!
This place, tucked away in the upper tower floors of the vast west coast mall was a bit of pleasant surprise.
The chicken was moist, juicy, and cooked wonderfully.
Oddly enough, for a place with good food and lots of guests, there was only one person working the dining room.
I'd give the one-man-show running the place 20 stars for how courteous he was, his effort, and proficiency in making the place work.
It was quite remarkable to see him doing such an excellent job and working so hard to make things happen.
If he's not the owner, I hope he goes off and opens his own place instead of working here.
Meanwhile, I suggest to the owners that you hire more people like this and make things run better.
You already have tasty chicken, so make it a go-to place for guests by offering the service that bring people in and keep them satisfied.
Why have only one staff member when you could fill an entire dining room with happy customers, instead of having many people see no one is available and choosing to go somewhere else?
Like a vege loaded meal served within minutes?
Paik's Bibim is your lunch choice then!
It is a Korean style fast food - order at the counter, wait for your number to ding and come pick it up.
The dishes are inspired by the Korean staple Bibimbap.
You can get it with rice or noodle and your choice of meat, or tofu for even more vege!
Their service is fast and efficient while still friendly.
Need sometime to check out their menu, no prob, take your time.
The price is reasonable at $6.90 - $8.90 for a bowl of satisfying size.
The only downside is finding a place to sit.
It is very popular with the lunch crowd but have limited seatings.
No worries, get a to-go!
They pack your rice/noodle separate from the veggies so you don't have to worry about your veggies getting too soggy.
Oh, the meal also come with a bowl of soup.
It may be pricier than the North Spine Canteen but for the fresh veggies, I think it is worth it!
Ok that was damn tasty.

On a Chinatown side street across from a hawker center and a parking ramp with Singapore's "Eat Street" on the other side, this place stands a good chance of being passed over but it had a lot to like.
Live seafood tanks, late hours, cold beer and some tables outside under shade and fans.
The couple that own it are very pleasant, eager to have your business, and the food is great.
The spicy Sichuan pepper and chili oil beef had my mouth numb at first bite.
Actually felt kind of lame eating it since I am not accustomed to Singapore's heat and humidity and I was dripping sweat trying to get through the dish.
Kind of a sadomasochistic eating outing for me but what pleasure from the pain.
I would have no reservations coming back.
Expensive popsicles by the Bay.
4 star for taste, 2 star for price.
read about Frostbite one day so decided to bring the missus and mom in law to try it out.
The taste is wholesome, just like any of the artisan homemade ice-cream stores popping up across Singapore but the Popsicle version.
the good thing is that it is made with real fruits and has no gelatin or artificial flavoring and preservatives.
They even have Mao Shan Wang durian Popsicle for the Singapore durian fanatics.
they also do deliveries for min 20 sticks, great for parties.
its location is fantastic, facing the Merlion directly, and naturally it is priced fantastically expensive too.
sadly with the exorbitant rent of "fantastic locations", I hope it will be able to survive long enough to be more than a fad.
Delicious fresh ice block ready to cool you down and rehydrate after wandering around in the Singapore humidity!!
They sell for $5 a pop, which is on the pricer side but worth it for the refreshment.
I got the Watermelon and my friend got the Orange and Pineapple.
This foodstall is located at the Anchorpoint Foodcourt on Basement 1 at the far right end of the mall.
Don't be confused by the name Osaka Cuisine, because this place has nothing to do with Osaka which together with Kyoto has 97 michelin stars, and it also has nothing do with Cuisine.
It's just a Korean foodstall at the anchorpoint foodcourt.
Food is not bad.
The bibimbap has a good amount of flavor and balanced portion of meat, veggies and rice.
It is one of the most popular stall in the foodcourt, also because the prices are reasonable.
It's hard not to fall in love with Ng Kim Lee.
It is increasingly rare to find a 'traditional' bakery like this outside the heartlands.
Well, I guess it isn't all that traditional.
They do still sell the old school biscuits and little snacks, as well as some of the classic cakes, but what they're most famous for are their custard and durian puffs.
When you buy them you'll have to buy a few at a go.
I know I can't leave with any less than ten.
The moment you get it you're just tempted into popping it straight into your mouth.
the skin is nice and thin and isn't too fluffy, and envelopes a wonderfully casual and sweet (but not too sweet!)
bundle of custard.
I bought a box of six ($2.40) for my friends to try and they were so convinced they got a few each themselves.
I can't quite describe their durian puffs so well because I'm oddly averse to durians, but both of them sell out like hotcakes, so you know they're worth it!
They also do really good muffins of various flavours - lemon, blueberry, chocolate, and as you would expect form a fresh bakery they manage to get the density and texture all spot on.
I enjoy their cakes as well - they come in so many players and aren't very expensive, so I try a new one every time and it never disappoints!
Like Italian ice but 10 times better!
Try the durian or coconut!
If you have watched the Mediacorp Channel U reality tv game show "Buzzing Cashiers" (), you'll most likely recognise the owners of Bee Garden.
From what I understand, they were the winners of one of the season of the show.
This stall is not new at the Commonwealth Crescent Market.
They were around even when the stall was still at the old market, prior to its upgrading.
The family business has gone through quite a tough patch but the mother and son team can be cranky but they do make fantastic dessert!
Their best selling dessert is the ice mango pomelo dessert!
The pomelo is fresh and each one burst its juice with every bite.
The mango too is sweet and a perfect contrast with the slightly sour bites of pomelo.
The durian penyet is also worth trying but better eaten on the spot as the shaved ice are smooth and soft and wouldn't survive well with travelling or refreezing.
Personal favourite is the ice bo bo char char which uses melted gula melaka dressing on the ice shaving.
The dessert of yam and sweet potato is usually eaten hot but I love this cold and theirs is one of the best.
The hot desserts are under $1, definitely cheap and value for money too.
But unfortunately they only open in the afternoon so remember not to go too early.
I'm not familiar with this chain although their menu says they are a famous noodle shop in Osaka with over 200 stores.
They are very proud of their Udon and Soba noodles.
They charge quite a premium for the soba noodles.
I didn't think it was anything great.
The food here is average, the service is sub-par.
I get the sense that the employees here are not very happy and it makes you feel uncomfortable as a patron.
Inspired by the "Cook a pot of curry" day, I decided to have curry for dinner last Sunday.
But I had a craving for Jap curry, which is not so in line with the theme I suppose, but it is still curry, no?
Heh.
I thought hard about places with good Jap curry in Singapore, but my mind drew a blank.
Scoured the net for good recommendations, but that did not yield substantial results.
My sporadic love for Jap curry started after a long tiring day at Tokyo Disneysea about 2 years back, when Ter and I were on our way back to our hotel for the night.
Those who have been to Disneysea, or Disneyland will know that running around the place to catch the best rides is like some sort of physically demanding amazing race.
Coupled with the exorbitantly priced F&B inside, it is suffice to say that we were both damn hungry and spent at the end of the excursion.
So at a particular JR station where we changed trains, we popped into one of those eat-by-the-counter eatery, where you purchase food coupons via a vending machine, in exchange for the food.
So as you might have already guessed, it was a curry shop, and when the order came, we scarfed down the curry rice like we had been starved for a long time.
And that is when I started to appreciate Jap curry.
Something about the mix of sweet, spicy and savory that drew me in.
Especially love the red pickled veg that comes with it (think it's called fukujinzuke)!
Funnily enough, the other yummy Jap curries I've had was in LA, at Hurry Curry, Sawtelle.
So I find it odd that I can't find any good recommended Jap curry in SG.
One name stood out though, from all the scouring on the web, and it was Go!
Go!
Curry!
Located at the ION Orchard food basement, I vaguely remember seeing it, when its name appeared in the searches.
All the reviews seemed favourable, so headed there for a nice Jap curry dinner.
We settled for the Grand Slam because we could nt decide which katsu to get, and the grand slam had a bit of everything.
We even added shrimp because there was only 1 miserly shrimp in the Grand Slam.

When our order came, we sized up the situation pretty quickly (this would be called appreciation of situation in my line of work) and opined that we needed more curry, so we topped up $3 for additional curry.
Between the chicken katsu and the pork katsu, I preferred the chicken; thought that the pork was a bit tough, but maybe I have just been spoilt by Tonkichi or Tetsu, lol.
Other than that, the curry was creamy and tasty!
Not too spicy, and was a seamless blend of sweet and savoury.
My only gripe was that there wasn't any of the red pickled vege that I so love.
Alas!
I would have loved to finish the entire container of it, like what we did in Tokyo.
Then again, who does that right?
:p Go!
Go!
Hurry!
is ideal for a satisfying Jap curry meal that is also value for money.
Worth a try if you are into Jap curry.
Oh, and they also have various serving sizes (with inventive names) for the rice, ranging from economy class to first class.
So for those folks who are carbo loading, or love to eat rice, it's first class for the win; else economy class should do the trick!
So go, go, go to Go!
Go!
Curry!
Looking for a convenient place to have a quick dinner on a crowded Saturday night and stumbled on this new - to me at least - eatery in the basement of Paragon.
The speciality is gyu katsu, which comes on a little sizzling hotplate for you to tweak the doneness of the steak to your liking.
The service is fairly prompt because of the automated ordering system and the food comes quickly.
They have a very nice sparkling sake on the menu and the food is decent.
Good mid-priced place to grab a quick meal.
I'm posting it on behalf of KFC delivery, idk which outlet they sent my food from but since I stay nearby Thomson plaza so I'm guessing it's the one at there.
Anyway, as usual I have never had high expectation on any fast food joint, let alone KFC, although it's much better than McD.
So my craving for fried chicken came out of nowhere when I was home and decided to try KFC's delivery service.
Ordered chicken nuggets, original rice bucket and popcorn chicken.
For a fast food chain, seems like they're doing their job in an above average manner.
I'm very impressed about several things: 1.

They separate their mushroom sauce for the rice bucket to prevent it being soggy on the way so when it finally reached home, I was like MAN they know about all these basic things and 4 thumbs up for this.
Also, seems like they gave more chickens for take-away.
The rice to chicken ratio is perfect too!
Actual delivery time is actually much faster than estimated time (like 15 mins faster and hell yea it matters to a starving woman).
I ordered chicken nuggets for the first time from KFC and they taste DOPE!
Like really!
So fresh, tasted like real minced chicken breasts and free chipotle bbq dipping sauce!
I must say $3.5 delivery cost is totally worth it!
Although they do have $12 amount as minimum order charge which is understandable.
They also have weekdays promo, and I opted for the $6 for 2 portions of popcorn chicken which is only valid on mondays!
Really made my day!
- This is NOT your organic grass fed non-gmo no-hormone something something restaurant.
You're gonna come here cause you wanna eat really tasty food that's pretty difficult to find.
It's likely not the healthiest meal.
- Traditional Teo Chiew style food - small side dishes and a watery staple (soup noodle).
Generally very difficult meal to find in Malaysia, this is 1/2 places I know in Johor Bahru.
- My childhood dish, 9/10 for taste and convenience - Opened for 18 hours a day.
So good for family meals and for post party eating.
It's likely you would need to know Mandarin, or just point out the parts you want.
- How to order: 1.
Get here.
Head to the chef at the front.
Point out the meat parts that you want.
Small, large intestines, stomach,  tongue, normal meat parts, eggs, vegetables to make yourself feel better.
They'll chop up the meat and heat it up too.
Start with one bowl of noodle.
You can order more like rice.
Take a sit.
Eat when food comes, it takes time to heat it up.
Get full.
Enjoy.
Pay bill.
(I paid RM29 for 3 people)
This is a old style cake shop located at the HDB housing estate.
This cake shop was around since the 80s and so had a long history.
Having stand the test of time, it being still in business means they are making the stuff correct.
The variety of breads and buns are plentiful, you can get both savory and sweet buns.
Savoury ones includes the Singapore laksa bun, otak bun as well as the usual sausage roll, chicken mushroom bun and egg ham bun.
Sweet varieties included Apple chestnut, cheese blueberry plus other assorted fruits buns.
Not all types are available each day.
The buns are nice and they are cheaper than the newer bakery around .
You can also get various cakes.
First, NO :( Please do not replace all the Starbucks in Singapore with Tai Cheong Bakery as suggested by another yelper.
I love my Tai Cheong egg tarts but I can't forsake my love for Starbucks too.
Tai Cheong Bakery is the down to earth, simple practical guy one would not go wrong.
Starbucks is the romantic charming guy who just draws one in.
I have written reviews on Tai Cheong bakery in Hong Kong.
I love egg tarts, not from anywhere else but just from Tong Heng in Singapore and Tai Cheong in Hong Kong.
Tai Cheong Bakery has finally made its appearance in this sunny island since last year.
I heard there were long lines where it first opened.
I do not stand in crazy lines for food or anything.
Reminded me once upon a time when patrons had to stand in long lines to enter the most popular clubs.
I guessed I was lucky no one made me stand in lines; my legs would give way by standing for too long!!
:O Not sure if it is psychological, the Tai Cheong egg tarts I bought in Sg were very good but I somehow thought they were slightly different from those I bought in Hong Kong.
Perhaps the next time I would try to eat it on the spot once I bought them.
Minimum purchase of the egg tarts is 4 pieces.
It is $7.20 for a box of 4.
The tarts are baked at the premise, so they are fresh!
So fresh that the staffs would make everyone who placed an order and paid to stand around and wait for the tarts to cool down a bit.
That added to the increasing number of waiting patrons standing around.
I definitely do not mind trying other pastries at Tai Cheong.
So glad I can finally get Tai Cheong egg tarts here.
Now I just need to trek my way to Chinatown to get my hands on some Tong Heng egg tarts :D These two egg tarts have different crusts but both equally amazing!
Once upon a time, thwarted by a devilishly long queue at Toast Box, a girl named Fats despaired and slinked over to Imperial Treasure Bakery to sniff dismissively at the goods on display.

At first glance, they appeared common...the same old, same old Asian pastries With an air of beleaguered desperation and a long suffering sigh, she plucked a cheese and sausage pastry out of the display and settled up at the register.
And it was at the magical moment of exchange, when she first felt the bagged pastry in her hot little hand, that the spell of enchantment was spun!
Because the pastry was hot from the oven...and turned out to be extremely delicious!
(Even though sausage apparently means hot dog).
For just $1-2 a pop, Imperial Treasure bakes up some amazing breads and pastries!
My favorite, affectionately termed by my colleagues as a donut for carnivores, is the polo cha siu bun ($1.80).
The bun is soft, chewy and slightly sweet, like Hawaiian sweet potato bread.
Sugary pineapple streusel is baked into the top of the bun...and then...the piece de resistance...the bun is fulled with flavorful, fatty cha siu pork.
Oh yeah, that baby is a killer, a sweet decadent killer.
PARTING THOUGHT: I am looking forward to trying the other pastries...if I can tear myself away from the magnificent polo cha siu bun!
Went to Central Mall to look for a bakery to grab some breakfast to go.
Found Crystal Jade My Bread with all its cute panda logos and was excited to show my German bf what yummy Asian breads are like.
We settled on a baked pineapple bolo bun, baked Oreo mexican bun, steamed red bean paste bun, and baked chicken curry puff.
Honestly, I was only familiar with the first and third choices, but it was a good chance to try something new.
:) The breads were light and sweet, and the puff was flaky and oily.
Actually, all of it was pretty oily.
But it still made for a nice breakfast.
I've always been a fan of the Japanese food at Liang Court.
Tampopo Deli is no exception.
This is my favourite place in Singapore to buy Japanese comfort food: bento boxes, ramen, udon.
They have EVERYTHING!
I think that's the beauty of this place.
The food won't blow you away, but think high quality Japanese food court food.
So please temper your expectations!
I am a huge fan of the Tokyo Street Ramen for $11.50.
It's a simple ramen, but tastes exactly what I remember from my various trips to Tokyo.
The bentos boxes are solid, however, they are sitting out in the open and need to be heated.
I dock one star because it's likely not fresh, it is a deli after all.
Fortunately, the ramen and udon are made fresh, so no worries.
If you live or stay in the River Valley / Clarke Quay area and are craving Japanese comfort food, there is no place better than Tampopo Deli!
This KFC in Anchorpoint has a nice location in the mall, tucked away in the corner, so you can enjoy your chicken here in peace.
There are always plenty of places to sit around, It's clean and the couches are comfortable.
The staff is friendly and the store looks clean in general.
However since I saw Food Inc, I don't want to eat chicken anymore from fast food chains.
Filled with hormones since birth, these chickens are never able to stand on their feet just to grow the meet as fast as possible.
The image of a guy filtering out the dead chicken from the other almost dead ones is still baked on my retinas.
Anyway this KFC is open daily daily : 11:00am to 10:00pm
WAFFLE ICE CREAM!
Who can resist good waffle ice cream??
I certainly cannot!!!
I didnt come here for dinner but only for dessert thus I can only comment about the 2 sets of awesome waffle ice cream I had here.
Besides the lychee martini and really didnt taste anything like lychee martini (more like lychee only), the rest of the ice cream flavours hat we had were GREAT!
LOVE LOVE LOVE the rum and raisin.
A little out of the way for those who dont drive cos its a slight trudge from the nearest Kovan mrt.
Parking is also challenging cos the options of parking at the private estate is not as convenient as parking near to the shop but lots are really limited.
In any case, I LOVE THE ICE CREAM here!
Nice environment (indoor or outdoor) for good food.
Great hangout for large group and family as well.
Best of all no service charge!
Although I'm not a big fan of chocolate, Chocolate Origin's chocolate cake has won me over.
In my opinion, they beat Awfully Chocolate easily as having the best chocolate cake in town.
Its made true to its name, thick with rich chocolate, and glazed to absolute perfection.
Its moist and velvety, and will keep for days if sealed well in a container and put in the fridge - so you can space out that indulgence, with the comfort of knowing that it will taste just as good.
Also love how you can make an order for the cake online on their website with just a few easy steps - and they even provide a tag for you to write your own msg on and stick on the cake!
Very cute :)
If you like Lava Cake with a scoop of ice cream on the side, then this Cuppa is for you!
It's as the name suggests = hot lava cake with molten centre + cold ice cream at the bottom.
Awesomeness in a cup!
This stall has been around for as long as I can remember.
I need to have a bowl if I happen to be around the Malay Village.

Nowadays, other toppings like kidney beans, grass jelly cubes, creamed corn and even durian paste and vanilla ice cream have found their way into this dessert, but I still feel chendol tastes best at its simplest.
Just coconut milk, shaved ice, gula melaka, light green chendol and a dash of salt will cut it for me.
It's made fresh each day and tastes so much better than the factory-made ones.
And yes, no red beans in their chendol!
The stall also sells chendol in cups if you are in a hurry and want to enjoy yours on the go.
I'm really such a fan of Ah Balling's peanut soup.
I like the fact that the peanuts are extremely soft and thoroughly cooked, and in addition the soup is smells really good and is delicious.
I can drink tons of it and not feel full or bad about my body's sugar level.
As for the glutinous rice balls, they have Black Sesame, Peanut, Red Bean, Yam Paste and Green Tea.
To be honest, I have tasted glutinous rice balls that are equally tasty and those can be bought in local wet markets or supermarkets too.
So far I've tried a few flavours but I think I will stick to the peanut flavor.
The sesame flavor comes a close second.
They also have branches in Chinatown, Nex, Golden Mile so far my experience is that their standard for the peanut soup is all very consistent, so feel free to visit any of the branches!
Would be a lot better if they sticked with the clear ginger soup.
Otherwise a strong fan but looks like going down hill.
I remember a time where almost every 5 star hotel has a nice old school hotel bar.
These days, most of them just have soulless coffee lounges.
Other than the Long Bar at Raffles Hotel, there isnt many like that left.
Fortunately, Victoria Bar at the InterContinental is still around.
The bar is cosy and quiet, with sofas and arm chair sitting as well.
Even though they have a large screen tv that shows sports, the volume is kept minimal.
Drinks selection is also very extensive with over 30 beers, wines and whiskies.
The bar also makes very good cocktails.
So all in all, you'll be spoilt for choice of tipper.
A perfect hideaway from the vibrant bustle of Bugis Junction to chill and relax.
A+ fun!
Great way to entertain kids and adults alike!

Even walking around the restaurant is fun as you see people unleash their inner artists to create pancakes in shapes from mini pancakes to teddy bears to hello kitty to crabs and stars and much more... Each tube of batter $8.50 goes a long way... with two adults, we ordered two and a main course and wound up with the smaller half of both bottles left... Best to bring more people to maximize your "art supplies"...ermh...I mean ingredients :) We got about six toppings from bacon to scallions to chocolate chips and bananas and we used just about all of it.
On a comparative basis, the main course, country fried steak and eggs was rather disappointing.
First, it was chicken, not steak (yes, Oklahoma, they butchered your state dish), and there were about two teaspoons of thin and rather flavorless gravy.
If this is anything to go by, best to stick to the pancakes.
PARTING THOUGHT: next time, we may get a chocolate batter to outline our beautiful pancake creations... Buttermilk and peanut butter, while tasty, were just too close in color...
I would recommend this place to someone who has time, is creative (because circular pancakes are boring) and doesn't mind paying a bit of money.
The pancakes are good, the service is alright.
This particular one is right outside USS, so it's great for a late breakfast before entering the park.
Whenever I'm in the vicinity I craved to have a meal here whether it's for lunch or dinner or to takeaway.
Good options of rice, roti, naan, and dishes but I always go for their Briyani rice with Tandoori chicken and Assam soup.
Sometime with  hot masala tea.
All very well cooked and delicious.
A good meal in a nice comfortable and clean setting :-)
The menu has limited choices for chicken delights despite the name of their shop.
Their fried chicken cutlet taste like what you could get at KFC outlets.
Yet their pricing easily doubles.
Other dishes are sub par.
Overall, it was quite a let down.
Do note: I am not expecting restaurant standard food, just a decent meal for what I am paying.
There is always a long queue and my friend wondered what the hype was about.
The menu is quite extensive so it can be tricky to choose what to eat.
I had the glass noodles with braised pork.
The portion did not seem big at first but turned out to be satisfying.
I was surprised by how much I like the pork slices.
It was flavourful with the right amount of fat and taste.
The waiters did not serve water and we thought maybe it's an additional charge until we checked.
Haha.
I'm surprised to find a local ice cream store near my place.
My aunt was the one who told me about it and that it was always packed at night.
I like that the staff/owners are polite and patient with older customers, especially when they prefer to speak in dialect or mandarin.
It has a more casual homely vibe here where "everyone is a friend" compared to those in the city area.
While the decor is a bit hipster-ish, it does not give the sense of trying too hard.
Water from a spigot (near the middle of the room), anyone?
As with many homegrown ice cream places where they concoct many different flavors, Lickers is no different.
Besides ice cream and waffles, it also sells flavored soda water and light finger food snacks.
Somehow I like their version of a yuzu sorbet and Yakult Oreo.
They are light and refreshing.
Not too sweet or sour.
Pretty perfect for the hot weather.
A scoop of ice cream starts from $3.50 which is a decent price for the neighborhood.
This is a small gelato stand near the food court.
The gelato is tasty and very similar to regular ice cream.
However, they have a ton of interesting flavors, such as Ferrero Rocher and Snickers, in addition to traditional ice cream and fruit flavors.
The dark chocolate Ferrero Rocher was very dense and decadent, bursting with chocolate flavor.
Meanwhile, the Snickers was a little softer with subtle hints of caramel and peanut.
The prices are a little higher than a typical ice cream shop, but not outrageous.
Overall, it is a good place to stop by for a dessert snack, especially if you are interested in the unique flavors they offer.
This cake shop serves sugared bread in different forms, from pie-shaped to large crossaint-like pieces.

The types that are encrusted with cheese are my favourite: you can crunch through the upper skin of the bread and smell the aroma of the cheese as you chew off the bread (which is fresh and of decent quality).
These tend to get snapped up before 10.30am, so do take note.
Other than sugared bread, the shop sells a variety of bread snacks similar to those found in Bread Talk, as well as entire cakes with themes suited for children.
Every neighbourhood NEEDS to have at least one bakery.
Thankfully, Serangoon North homes a rather good one.
Plenty of childhood nibbles such as iced gems and wheel snacks are available here.
One of the best things about this bakery though is the waffle pancake!
Soft, fluffy and moderately filled, these waffle pancakes are extremely popular among residents here.
My favourite filling has got to be the rich kaya and butter combination.
The doughnuts there are also pretty soft, but run out really quickly especially when it comes to the rainbow sprinkled ones.
Another highlight about this bakery is of course, its colourfully decorated cakes!
Fruit and chocolate cakes are their main specialties.
This is ideal for last-minute birthday surprises or when you don't have the time to order a cake from more major bakeries.

Also, remember to get your hands on their thick Blueberry cheese tarts (2 for $2) as well as Rum Ball ($0.80) and Cutey Mouse ($0.90), which are three of the most delicious pastries there in my opinion.
YUM.
I have been craving a good burger since arriving in Asia.
This was SO juicy and delicious, I've already been back twice.
Besides the burger, I've had the mozzarella sticks.
They were served with some salsa type dressing which did not do them justice.
I asked for a side of marinara (which they brought) and then they were perfect.
While this review is based solely on the burger, I will say food at other tables looked great and people seemed to be cleaning their plates.
Also, the service is very friendly and accommodating.
Can't wait for my next visit!

Bought a box of the new Thé Noir tea infused chocolate cookies ($14 for a box of 10) for my friend who was meeting me for lunch at Japan Food Town and also a box of ironai cheese cookies/langue de chat au fromage ($12 for a box of 9) for my sister.
The staff was friendly.
I guess the pricing of the product is reasonable.
LeTAO is supposedly famous for their cheesecake, specifically the Double Fromage made with imported Italian mascarpone cheese.
Since they do not sell by slices, it would be too much for me to buy the whole cake and share with my mom.
So I have to pass.
Hopefully someone I know will get to try and let me know how it is.
LeTAO at Ion Orchard is the flagship store in Singapore.
The stand alone counter is located at B1 right outside Lululemon or Coffee Bean & Tea Leaf.
A very popular bakery when it first opened at Raffles Place with super long queues for their bakery items.
People used to buy their buns by the tens when they first started.
But the fad has died down a bit, although you can still expect some queues to form especially during meal times.
This branch is located in the middle of level 3 with a few other smaller bakery stalls, which is the same floor as NTUC Fairprice Xtra & Sushi Tei.
Once items are sold out, you can expect to wait up to 1.5hrs for the next batch of buns to be ready.
Favourite items are: - raisin cream bun - mashed potato bun - liu sa bun
Baker Talent is a new bakery recently opened at Serangoon Central that boasts a long queue each time I pass by it.
I couldn't figure out what was so great about bread/buns so I decided to give it a go one evening.
The queue, although undeniably long, moved quickly.
I chose the Cranberry & Cheese, Bo Luo Bun and Butter Boom.
They were having an opening promotion, selling the buns at unbelievably low prices - 90 cents for the Cranberry & Cheese, 60 cents for Butter Boom, 80 cents for Bo Luo Bun.
I was really impressed with the Cranberry & Cheese bun.
It was so soft, full of cheesy goodness and light at the same time.
I'm not sure how that works.
The Butter Boom and the Bo Luo Bun were rather mediocre though.
The best bit about Baker Talent is that they serve their buns warm, which is quite a rare find these days.
OMG!
Step aside Breadtalk and Four Leaves or any of the major chain bakeries on our island.
Baker Talent has seriously awesome buns.
I first chanced upon it a few weeks ago when I got off at the wrong bus stop.
I was curious about it as there was a standee proclaiming $0.90 for the golden sand bun.
Now...golden sand did not sound very appealing to me as it did not tell me what was in it, and I was not about to go to the bakery and inquire.
Fast forward a few days, a friend posted a picture of the golden sand on FB and it looked absolutely delicious.
Golden sand = salted egg yolk custard aka liu sha bao.
Now I just had to make my way to Baker Talent to try it.
I finally made it this morning and bought the Golden Sand bun and the original custard bun.
The Golden Sand bun is really to die for, especially if you are a big fan of salted egg yolk.
The bun was not that warm when I bought it.
It was still pillow soft and encased a generous amount of the salted egg yolk which could dribble out if you are not careful.
The salty sweet was just amazing.
For that I would rate it 5 stars, and the clincher was it only cost $0.90.
In fact, all buns I saw was under a dollar.
The lowest price was $0.60 for the butter boom (I presume it to be butter bun).
The original custard bun ($0.80) was equally good but paled to the Golden Sand.
Creamy custard inside the soft bun.
A bit of caramelized crust in the center gave it a bit of oomph.
I tasted some tartness and I could not make out where that came from.
No, the custard had not gone bad or turned sour.
It was like lemon juice dotted in a few spots.
I would definitely return to try the other buns.
And the cost of 2 buns here is less or equal to a bun in Breadtalk.
A very good deal for breakfast or snack indeed.
NOTE: It is a corner shop just behind the bus stop.

My go-to place for various purposes: afternoon snack (plenty of kueh to choose from and the latest addition is mao shan wang durian ambon), western cakes (rich mango cake and rarer option of pandan cream cake) and gifts (pineapple tarts and almond cookies in fancy tins).
The pandan non-cream cake has just the right amount of flavour and texture.
If you have not tried this bakery yet, you should give it a shot at one of its several outlets across Singapore!

While strolling around the Japanese Food street (Shoktsu Ten) in Jurong Point, came across this bakery and there were quite a number of people coming in and out of this place that made me want to try.
The display cases had quite a number of dessert ranging from cakes to mochis to tarts.
What caught me the most was the mochi with the macaron on top of it and it was the only one left so I decided to get it.
I also purchased green pumpkin bun (signature bake goods), chocolate bun and takoyaki bread.
The mochi was flavorful and the chewiness of the mochi was perfect when accompanied by the crunchiness of the top shell macaroon that was accompanied.
There were a layer of cream in between too.
I was glad that I managed to get two of my favorites together.
The takoyaki bread tasted like takoyaki.
The bread was fresh and the ingredients they used made it taste as if I'm getting an appetizer instead.
This bakery uses quality flour that is imported from Japan but the prices of the bread was on the affordable range.
For the green pumpkin bun, when you bite into it, you can taste the green tea and after awhile you could taste the homemade puréed pumpkin.
Bread was soft and the taste lingers in my mouth for a bit after taking a bite.
Will definitely come back for more desserts or baked goods.
Make sure to drop by here if you are in Jurong Point.
Ming Jia is another family korean restaurant and one of my regular hunts for affordable korean food.
Situated in Bukit Timah Plaza, the restaurant itself is nothing fancy, with just the bare minimum furnishings and paper signs as their menus.
The food on the other hand, is truly an authentic korean fare.
One of my favourite dishes is the beef bulgogi rice set.
Unlike usual korean food stores that serve this on a hot plate, Ming Jia offers it as a stew in a bowl that is usually used to serve kimchi stew.
The pieces of beef are left simmering in the stew, adding flavour to the thick broth.
The beef is tender and a tad salty, but this is cancelled out once you eat it with the rice.
Another dish is the kimchi pancake.
Packed full of vegetables and chilli, the pancake is crisp on the outer ends and soft and chewy towards to centre.
A special soy sauce is served together.
The unique taste, somewhat like a cross between miso and soy sauce, brings out the kimchi flavour in the pancake.
Don't underestimate the portion size because it is extremely filling.
The good thing is you can request for a take-away box if you can't finish the dish.
This is just the weirdest thing.
After ordering I felt something was up.
It didn't look promising.
Indeed, there are TWO Korean restaurants with the same name on the same floor.
I'd happened to walk past this one first.
Ming Jia Korean Food is at B1-07/19 and is run by 3 Chinese ladies.
It's like a hole-in-the-wall but without the amazing food to justify the spartan look.
No Korean people eating there on a Sunday afternoon.
One side dish.
Ming Jia 2 Korean BBQ is at B1-55.
It's run by Koreans and is a restaurant.
Lots of Koreans inside.
Seafood tofu soup ($9) - 1 star The soup itself was unremarkable.
Not many ingredients - a couple of prawns and squid.
But the deal breaker was the rice.
I've never commented on white rice before.
The rice was slightly undercooked and hard and tasted like cardboard.
Where's that fluffy fragrant rice that make us proud of being Asian?
I've had better cheaper Korean food at Kopitiam.
Garrett's prides itself with selling gourmet popcorn.
And it's definitely a store that can't be missed for everything you walk past it, you will get a whiff of the sweet scent of caramel drifting out of its store.

I always wonder how the employees can tolerate working in there all day as I'm sure eventually the scent of the caramel will stick to them eventually and make them feel a bit sick... well.. back to reviewing this place..
I love sweet things.. so it's only natural I ordered their sweet caramel .. but I also like cheese so I got a mixture with their cheese popcorn as well.
The verdict was... the popcorn is definitely tastier than GV, Cathay and Shaw's combined.
Every bit of the popcorn was slathered with caramel.. making sure you know that what you paid for is what you get.
The cheese popcorn though.. some I could barely taste the cheese, some the cheese taste was so strong.. it made me giddy with glee.
However, the bad thing is... as this is popcorn... at some point, you'll feel a bit sick of eating it.

So I guess it's alright to go down to Garrett's once in a blue to moon purchase some of their awesome popcorn... but after eating it.. you'll be put off from it until the next blue moon where you crave for it again...
I forgot how much I do like the popcorn from Garrett.
You will definitely smell the sweetness of the caramelized popcorn when walking past it.
There is no long queue here now that Garrett popcorn has several locations all over Singapore.
For those who cannot make up their mind, the Chicago Mix is a good option to have both sweet and salty popcorn Caramelized and cheese corn are just so good that I want to lick my fingers.
They also do samples so you can request to try the various flavors before buying.
I find the caramelized (in all variations - nuts and plain) very sweet after a while so it may be best to share that with others.
The small size is a good portion to share as a small snack unless you love popcorn and can finish it in one sitting, you will be better off getting the medium or large bag.
I do love the tins but the prices do not justify them I feel.
Over $15 for a quart tin of popcorn?
I think not.
Spoilt for choice here!
Even after zooming-in exclusively to the 'thumbs up' options, I still had so much to consider.
It did seem evident, though, that they were to be known for their mango desserts, and no wonder.
I picked the Coco Mango Mini Mochi with Vanilla/Green Tea Ice Cream ($6.90).
I picked green tea, which seems a little odd but I thought that if they'd give that as an option, it can't be that bad.
True enough, it worked a treat!
The mini mochis were very chewy and starchy (as some would like it), but a bit too much for my liking.
They were also very generous with the number of mini mochis in the bowl, such that I ended up leaving some behind.
The best part of it was the mango cubs which were well sweet and very apparently fresh, leaving me wanting for so much more of that.
All in all a good dessert, chiefly won over by the mango.
My friend ordered the Mango Pomelo Sago, and while not being overly expressive about the dish, absolutely lauded the mango in hers as well.
I think one of the foundations of a good dessert shop is the freshness of its ingredients, and Honeymoon Dessert has certainly nailed that.
I look forward to exploring the rest of the menu!
Set in the same building as The Club boutique hotel, is pretty identifiable, with its clean and classic looking décor.
My friends and I were there late one night and it was the one of the few stalls with desserts and cakes that stayed open past 10pm.
Unfortunately for us, the cake selection available at that time of the night was pretty dismal.
I'm assuming most of their better cakes have been sold out during the day.
I got a Passion fruit cheesecake and a nutty chocolate, both of which were average at best for me.
The passion fruit cheesecake failed to show case the cheese, and it felt like I was eating a passion fruit cream pudding rather than a cheesecake.
The nutty chocolate was slightly better as I liked that the sponge cake was flavourful and light, but once again, the mousse failed to deliver the nuttiness and chocolaty richness I was looking for.
I have heard great things about their rainbow cake and will be returning for it some time soon.
As for the desserts in general, there are probably many other cafes around the area to get a good piece of cake.
I stayed at the Scarlet around the corner, and went looking for breakfast.
Not much open at 7 AM, came across this one.
Very simple place, clean, and tablecloths at 7 AM!
Don't see that often.
Basic menu, not a lot to choose.
That said, I had Eggs Benedict consecutive mornings-a little slow opening on Friday morning, had to encourage her by showing her a wad of cash.
(Strange how that always works) And, it was excellent!
Toasted English muffin, topped with perfectly done eggs, finished with spinach, salmon, and hollandaise.
Just perfectly prepared.
Can't beat that, who would have known.
With a beverage, it came to $20 Singapore dollars.
A small unpretentious little corner store at the void deck of Ang Mo Kio Ave 10, this is the place to go for a simple, budget meal of local delights and desserts.
What's charming about this place is that you see a few middle aged aunties serving you not just traditional kuehs like soon kuehs, chee cheong funs, etc.
There are other staple like the kaya toast with half boiled eggs, modernized thick toasts from the butter sugar ones to the chocolate, peanut butter or strawberry types.
The range of desserts also go from almond, sesame seed paste to the red bean soup, bean curd skin to the shaved ice options.
It's like a mish-mash of traditional vs contemporary in a very compact shop.
The deco is a little tacky with the posters of all the menu items plastered all over but I guess that the beauty of this type of neighbourhood shops.
The flow of customers is pretty regular with random seniors, youths and children streaming in and out.
I only ordered the bean curd skin with Gingko nuts and it's pretty alright.
Not too sweet and the serving is sufficient for me.
Will keep this place in mind when I head over for my next Doc's appt down the blk.
A quilt place hiding in the basement of busy United Square.
Good place for you to escape from the crowds of the mall.
This is a cute little restaurant in the JCube mall.
It is staffed by a few young people (perhaps owners?
), who were very polite and friendly.
The service was good.
The food was average for the most part.
I tried the spaghetti and meatballs.
The pasta was a bit tough and bland and the sauce lacked spices.
Yet, the meatballs had a nice, fresh flavor.
I also tried the macaroni and cheese.
It was rich and creamy in a homestyle baked format, but there were some dry and unsavory noodles on top.
The chili that came with the chili fries was the star of the show.
It had a good peppery spice to it and would be good for a bowl itself if they serve it that way.
Unfortunately, the prices are extremely high here, coming out to about $30 per person.
Although there is friendly service, the mediocre food does not come near to commanding such a price.
Famished after long hours of shopping with my colleague, we decided to go to JCube for dinner.
Pique Nique was the first eatery we saw when we reached the place, and our mind was set.
Yes.
We were THAT hungry.
Besides, the look of the café was inviting enough for us.
It was quite pretty.
The skies were already getting dark outside, and I loved that the place wasn't glared with bright lightings.
It was dim and just right.
Like in every restaurant or café, the first thing I check when I open the menus is the pricing...
Very pricey!
Nonetheless, we decided to just try the food.
We shared their Texan Fries since the staff was considerate enough to warn us that the portion will be large even for two people.
The fries were good.
Really good.
For desserts, I ordered the Ice Cream Profiterole.
Everything was nice except the ice-cream.
It wasn't sweet enough.
I've tasted countless of vanilla ice-cream, but this wasn't even creamy and sweet.
My colleague who ordered their French Toast drizzled with salted caramel sauce also commented that the sauce tasted purely caramel, not salty.
Not sure if this is one place I'd return to; even if the staffs are helpful and friendly.

As someone who's eaten at Ginza Bairin near this outlet of Monster Curry, and at Coco Ichibanya at Somerset, I'd have to say that taste-wise Monster Curry does slightly lose out to both chains, but however offers more competitive prices at a slight discrepancy in the flavours of the actual curry.

For example, I find that Ginza Bairin provides a more flavourful curry in which you can taste the different spices added in the curry, whereas at Monster Curry you really only taste a bit of chilli and its mostly salty.
I assume it'll be spicier if I pick something more than Level 1, though.

What attracts me to Monster Curry is the price, as its affordable, the prices range from $12 - $16 (If I am not wrong but its around this price range), and the soft drinks are $2 onwards, which I think is quite okay-priced especially since this is in the middle of Town.
Taste-wise it can definitely take a leaf out of the books of its competitors, but nonetheless the actual curry is still rather yummy and the service is efficient.

I visited the outlet at dinner time with a friend on a Monday, and between payment and being ushered to our table, it took no more than ten minutes before our food arrived, and I was reasonably happy with the efficiency.
The food portion is more or less okay.
I mean, its just enough for me, but I definitely can comfortably eat a dessert without feeling too full.
If you are someone who likes larger portions then you might want to consider Coco Ichibanya or Ginza Bairin which does offer a slightly larger portion, and size upgrade options.
This up and coming new establishment is showing growing signs,  very quickly growing signs that it desires to be the benchmark of what's good about Duxton hill.
Nestled away at a fabulous corner unit,  Life is Beautiful (LIB) is gaining traction very quickly amongst expats and locals alike,  all looking to enjoy themselves at a unique watering hole.
LIB serves up a dinner menu as well,  and whilst I have heard great things about quality of food,  I have not been able to savour their delectable treats yet.
Their manager is a close friend,  and he boasts aplenty of their famous butter milk fried chicken,  and if pictures are anything to go by I am sure it tastes heavenly.
I did however,  have the pleasure of ending up there on Saturday night for a few drinks with friends.

Once dinner time is over,  LIB bursts to life in the later part of the evenings where djs take centre stage,  and Singapore's finest talents,  sometimes guests from overseas,  control the dance floor with their signature sounds.
LIB is a great place to unwind,  let your hair down, have a drink or three,  hell maybe even five,  and dance your troubles away.
There's ample seating as well if you want to rest your weary legs.
They have themed nights with a wide variety of musical genres on offer depending on the day of the week.
Their impartial attitude towards music is very appealing to me as a DJ.

I give it 4 stars,  of course to be updated in future once I've given their food menu a try,  but their skilled bartenders and extensive selection of drinks,  along with the fantastic atmosphere and general feel of the place are worthy of a positive review.
Watch out Duxton Hill,  Life is indeed Beautiful.
We decided to patronize this place while we were shopping at Causeway Point.
The place has quite an interesting and inviting décor.
Our experience was also that the service was quite attentive.
We ordered the set meal, which came with the garlic bread, soup and drink.
We felt that the bread was just ok; it was very buttery but served at room temperature.
The soup tasted suspiciously like campbell's soup, but since I like campbell's soup, no complains here.
For my main dish, I had the pacific dory, which consisted of two large slabs of grilled dory with herbs.
The dish also came with quite a bit of spaghetti and some salad.
I found that the dory was quite nice.
My friend has the Steak N Prawn which was rather cheap at $12.90.
He found that the prawns were not that succulent, or perhaps even somewhat not fresh.
The steak was pretty average from what I heard from him.
Overall, this is a fairly decent place to have a meal at affordable prices.
The fact that it's a McDonald's makes liking the place in this day and age somewhat tawdry.
Emerging from a McDonald's is not unlike being caught slinking out of a peep show, especially for the foodie desperately trying establish street cred.

But honestly, people, snobbery aside, what's not to like about a large airy pavilion with outdoor seating that is well-ventilated and well-lit with the option of arctic air-conditioning if the weather gets hot and humid (as it sometimes gets in Singapore?!
), free wifi and access to food, drink and bathroom facilities?
Very little, I'm guessing, especially after a run, a romp in the park or in the middle of a busy day when a mini getaway is all you need.

In this, McDonanld's has been very shrewd, and while one may sneer at the quality of the food and drink or even haughtily inquire if it is even food and drink, one  cannot deny that this is a very well thought  out and strategically located outlet.
It just happens to be a  McDonad's.
I go through long periods when I don't go to Starbucks but now and then I return.
I'm most likely to go when I'm meeting someone and they want a sweet drink or we need a comfy couch chair to catchup over.

I always explain to friends (or face it anyone who will listen) that there are 3 reasons I come to starbucks: 1) It's got this warm casual laidback atmosphere and because they look pretty generic inside, for that moment (especially on a work day) you could be anywhere else in Singapore..or as my friend said Milan.
I mostly pretend I'm in a shopping centre far away from the office or..the Pike Place Market location which admittedly is tiny.
2) They do good soy.
3) They do good flavoured syrup drinks for when you want something more like dessert or need to topup your brain food.
They're pretty patient with my custom drinks requests here (usually things like reduce the syrup, short drinks, replace syrups with other flavours etc)!
Until the one time I ordered a non customised one, the barista making it actually checked with the cashier if he had heard right.
"Normal??"
Red Mango serves fresh frozen yogurt, located at a small corner of Esplanade Xchange, the small 'shopping mall' at Esplanade MRT Station.
Compared to many frozen yogurt shops out there, Red Mango do stand out in certain ways.
Although the variety of flavours aren't that many for you to choose, they have a decent range of toppings and add-ons for you to choose from.
Also, I like how they have a small seating area where customers can sit down and enjoy their cold dessert.
In a hot country like Singapore, dining in with a cold, frozen yogurt is refreshing and really enjoyable.
Red Mango originated from Korea, so expect their large TV in their shop to play some Kpop-related videos.
The last day for this outlet was 8 Dec 2017 before it converted to Yole the next day.
Although it was one of the last few outlets still offering llaollao, the queue was short.
Certain toppings such as melon already ran out.

Sanum (S$6.95) Frozen yogurt 3 choices of fruit - mango, strawberry, dragonfruit 2 choices of crunch - almond crocanti, Filipino white chocolate biscuit 1 choice of sauce - chococrock white sauce Smooth slightly sour frozen yogurt, topped with  the coconut white chocolate sauce, packed with juicy pieces of fruit and crunchy nutty crunchies.
You are sure to find something to suit your palate from their extensive variety available at Marble Slab Creamery.

Claiming to serve the 'freshest ice cream on earth', they sell a range of ice cream products like ice cream flavors, ice cream mix-in combinations, ice cream cakes, gourmet milk shakes, smoothies and ice cream floats, and even non fat yoghurt.
Craving something with a kick, I ordered a single scoop of Tiramisu.
The ice cream artist proceeded to mix my ice cream on a frozen marble slab, and then scooped it into a crispy waffle cone.
Marble Slab Creamery's rendition of this is with a hint of liquor, a touch of coffee and some chocolate.
The ice cream came in a creamy sticky texture but the liquor taste was almost close to none.
Prices for a single scoop start at $4.50 here which is pretty pricey.
But the service staff at I12 Katong were patient and accommodating, allowing customers to sample many of their flavors before deciding on their purchase.
When I have my yogurt, sometimes I opt to go old school with the plain white yogurt, topped with fresh fruits.
Truly a refreshing experience, perfect for the Singapore weather.
Yami yogurt offers a low-fat delight but is patronized by all.
So obviously, there's nothing to be guilty about this dessert.
As I grow mature, I am leaning towards yogurt rather than ice cream.
It does make me feel lighter and maybe healthier, without the bloated feeling that ice cream gives me.
And nowadays, yogurt has branched out to a variety of flavors which expanded its market.
But with Yami, I go old school plain and natural plus fresh fruits.
I'm not too sure but I'm not quite a big fan of their flavoured yogurts.
Maybe I haven't figured out the perfect blend.
I never thought I needed a technical mind when mixing toppings with flavoured yogurt.
Although I would enjoy that, I'd prefer not to think much about something that's going to enter my stomach.
If you want a variety on your yogurt experience, Yami would be a perfect place for you to start.
But sometimes, going old school is more than enough.
Sho Teppan is a brand new dining concept that surfaced in 2009.
What Sho Teppan attracts me is it allows customers to enjoy the thrill of cooking the meal themselves, just the way they like it.
Unique and creative.
Sho Teppan is the first to offer both Teppanyaki and Sukiyaki under one roof.
Ranging from Wagyu Beef, Premium Black Angus, Kurobuta Pork Loin are the selection of meats that you can choose to cook with.
And they are definitely spoilt for choice here.
My favourite choice is their wagyu beef shabu shabu.
Thinly sliced premium beef dip with their sesame shabu shabu sauce makes it ultra delicious.
However, the negative part is the portion is a bit too small for me.
If they were to offer buffet style, I would definitely be camping there every day.
Decent quality food here but not as good as true Yakitori because it doesn't have that charcoal taste that you'll get at real yakitori houses.
Still, it's pretty good if you're just craving chicken, beef or pork on a stick.
The basement at Causeway Point is such a food haven now.
After dinner at The Chicken Rice Shop, my friend and I felt like having a sinful dessert to end our meal.
Marble Slab Creamery is just next door, so it made things all the more convenient.
With so many flavours though, it was hard to decide.
(Okay, it's just the way many girls are.
If a guy likes something he sees in a shop, he buys it immediately.
When a girl goes out shopping, she has to consult ten friends before she parts with her money.
I'm guilty of this too.)
Sensing this, the friendly staff actually allowed us to sample some flavours.
We eventually went with the peach and lemon custard flavours and watched as the staff mixed the flavours with our chosen toppings on the marble slab.
The end result was both tart and creamy.
The service is not bad either.
As we headed to the shop's dining area to enjoy our ice-cream, the staff offered us water too.
Haagen Daz in Holland V has been around as long as I can remember.
It recently went through a renovation and is a lot more bright and spacious.
There is an outdoor and indoor seating, and you can eat in or take away.
Be aware though that eating in is about 20% more expensive than buying take away.
Haagen Daz ice cream is always really good and although a bit more pricey, its worth it.
The chocolate and cookies and cream are my favorite.
It can get a bit crowded here during weekend nights.
Worst service ever.
I've grown up in the states and Haagen Dazs first of all doesn't cost this much, and secondly the scoops are not this little.
The managers name is Katherine and had the worst attitude ever.
She had plenty of empty tables.
And we want to sit in the table that she claimed was for 7 people.
We are a group of 4, 2 moms and 2 daughters.
"No you can't sit here this table is for 7 people.
That's the rule."
Can I speak to ur manager?
"That's me in the manager and this is the rule.
You can sit over there at the corner or at the other corner for 4 people."
Well we don't want to sit in the table of 4 next to the bathroom or by the corner.
"No you can't because this table is for 7."
What time do you close?
It's 10:30pm right now.
"We close at 11:30pm and it's already a busy time right now" oh so that's why you have so many empty tables and  only give us the shitty tables?
The place isn't even nicely maintained.
And now you're gonna give attitude to a paying client, 2 elderly clients spending family time with their daughters?
My friend says no we want this table, why can't you give us this table when you're closing in an hour and we are only going to be eating ice cream for goodness sake!
Urg singapore service makes me so angry!
Please learn some customer service manners because rule number 1: the customer is always right.
This is situated along Changi Road.
Parking is easy to find.
I managed to find one right in front of the restaurant at 7 pm on a day before the weekend.
There is ample seating outside under a big white tent.
I sat and was promptly attended to by a server.
He took my drink order with a smile.
He was quite entertaining too.
Quite cute.
Lol This restaurant meets the niche where Chinese dishes are cooked by Muslim chefs.
Let's me eat my Chinese food and let's my Malay friends eat without guilt.
When all our friends arrived we ordered a few things.
All were good.
See pictures for description.
I would definitely come here again whenever i have malay friends with me and i want to eat Chinese zhichar done halal.
Great for everyone.
I can safely declare myself as a loyal member of Swensen's.
Due credits to my dearest Mum who feels most comfortable eating here (for some reason).
We've been a Swensen's regular for more than a decade.
One thing I feel is notable about them is their 85% consistency in food quality.
I've never had much complaints before.
Of course there were times where I can definitely taste the difference between the Mac & Cheese at Tampines outlet, and the one at ION outlet.
But as far as this Bedok's outlet goes, I felt whatever I've tasted have been to my satisfaction.
The space is regrettably quite small when compared to most of the other Swensens I've been to.
It's located right at the corner of Level 1 near the escalators.., by the toilets.
Yeah.
Maybe it's this outlet.
Been this twice and the service and food standard are not good.
Their all time favourite chicken baked rice is not really nice at all.
Disappointed.
But their HOT U.S FRIES & DIP are not bad.
For me, I think mixing with the special chili sauce taste better then mixing with the mayonnaise.
PESTO SALMON is also not really up to a standard I guess everyone will have their own views and likes.
At first glance it seemed like just another branch of Food Republic but I was pleasantly surprised to see the famous Ah Yat Kitchen as one of the stalls.
The abalone noodles cost only $8.80!
The noodles were springy, the soup and gravy were tasty and the ingredients were fresh.
I had restaurant quality food in a food court and will certainly go back again.
The place was big with many seats and finding a nice spot was not difficult.
My friends had usual food court items like chicken rice, bak chor mee and shrimp dumpling noodles but I think the star is really Ah Yat Kitchen.

Was attracted to this stall by their dim sum rather than abalone noodles but was rather hungry and decided to order their abalone noodles which was promoted to be on a limited time offer at $5.50, u.p.
However, upon ordering the noodles, I was charged $8.80.
Questioned the cashier and was told that the promotional item would have less abalone than the one charged at full price.
While it is acceptable to me as I am not a big fan of abalone, it is not acceptable for them to advertise it as the same noodles without stating the difference.
This is misleading and unfair to customers.
The abalone noodles were not exceptional.
While the  thickened broth it were served in was somewhat flavourful, the noodles did not absorb the broth fully and I found myself reach for the chili more often than not.
Then again, this may be due to personal preference.
If you prefer something less strong, this would be just right.
The buns were average and not heated upon order but at room temperature.
The filling was sufficient and decent if one were not picky.
Most people come to this eating place for it's anchor tenant, Fei fei Wanton Mee.
In my opinion, this Rojak stall that sits next to the 'star' of 64 Joo Chiat Place is one of the best Rojaks that I've eaten in the east side of Singapore.
It's run by a single man, Mr Heng.
I've enjoyed Mr Heng's rojak on many occasions and most of the time, he's always friendly and his Rojak is always top notch (unless of course, he's so busy, that he needs to be all business).
Most stalls tend to skive on making sure all the barbequed ingredients are crispy when they've got a long line but here,the Rojak is always barbequed to perfection.
I've never had a soggy Flour Fritter (you tiao) here!
I've tried many combinations and I find that the best tasting combination at this stall is to request for only fritters (you tiao) and the cuttlefish (without the cucumber and other stuff).
This way, one can truly enjoy the crunch of this stall's patiently barbequed ingredients and savour the superbly mixed rojak sauce without vegetable juice and pineapple liquids getting in the way.
This is Singapore's delicious offering to rival salads from the west.
Fei fei wanton mee orders could take a long time, in the mean time, I suggest you work up an appetite with a plate of Rojak.
Located in a coffee shop in Hougang, literally across the bus interchange, near the xin wang cafe is Tian Wai Tian Fish Head Steamboat.
I normally frequent the tian wai tian at ang mo kio, but since I was going bowling at jForte my friends decided to grab dinner here on a rainy sunday night.
At around 730pm, the place was packed.
there was a queue to place zichar orders.
All the tables were occupied and you would've to wait quite a while for an empty table.
Even when we got a table, it took another 10-20 minutes before the table got cleared and cleaned.
My recommendation is make a reservation, so that you have a clean table and the reserved tables are on the other side of the coffee shop which is more airy and windy.
I say at the side facing the bus interchange, there wasn't much air crossflow.
Fish head steamboat We ordered a medium and my friends complained that they coudln't find much fish in the steamboat.
There were 5 of us and yes some pieces were miniscule and some were half the size of an iphone 6S.
The fish was decent, it wasn't MSG ladden as I didn't feel too thirsty after the meal.
The soup was served with vegetables and seaweed.
I loved the seasweed.
The soup was refillable, but it is self-service.
Prawn Paste Chicken Their prawn paste chicken never fail to meet my expectations.
I love them!
They are so crispy on the exterior and juicy and tender on the inside.
They aren't too oily but they sure are sinful!
The chicken wings are also pretty plump.
Egg Fuyong The egg was pretty oily but they were generous with the ingredients, lots of prawns, carrots and some meat in the egg.
The aroma of the egg was pleasant and even though we ordered a small portion, it was more than enough for the 5 of us.
Salted egg pork This was the only disappointing dish we ordered.
The pork was dry and I could barely taste the salted egg.
The salted egg was also barely visible on the pork.
Skip this dish 5.
Sambal Kang Kong This was drenched in oil!
I ended up washing the kang kong in a bowl of fish soup before eating it as there was just too much sambal oil on the vegetables.
For 5 of us, we paid $79, at $16 per pax, our tummies are filled with zi char food and we were all satisfied.
But I'll definitely go for sweet and sour pork rather than salted egg pork the next time round.
Overall : don't expect any service, since you're not pay any service charge or GST, make a reservation before heading down, and do give the fish head steamboat a try.
Hot Stones Steak & Seafood Restaurant used to be one of my go-to places for a great set lunch.
Located at Clarke Quay, Hot Stones is one of the many restaurants offering Weekday Set Lunches at $15 nett.
The sets range from 2 to 6 courses and are immense value for money compared to ala carte prices.

However, while there is no denying Hot Stones still serves up a decent set lunch, it no longer entices me for the fact that standards of meat cuts, portion sizes, sides, service and even accompanying sauces have deteriorated over the years since I first visited the restaurant in 2007.
At Hot Stones, the Set Lunch ($15 nett) gets you 2 courses of soup/dessert of the day and a main of either Sashimi Grade Salmon, Australian Beef Sirloin or Chicken Breast.
A couple of years back, one could choose up to 2 options of main with more choices like Prawns and Kurobuta Pork, but the choices have been sadly whittled down.
The soup of the day was Mushroom Soup, accompanied by Toasted Garlic Bread.
This turned out to be the most enjoyable dish as it wasn't the typical canned-like Mushroom Soup, tasting more like it was homemade with wild mushroom and had a thick, creamy and woody flavour.

While the Beef was immensely disappointing due to the lack of marbling and the cut given (compared to what we have came to expect from Hot Stones from previous visits), the Salmon was still good, though it tasted better raw then cooked, perhaps from the lack of punch in the marinate.
The meat and fish are served raw at Hot Stones and each table is given a hot cooking stone which will slowly cook the protein through.
For the full review and more picture visit voraciousappetite.wordpr…
Service was really slow and you constantly had to flag someone down.
Food was nice though and there was a wide variety.
If you ordered a main you got a free salad bar.
Earle Swensen's -- Till date I still cannot understand why they have to separate the normal Swensen's to this 'atas' Swensen's.
The prices are too costly.
It's quite discomfiting knowing the same dishes at the 'normal' Swensens are priced at a much lower cost.
I've eaten at this Vivo restaurant four times so far.
Twice were treats by my boss.
Hahaha!
And oh!
It's best you make advance reservations if you plan to eat in big groups.
Despite the high cost, this place can be pretty crowded even during a weekday.
I usually look forward to the salad bar whenever I come here.
Those Ritz biscuits are a must have to add that extra crunch to your veggies.
Even the diced up fruit salad is nice.
I usually go with the traditional Thousand Island dressing with my salads.
It's a bowl that is always there.
They have other dressings like mango-flavoured, honey mustard and etc.
Coming to the main courses, I actually do not remember anything that is below $17.
Most of them were $20++ per plate.
I ordered the "Tropical Hawaiian Baked Salmon".
Nice...
The fish was baked and topped with cheese and pineapple.
One of my colleagues ordered "Earle's Poultry Combo".
As soon as her plate came, all of us were entranced.
Me, "Can she finish all that?"
It was definitely a 'poultry combo' as they put it; chicken sausages, chicken thigh slices, chicken breast, duck slices... and a big dollop of mashed potato.
Whoa!!
We all concluded our meals with a molten lava cake, which was scrumptious!
A great dessert to compliment a heavy meal.
One of the famous seafood place in Mersing.
Well, Mersing is well know for its beaches hence seafood there are quite famous and became one of the main attraction there.
When there's too many seafood restaurants, people will going to get confuse in choosing one.
Here it is, one of the affordable seafood restaurant that offer delicious menu.
The ambiance here is what it takes to get me longing and wishing to come back here some other time.
The calm and peaceful beaches is your loyal accompanist whist you're enjoying your meals.
The windy and playful breeze, the skies when you sit at the outdoors seating, something to be treasured when you're spending time with you families or friends.
Quality time I must say.
Anyhow, the parking is quite hard since this is a famous tourist spot and village area normally didn't cater much parking spaces.
Open from evening to midnight, this restaurant is suitable for early dinner and dinner.
One the best rojak ever!
I love rojak, so I think I am justified to say that this uncle had the best balance of the prawn paste down pat.
The ingredients are well soaked and fresh!
The sweetness is just right, the sauce is just right.
I forgot the photo.
But you need the palate not the photo to tell you this is good stuff.
Magic
Lava Rock is a relatively more pricey version of Western food stalls you find in hawker centres, but it provides decent food at comparable prices found in pricier outlets like Aston's.
The stall sells various types of meat (chicken, beef, lamb) as well as seafood and pasta on hotplates.
Each of the main dishes (priced between $8 and $15) comes with two side dishes.

I once had a grilled lamb chop for $9: the meat was cooked pretty well, and more importantly, the texture of the lamb was sinewy rather than crumbly - a good sign that the stall doesn't use processed meat.
The sauce for the lamb chop is nothing outstanding, though decent.
I also once paid for a grilled dory with spaghetti bolognaise on a hotplate for about $9, and the fish was not only tender but fresh.
The spaghetti and the tomato sauce were average, but I felt that I had value for money for that meal.
As for the sides, you won't go wrong with french fries and mashed potatoes.
The coleslaw and rice are forgettable.
The stall also sells calamari rings amongst a slew of hot and cold sides.
The variety of dishes offered at this small outlet is surprisingly wide.
Overall, I would recommend you give it a try.
