For me, the fact that you get relatively good quality meat for under $10, in a hawker centre with a laid-back atmosphere, is good enough for me to choose this over Aston's.
Opening hours: 11am - 10pm
This is a very small stall on the outside of the 321 Clementi mall.
It specializes in coconut ice cream with fruits, nuts, and other toppings.
You can get the base ice cream as normal or in soft serve.
Additionally, there is normal and "strong" flavor, which is even stronger in coconut flavor.
The prices are comparable to other dessert places at about $6 per serving.
I tried the strong flavor normal ice cream with peanuts, pineapple, and aloe jelly.
The ice cream is quite tasty and the peanuts were especially nice with it.
There are some nice touches as well.
The ice cream is served in a coconut shell with some remaining flesh that can be scrapped out and eaten.
You also get a side cup of coconut juice along with it.
Overall, it makes for a nice dessert option, especially if you like coconut.
Not too nutty over this coconut Ice cream.
So I finally got a chance to try the other "authentic" thai coconut ice cream outlet in Singapore (the other one being Pong at *scape).
After 2 previous attempts to try this place (they supposedly close at 10.00 pm but was closed when I got here at 9.45 pm the first time and ran out of ice cream the second time I was here at 9.15 pm.
Talk about bad first impressions).
Today, I was here at 8.00 pm and all prepared to try the first "authentic" coconut ice cream open here.
First impression?
Bad.
They ran out of coconut (the shell and fruit) and coconut water!
Instead, they cut the prices by a dollar and served it to me in a plastic cup.
Secondly, the authenticity of the ice cream is as authentic as Justin Beiber's ability to sing (yes, you can tell that I really don't like him very much).
First impressions aside, the ice cream itself was sub-standard.
The texture was more sorbet-ish than it was an ice cream / gelato.
Slightly icy, the ice cream was more frozen slush as compared to its rival and lacks that creamy rich coconut flavour.
While it comes with a wider variety of nuts (cashew, crushed peanuts and sun flower seeds), and a choice of red Ruby for that authentic thai experience, the key component falls short of expectations.

Overall, while it is edible, it isn't quite the authentic thai experience that it claims to be and the fact that they constantly run out of either the ice cream or the fruit just adds to the disappointment.
Lesson learned.
Good try but I'm sticking to Pong from now on.
You heard of ice cream mix-in, this place offer similar mix-in not for ice-cream but milk shake.
You don't have to stick to the traditional milkshake, you can create your own flavors.
First you choose your the shake base and then you determine what are the mix-in that you want.
If you are not up for experimental flavors, you can pick from their signature shakes.
One of my favorite is simply marshella (nutella and marshmallow mix-in)
Tucked in a tiny corner inside Jurong Safra is the only Ishi Mura Express in Singapore.
Just beside its Sakura Buffet big brother.
For those of you who are not familiar with Ishi Mura, they belong to a chain of Japanese eateries and basically is a Japanese themed food court.
Ishi Mura Express is more like a quick Japanese fast food joint, not dissimilar to Yoshinawa.
In fact, you can also find plenty of these kind of small Japanese fast food style cafes in Japan.
On the menu, you find your typical bento sets, don sets and even ramen.
Food wise, it isnt fantastic.
Price wise, as opposed to Sakura and Jack's Place and the now-defunct Hanis, its the cheapest option in Jurong Safra.
The entire place, and its not very big, feels like a tacky and cheap Japanese cafe.
Yet, like I said, its the cheapest option in Jurong Safra for a quick snack/meal.
If you craving some roti prata, this is the place to stop by!
The curries are delicious and the roti is nice and greasy!
We got the cone thosai just because it would look fun in pictures, but I don't believe you could go wrong with what you pick from here!
Indian Vegetarian is located next all the way at the back of the Comtech foodcourt on level 1 / basement / same level as the carpark.
There are 2 Indian stalls at the Comtech, but this one is vegetarian and the other one is not.
That's about the only difference.
Plus this stall has a bit less choice.
Not because it is Vegetarian, just because the stall is small.
Actually the people at this stall are also less friendly than the Andhra Curry.
Comtech has a large indian working population and they form around 30% of the diners at the foodcourt.
Since there are only 2 stalls and Indians do like to eat Indian food, you can guess the queues are pretty long.
The line of Indian Vegetarian seem to move faster though.
Ok actually there's a lot of difference between the two stalls so make up your mind.
There's a fine line between an exciting and interesting taste, and a taste that is just quite strange.
Personally I found that the flavours here at Jollybelly try to be ambitiously adventurous, but fall short of producing the goods.
I'm not about to slam this shop, I just didn't think it was what I wanted.
Perhaps I expected a bit more of an egg tart experience, or at least a nice cream tart.
There is cream at the bottom of each of these, but nothing very special.
I know they do try, and it probably takes quite a good deal of effort to produce these little tarts, but the flavours like Apple Cheese and Longan Jelly tart just didn't work out very well for me.
I imagine they'd be more welcome on a shallow tart, like those you see in functions.
At $1.50 each though, perhaps you can give it a shot to make your own judgment!
Reminds me of Honeyberry; a piece of home when I was traveling made it a little easier on me.
I am an early riser.
I still woke up early to hit the gym, was the first to dine-in for breakfast at the hotel, and I walked around for an hour to explore.
I had that much time before having to head into work.
Another serendipitous find.
I was walking and enjoying some quiet time to myself and then right before my eyes, I knew I would gain at least 2lbs from my purchase.
I bought the Cheesy Shrooms Pizza and the Chocolate Bomb.
I ate both in the elevator whilst waiting to get to level 2M at work.
My colleagues were amazed and disgusted w/ my appetite.
I didn't care!
A few days after my discovery, I bought a few for my team in Singapore.
During my last week in Singapore, I came back again on a Saturday night for another Chocolate Bomb.
+ cheesy shrooms pizza is hella cheesy + chocolate bomb is THE BOMB Exactly like the roti bun at Honeyberry.
So light, airy, decadent, and a hint of chocolatey goodness.
I enjoyed every single bite.
Damn.
I might need to visit Honeyberry soon!!
Yum!
Tasty little creme-filled donuts, and a ton of different flavors.
My friend and I got a sampler of 4 of these little guys, and it was a nice snack while exploring Singapore.
I've never found this that great, but people seem to love it, and it's the only proper dessert stall in Adam Road Food Centre, so I always find myself finishing off with this anyway.
Their tau suan comes in a very generous portion, with an equally generous helping of you tiao on the side, something which I hadn't even expected at all.
Top marks to them for recognising that you should never have tau suan without the contrasting savouriness of a you tiao!
I found the tau suan rather average, I got a little sick of how 'beany' it was, and I felt that the consistency of the tau suan went a little wrong after a while.
Then again I bought this almost at midnight, when it would probably have been wiser to get in the morning instead.

I was also fairly disappointed by their cheng tng, which has a decent soup, but their ingredients aren't very soft, and don't seem particularly fresh to me, so I never feel like finishing every bit of it.
I'm a sucker for the little sago pearls in cheng tngs, but this one has too little, and is a little too hard for my liking.
I've never tried their iced kacang, but it does look pretty decent (half of the excitement of iced kacang is in its appearance anyway!).
Would love to hear how that goes!
Decent local dessert stall that sells pretty cheap but nice dessert.
I always enjoy coming here for either 'Ice Kachang' or 'Tau Suan' and they never disappoint.
For a price of around $2, what's there to complain?
It's value for money in fact.
For the 'Tau Suan', I enjoy it because it is not too sweet yet tasty, perfect combination with the Chinese doughnut.
The Red Mango at Wilkie Edge is always quiet although occupying a big area.
Seats are always empty and I believe business is not that good.
But it is still a nice yogurt to have between breaks.
The store usually provides two flavours daily.
One being the original plain yogurt and the other flavour is different every day ranging from Mango, Raspberry, etc.
Because of the bad business at this location, the stores always has promotion during weekends and other occasions.
The promotion is definitely worth it, which is 1-for-1.
I will always get myself one and share the promotion with my friend.
The store provide 3-4 tables for dine-in for customers to enjoy their yogurt at the place.
What I don't like is the lack of lights at the store sometimes when the spotlights are not on.
It gives a not energetic feel and doesnt go in line with the impression of yogurt.
Whenever I am around Cineleisure and I am feeling peckish, Best Fries Forever will usually be the place where you will find me satisfying my hunger.
Why this place?
I mean it's nothing special right?
There's fries at MacDonald's, KFC, Burger King etc.
Because here, the fries are well, sliced with the potato skin on, deep fried and served in it's seemingly all natural oily goodness.
But that's not all, it comes in several different 'flavours' ranging from plain to garlic dips to curry.
My boyfriend will usually take the Gusto Garlic flavour while I pick the Wow Wow West (Chilli beef and cheese) one.
This time, I decided to be a little more adventurous and try the Friendly Fire ($4.70 for Large), which is some kind of spicy mayo tasting sauce generously sprinkled onto the fries.
Thankfully, I topped up $1.50  for the Sjora drink because my tongue sadly, cannot tolerate the 'spiciness.'
All in all, Friendly Fire was not bad.
It tastes sweet at first, then the spiciness kicks in a little bit  later.
It's definitely the place to go if you are looking for a quick bite when you are feeling peckish in the afternoon or if you want, order the large and have it for a 'full' meal.
Local chocolate heaven with various mouth-watering desserts.
The price is a bit high but worth it for the quality and support of domestic brands.
I tried the flourless chocolate cake and chocolate truffles.
Thumbs up for both!
True to its name, the cake is filled with pure chocolate instead of flour and the portion is just right to be satisfying but not overwhelming.
The truffles also have the right amount of richness and texture.
To top it off, it comes in cute packaging!
super stoked to try this but alas I was kinda disappointed.
great concept but e toppings are an overkill.
disclaimer: review is only referring to the customize magnum sticks not e plated desserts and food.
I'll be back again to try that :) concept for getting e customized stick: 1. make payment at cashier $7.

one stick w 3 toppings 2. pick your 3 toppings 3. select your dip (white or milk or dark choc) 4. select e drizzle (white or milk or dark choc) 5. watch e pleasure maker making your pleasure and putting e chocolate M to finish up 6. voila!
dig in!
reason why I gave it a two star is cause I think 3 toppings are too much for my taste.
I  didn't even finish e toppings.
I guess I like e simplicity x creaminess x minimalistic of e original magnum.
lesson learnt: too much of  topping may not be a good thing says my inner glut.
pleasure maker?
not so much
Everything With Fries (or EwF) was a pleasant discovery.
Pick six different flavours of fries when you order a main course.
I tried their lamb burger and it was delicious.. the fries?
It was not too bad... just that the amount served to you can be quite overwhelming.
If you must know, do order their curry or garlic fries.
Their Nutella Tart is also not too bad.
Just be warned though, all EwF stores do not charge the same.
At Bugis, one meal (burger and fries minus the drink) can be around $15.
At Orchard Central, it's $9.90 with the burger, fries and a cup of drink.
Of course, the lamb burger is not sold at the Orchard Central branch and so are some of their other dishes.. so do your research properly first before going down to any one of the EwF stores.
Everything With Fries - Where Eggs and Potatoes are the stars The name of the restaurant says it all, every main meal serve in this restaurant come with fries.
A refreshing concept from the founder of Awfully Chocolate, whom recently just open their third branch in Bugis Junction.
Thanks to our friend, Grace, the mother of a tiger baby who suggested this place for our makan session and catch up.
Located in the 4th floor of Bugis Junction, the same floor as the cinema, this restaurant concept is casual dining.
Basically, you won't miss it when you coming from the escalator.
Not sure on how the crowd was going to be that night, we arrived early and hungry.
So we decided to order Skinny Wings ($6.90)  first before our makan kakis arrived.
The skinny wings is crispy on the outside, well seasoned, and juicy on the inside.
Nice and yummy, I'll say.
Lucky thing they arrived when we only started on the nibble, if not I sure will gobbled all up.
Now for the actual meal, I ordered the Char-Grilled Char Siew ($15.90) and the Little Devil ordered the Steak n Tulang ($25.90) on the special menu.
By adding $3.50 each, we also get the famous The One Egg Soup and Lemon Tea drink.
For those that never been here before, the The One Egg Soup is a must try.
Look yellowish in colour, the soup taste is unique, creamy, full of flavour with a little tangy twist.
To top it up, it has the edges of the fried egg to add a different dimension in the texture.

Now for the fries that come with every meal, you have a choice of shoestring or straight cut fries with the following flavours: Original, curry, salt & vinegar, sour cream & onion; and garlic & herbs.
I tried the straight cut with curry, while the little devil get the shoestring fries with truffle oil as part of the special meal.
The fries here sure did not disappoint.
My Char-Grilled Char Siew is tender, juicy and well marinated.
The char-grilled add to the intensity of the flavour of the well braised pork belly.
The garlic sauce is quite subtle and does not overpower the pork belly.
The serving is quite generous, especially on the fries portions unlike the mini portions of the salad.
For Steak n Tulang (Bone) is more like the meal for the carnivore.
The serving is quite huge, compromising of steak, bone and fries that fill the plate to the brim.
The steak is tender and juicy, but slightly overcook.
The bone marrow make a nice pairing with the meat and the fries.
It is so yummy, The Little Devil really clean the plate.
Meanwhile our friend order the grilled pork chop ($13.90) and the cheese burger ($11.90).
Unfortunately the pork chop is a little tough, while the sour cream fries is not crispy due to the sour cream coating.
The burger is tender and juicy, but the portion is slightly smaller compare to the other mains.
Since everyone quite stuffed with the mains, we decided to share the desserts.
We reserved one slice of the mille crepe ($6.90) and Nutella Tart ($6.90).
The mille crepe is made from layers of crepe, cream and maple syrup.
However, the difficult part is to find the balance between the moist crepes and freshness of the cream.
At a first glance, it actually looks very inviting.
However, after the first bite, you realise that the crepe is a little too thick and the cream was slightly solidified that make the cake to become more condensed instead of airy.
It is actually quite disappointing, considering the owner of this place made their name in patisserie.
The Nutella Tart has a solid fillings and crust.
It is compact, thick and heavy.
The Nutella taste is also slightly off, seems different from the taste that you know.
Instead of finishing the meal on a high, the deserts was a let down.
Service here is good.
The service staff here can easily be identified as they are wearing  trendy pink shirts Overall, Everything with Fries brings an interesting dining concept with different flavour of their fries.
The food taste good and from a price point it is easy on the pocket.
We would not mind coming back for more, especially for the unique The One Egg Soup, however we won't expect to much on the desserts.
Cheers!!
Food & Drink: 7/10 Value: 8/10 Service: 7/10 Ambiance: 7/10.
***If you want the full review with pictures, check out my website through the link on my profile page.
Love the nutella crepe cake and the super burger.
We ate at 2 in the afternoon and i was full till evening.
The staff are super friendly too.
Though the place is too busy because its next to a cinema.
This time the place was nominated by Tim from the now defunct ALT foodie eam.
The spirit lives on!
This coffee shop resides in a sleepy HDB enclave of Commonwealth Drive, just about 10 minutes away from Two Chefs.
Why are all the good food in this area?

The dish we visited the place to try out was the nondescript and underrated "San Lao" or samlo horfun only because it is such a simple dish of fish slices and white horfun with none of the sinful ingredients like lard and chili.
It is a good plate of horfun.
Don't expect many dimensions of flavour though.
It is just simply the taste of the fresh fish and the slightly burnt wok-hei taste of the horfun.
The noodles were very smooth and not starchy/stuck together.
I am not sure why it takes "3 hauls" (the name) to make this horfun.
I asked around and someone told me it's because there are only 3 ingredients: Fish, horfun and bean sprouts.
We also had 2 other dishes worth talking about.
First - the rival to Two Chef's butter pork is Jufeng Garden's own rendition.
It is VERY spicy.
Be warned!
If you are a spice lover then this takes it right up to your league.
For me I felt that the pork is a bit dry and the spice just numbs my tongue a bit, but it is quite addictive.
My reactions towards spice is always like that - it kills me but I keep going back to it.
Another cereal (asian bacon!)
dish gave us a pleasant surprise.
The tofu was fresh and fried just nicely.
The sprinkling of some hot fried cereal makes it an irresistible combination.
Overall a simple and real tze char place to have some comfort food.
Prices are fair and if it is not so obscure I might go back there more often!
Local + is a small local restaurant at the second level of Alexandra Retail Centre.
Right outside of the entrance of the pedestrian bridge to the mrt.
It opens early and many have breakfast here.
My stomach is not localized enough yet to have anything else but fruit, bread and yoghurt for breakfast so I only visit this place for lunch.
Where all the other places in ARC have their peak hour between 1215 and 1330, this place strangely enough is only packed after 1pm.
Lot's of variety food from the local kitchen.
I'm usually going for the seafood hor fun.
The shrimps are a bit small but the veggies are fresh and crisp.
Good value for money and local + definitely out performs it's closest competitor killeney.
Get your Kaya on at Wang Cafe.
It's open daily between 07:30 - 21:30.
There is always people eating something at this place, I have never seen it empty.
Many come here in the morning for the home-made kaya, toast bread, soft-boiled eggs and local coffee and tea.
The Mee Siam taste authentic with lots of flavor and they also serve mee rebus and laksa throughout the day.
Sometimes I pick up an iced lemon tea after work on my way to the MRT, because it is right at the entrance of the pedestrian bridge to labrador park MRT.
Came for breakfast, ordered the "Rise and Shine".
The scrambled eggs were extremely dry and powdery, even McDonalds can do a better job at that.
It was a halal certified place, so I have no idea what the ham was made of.
The French toast was okay but was pretty cold when I ate it.
Service wise, the staff were unhelpful and cold, one seemed very new and uncertain of what she was supposed to do.
I observed plates taking at least half an hour to be cleared.
Overall, food cmi (based on my sample of this one dish) and definitely not worth the money.
Pretty quiet place to chill though.
Comfortable ambience, polite, friendly and thoughtful staffs make us feel at home.
I mentioned thoughtful, thoughtful in what way, the staff offered to warm up our chicken pies voluntarily.
Plus the surrounding is clean and the prices of the food are reasonable.
My mum and I had an enjoyable lunch dining today.
We ordered 2 sets of seafood croissants with mushroom soups n coffee & tea, they are yummylicious.
SS attempts to convey a cosy tavern feel with its heavily wooden furnishings, though the throngs cancel it out.
The menus are newspaper style, think House, and understandably manhandled and ratty.
Food choices are unfocused, with an entire page on breakfasts a la Wild Honey, an entire page on pizzas a la Skinny Pizza, and bizarrely, some ramen options too.
Luckily for SS, the kitchen executes its food well.
The sweet potato fries are yummy- crisp on the outside, mealy on the inside.
Popcorn chicken constitutes even cuts of juicy thigh meat.
Pizzas are a flat price for all choices, though if you want to go for half and half, there's an extra charge, which I don't understand, given that all pizzas are the same price to begin with.
For those who fancy Italian beers, SS carries Peroni, which isn't widely available elsewhere.
There's also draft Erdinger, which isn't too shabby.
Given that the the 3 for 2 offer is an all day affair, it certainly makes for (very) happy diners.
Maybe drinking at 10am is the social sin that's so aptly alluded to in the establishment's moniker?
Lucky Dessert is a relatively new dessert shop to Jurong Point, having made its way to Singapore from Hong Kong.
So you can pretty much expect to find a menu with desserts first made famous in Hong Kong, with specialties such as mango sago with pomelo or the snow ice topped with mango or durian puree.
Other than cold desserts, you can also expect warm ones like papaya and white fungus and soy bean pudding.
Here at Lucky Dessert, they present the bill right after the dessert arrives and you are expected to pay on the spot before you tuck into your dessert.

I don't have a sweet tooth so I probably wouldn't frequent Lucky Dessert but I would say it's a good alternative to other dessert chains in Singapore, especially for those missing the famous Xu Liu Shan desserts in Hong Kong.
In recent years, there has been a rising fad for froyo in Singapore.
Froyo basically means frozen yoghurt, which has been touted as a healthier alternative to rich, creamy ice-cream.
Without a doubt, this trend has especially attracted the female population.
Swirl Art is one of the chains of froyo stores that came out from this fad.
What is unique about Swirl Art is that you can DIY your froyo.
Firstly, you can choose from eight to ten flavours of yoghurt.
The yoghurt is smooth and stays frozen for quite a good while.
You can also pick and fill up your cup with a huge variety of toppings.
It is so easy to get carried away.
After mixing and matching your cup of yoghurt, you just bring it to the cashier who will weigh the cup for you and charge you by the weight.
While a fun concept, what draws us to Froyo is the quality of the yoghurt.
The attendants at the store are cheerful and helpful and the whole place is decked out in cute colours - it is quite obvious who they are trying to appeal to.
I'm sold.
Nice cookies but between $6.5-$9/100gm it's a bit on the steep side.
You can always get a quick fix by getting a sample and breathe in all delicious aroma from the ovens in the back.
Love the ambience it's always so relaxing to have your meal or dessert craving there.
I'm always attracted by the colourful dessert display and I'm always spoiled with choices.
At times I really feel like ordering everything.
I had a late night dinner on Friday night and I'm glad that they open till 1 am.
I'm always there with friends for a coffee and some sweet pastry to ease my lonely night and the sweet pastry does do the little wonder.
This cafe or restaurant it's split into 2 parts the outer area is more for cafe style and the inner area is more of a restaurant style.
This time round we decided to have our dinner instead and we pick a seat inside.
The place look so classy and I feel classy too even when I'm wearing a shorts ..... haha Foodie that we order: 1) Duck Confit $28 my all time favourite and it's a must to order food.
The presentation of the duckie is good and it has a nice well crisp on the skin but the meat is alittle dry ..... don't really like it.
2) Cajun Chicken $26 my friend cut me a slice of it and the meat is so tender and juicy.
The fries taste good too the salt level is ok and it's crunchy and I like the way it is.
3) Strawberry Shortcake $12 oh my this is the little sweety that perks my night up.
This is really delicious and I'm in love with the base the cake the 2 layer of different cream.
It's simply too yummy.
4) Classic Cheese cake $9 this is my friend favourite dessert and it's a must to order.
The cheese is so delicious and it's really very nice.
The dinning experience was good and the manager Rebecca is very nice and give us recommendation on food and drinks.
I personally love my mock tail straight no chaser.
It's really refreshing and I love it.
The menu is not extensive and we give our feedback as we feel that it would be a catch if they have more items on the menu.
Rebecca replied that they will be adding more to the menu.
If you are there around next month September do pop over to checkout the new menu ...
I will be there too.
Walked by and knew that I would be ordering something because I know myself so well.
My colleagues also knew and laughed at me.
As always.
I wanted to purchase a few things and totally forgot that I could expense these so I bought a Nutella tart.
The cost is $12 SGD / $8.63 USD.
Still very pricey.
I took this baby back to my hotel room and enjoyed it in bed.
The crust was a bit hard but after the initial bite, everything crumbled easier.
The Nutella mousse was absolutely decadent.
A treat after after dinner in peace was the best way to end the night.
Canele Patisserie and Chocolaterie is one of the many eateries at Supertree Dining, located inside the newly launched Gardens By the Bay.
If you are looking for some good desserts, why not head down and try some really good quality desserts at Canele!
From a wide variety of selection of desserts, choose your favourites from sweets, to chocolates, to macrons and even ice cream!
As the saying goes, there is always room for desserts, and in this case, you better leave much more space in your tummy if you want to taste the yummy sweet delights at Canele.
My recommendations would be the macrons and of course the caramel ice cream.
Macrons are one of my favourite desserts and these small sweet colourful delights just bring jot whenever I take a bit into it.
Even the colours attract my attention when it's on display at shops.
The caramel ice cream is to die-for.
It can be quite sweet, so prepare a cup of water if you can't take it.
Otherwise, it's so rich in flavour and the texture of the ice cream is so smooth, it's gonna be the best way to end your meal!
Half design workshop half cafe/bistro, this place is really for the yuppies and wannabe hipsters.

They have great design aesthetic and philsophy though, taking over a two story colonial house and retrofitting it to be a light-filled open space with communal seating, couches, as well as outdoor tables.
Makes for some great modern photography.
You definitely have to pay to be part of this upper echelon lifestyle though as a simple hot tea will cost about S$8, which is rather exorbitant.
The food encompasses the fresh farm to table philosophy, but isn't particularly mind-blowing.
If you're interested in some trendy photographs and some hipster experiences or you aren't very cost conscious, then go for it!
Chicken Rice is located next to the Resh Fruit stall at the entrance / exit of the Comtech foodcourt on level 1 / basement / same level as the carpark.
Don't be fooled by the long queues, they move super fast.
It's probably the fastest service you can experience at the Comtech Foodcourt.
What I love most about this stall is that it is just decent chicken rice for $ 2,50.
The portions of chicken are not to be complained about.
The rice is full of chicken skin fat flavor.
The spicy sauce is balanced and delicious.
The dark sauce is as you expect it to be.
The staff is very friendly.
Good job guys, keep it up!
This place is fantastic!
Never overly-crowded, its a great place to sit for a cup of tea and munch on a fresh you-tiao after getting groceries at the nearby supermarket.
The teh and teh-c here is superb - the milk and tea perfectly balanced, and the Uncle who prepares the tea here seems to really understand what 'siu - dai (less sugar)' means.
Nothing irks me more than specifically asking for it to be less sugar and the server nodding their head but not bothering to reduce the sugar!
The uncle and aunty (whom I assume are the owners) are very friendly, always striving to give their customers their best and consistently deliver.
Do ask for your you-tiao or butterfly etc to be heated up if you are taking it away but are planning to eat it soon.
If you're having it there though they will usually heat it up to ensure maximum 'crispiness' :D
Stumble onto this place on yahoo's write out on Singapore's 14 best Hainanese curry rice.
It's situated inside Pasir Panjang food centre store 41.
Went there last week around 1.30pm, but was washing up to close....
It opens from 4am (that's right 4am ) to 2pm.
Today, I just managed to reach there at 12.45pm & taste their curry rice, but they ran out of pork chop..hiaz (probably most items sold out during the early hours of the morning).
Well, I guess this place is more for the people working the night shift in the area.
So I ordered what they have left, fried egg, sotong, veg & pig trotter.....& ofcourse, lots of curry over my rice (looks really messy...haha), total $5.50 which was a good deal.
The consistency of their curry is just right, not to thick or diluted.
Wish they had sambal chilli to blend into the dishes...that'll be yummy.
Will be back soon to try their pork chop & curry fish, that's if I can reach before it's sold out.
The store is tiny and the service is friendly.
The "balls" were al dente.
It was tasty, lightly sweetened and chewy in a good way.
Love it and highly recommend this place !
First time having churros so I haven't anything much to compare to but they were really good!
Exactly like I imagined, crispy, sticky and sweet.
The butterscotch sauce went well with the sugar and crunchy churros, which were served in a box folded from chicken rice paper.
Thumbs up for the serivce-there was only one lady there and she was really polite and patient!
The roti prata at this stall is really inconsistent.
The first time I came here it was fantastic.
I had a plain, a cheese and a bomb (boom) prata.
They were sold as they were turned out (i.e.
they were fresh) and hadn't been sitting there for any length of time.
So the prata were crispy with a good bite, and tasted clean without a doughy taste.
The mutton curry meanwhile was thick and tasty.
The bomb in particular was sweet, oily and dense.
However, the second time I came I just ordered plain prata, and they gave me some that had been sitting around for a while.
One piece was only slightly crispy, and was a bit tougher than when I'd had it fresh.
The other though was not crispy at all, and was stale and rubbery.
It was inedible, so I threw most of it away.
Meanwhile the fish curry I tried was too heavy handed and they put too much curry powder inside.
So if you can get the prata here fresh, do so.
If you see some sitting around, either order something special they'll need to make fresh or come back another day.
And you probably should order the mutton curry, not the fish.
Another one of those hidden gems in the middle of the heart lands that only those living in the neighbourhood would know about!
Most Indian eating houses nowadays offer a wide variety of dishes, most of which are only subpar in quality, especially the pratas.
Enaq's menu offers a wide but yet concise variety of different Indian dishes, more than enough to satisfy your palette.
I ordered a plaster prata (prata with an egg, sunny side up), it was definitely one of the best I've tasted so far.
A few places offer crispy prata, Enaq is one of the few.
The difference is that the prata here is a fine balance between crispy and soft!
Really a delight to consume.
The curry served might be too little for some, but it was just enough for me.
Another thing about the prata that differs from other places was that prata here is served with not only curry, but nasi lemak chilli as well, an interesting combination I must say.
The only downsides I would say is that the eating house is quite limited in seats, as well its closing timing at 12am.
This place is absolutely horrible - is what I want to tell people so the place doesn't get more crowded than it already is, but truthfully, it's my favourite prata place.
You wouldn't believe how happy I am to have place that serves crispy prata in the west.
The place seems to always be crowded, but the turn over rate is pretty fast and if you don't might sharing a table it really shouldn't be a problem.
You might have to wait a little for your prata cause of how packed it is.
I usually find myself at the tail end of my drink before my food comes, maybe that's why I get a drink after all.
I always get their teh tarik, and I highly recommended it, both hot and cold.
Foodwise, my go-tos are the kosong (plain), egg and cheese.
They are known for their milky gems prata which is filled with condense milk and m&ms, sounds like a delicious dessert combination, but it is pretty sweet.
I've also heard they have a good plaster prata!
Their curry isn't the usual fish curry, and is very flavourful, but compliments all good well.
They also give you chilli, which happened to be my first time using this as a condiment for prata, which also happens to work very well.
Overall, amazing no frills prata place, that I guarantee you will leave happy with your food.
The food is pleasantly delicious.Shd try the Nasi Lemak in the morning..The briyani is a class too.
Great restaurant near Mustafa.
Most lunch specials are about $10, which is quite reasonable.
They serve you papadums as an appetizer.
We tried: -roti prata with chicken currry: you can never go wrong with roti prata.
They did a great job.
-fish curry with basamati: delicious, not too spicy -mango lassi: delicious Overall, a great restaurant with good AC.
It was quite popular during lunch time too.
Men Men Don Don is a little food kiosk that is conveniently located at the first floor of White Sands.
This is where you can get a quick takeout of Japanese food, such as ramen, sushi and oyako don.
The taste of the food that you can get from here is quite disappointing, although the prices are relatively cheaper than getting a takeout from the restaurants.
Nothing else is really praise-worthy or worth mentioning... Well, overall just very average.
I had to pop by Men Men Don Don when to grab a quick bite before I booked into camp while I was in army.
Its a rather basic japanese eatery with your run of the mill dishes like udon and rice.
Its one of the more affordable places so dont expect world class food over here.
But I guess its okay considering how much you're paying for a meal.
THey've also got a takeout sushi section for quick bites on the go.
Decent place.
The buns are so delicious and reasonably priced!
Must go!
Ive tried their custard buns and really like it.
The staff are friendly and the prices are reasonable for a location in town.
A quick snack stop if you are rushing.
It faces the road near a bus stop, so you can't miss.
Enjoy!
The buns are freshly baked in the morning so soft and warm..
If you are there before 9am, go to the baking tray to see what you want.
My guilty pleasure is the luncheon meat with egg bun!
Yummy and it costs $1.50.
Sandwiches are freshly made and costs $2.50.
Located near Kovan mrt, the place is not very well known but the food there is nice and cheap.
Once you step in, the aroma of the coffee and slightly charred bread reaches your nose.
The spreads on the bread are also generously given spread to all 4 corners of the toast.
There are a few types of bread that you can choose from soft bun, the normal bread and French toast.
All can be eaten in its original state or toasted.
They also serve the hong kong style hot lemon tea which is rarely found in Singapore.
If you are looking for a good and affordable breakfast or tea break this would be a place to try out.
Nostalgic feeling with the decor to distress as well.
Was excited for traditional bread - according to Straits Times (I think it was Sunday Lifestyle), this is one of remaining eight bakeries in Singapore which still make bread the traditional way.
soshiok.com/article/21574 Anyway, there wasn't a ton of bread left, I would've liked to try their normal buns but they only had coconut and curry chicken left, which I'm not such a fan of.
Curry chicken with bread (or rice) - $5.80.
Came with barley drink (which had lots of barley seeds inside).
The curry was oh so decadently rich!
I bet there was a ton of coconut milk.
I also bet their laksa would be pretty good.
Anyway, the chicken itself was so-so, not as tender as I would've liked - a little tough, actually.
Potato was done well though!
3 large slices of toasted baguette -  the crisp from toasting was good!
But the bread itself was so-so also, I thought.
At least, texture-wise they definitely can't match up to baguettes in France.. Haha.
Perhaps that's too high a standard to hold them to.
A square loaf of pandan bread costs $1.70!
Smelt pretty good.
Fluffy bread!!
The lady was also really nice and let me exchange it later on (mom told me we needed more bread at home, so wanted a larger loaf).
So, I went on my merry way home armed with a larger (rectangular) loaf of pink and yellow coloured bread.
We shall see how fluffy it is tomorrow morning.. Update -- colourful bread was fairly fluffy, not so airy that it was insubstantial, but just nice.
Not mind blowingly amazing but pretty good stuff!
A very traditional bakery tucked in the clementi distreet.
It's olden looking brown shelves had caught my attention as I walked passed the shop after my breakfast.
Where most franchises are selling at $1.50 each, Emerald bakery offers them at a attractive pricing as most of the items cost not more than a dollar.
Custard Bun costs $0.80 and was surprisingly good.
It's custard was pure and not creamy as I would have expected.
The bright yellow custard was stuffed into the fluffy and soft roll.
Totally well worth it's money.
The croissant here I had in the morning was buttery, flaky and simply delicious!
At $2.80, it was absolutely worth every cent.
It went really well with the latte I ordered.
For $3.80, it was pretty decent and was nice and smooth.
Being extremely hungry, I had something else and I'm glad I did.
Their pain au chocolate was awesome!
Although I'd personally like a bit more chocolate (I mean, who doesn't?
), it hit the right spot.
Will be coming back again.
I totally forgot about the existence of this place until I was looking through Ngee An City's directory.
I decided to go there for lunch and to my surprise, it's not even half filled though it's almost 1pm.
we were quickly seated by the friendly host and orders for the 1 for 1 lunch deal (comes with soup of the day) was taken.
Less than 10 mins, the first of our 2 main courses was served but without the soup.
that quickly was rectified after they realized it missing.
The food itself was fine, nothing much to be excited about.
The chicken breast Amatriciana and shellfish pasta was good in portion but not too yummy in taste - perhaps because it wasn't too hot when served.
The seafood baked rice looked promising.
Sadly, it wasn't to my coworker's liking as it had way too much cheese on it.
If you love cheese, maybe you would think different.
we paid $15 each for this meal.
i guess it's decent for a meal in orchard.
Right smack on Serangoon Road with the Broadway Hotel Bus Stop right in front.
This place is great for people watching but the food was just average.
The menu and sign says they serve authentic Nepalese & Indian cuisine.
Menu is extensive and has something for the veg and non-veg diners.
Really nice table servers and always looking out for a wave of a hand for anything you need.
Sunday streets can be quite crowded.
Not touristy, which is a good thing.
No frills.
In fact, the staff seemed indifferent to our patronage.
We went around 1:30 on a Thursday afternoon.
It was not very busy and the customers all seemed to be locals.
Many menu options were not available, such as the chicken tandoori.
Not sure if it was because we went after the lunch rush, if there was one, or if they just don't regularly carry all the ingredients to make the menu items.
We ordered the curry fish and fried chicken.
The portions for each dish are just right for one person.
Both come with roti and were genuinely good.
The curry fish came in a rich spicy broth that had a good flavor.
We ordered mango lassi to wash it all down.
The lassi was rich and had a slightly salty flavor that balanced out the sweetness of the mango.
It was a good compliment to the curry fish.
Overall the appeal of this place is that it is not a tourist trap.
Nobody is trying to woo you and there are no stereotypical dishes catering to foreigners.
It is just simple good food with no frills.
We just moved to the neighborhood and discovered this place on our way to the post office a few weeks ago.
This shop sells both southern and northern Indian food.
We have tried the briyani, dosa, and pratas so far and enjoyed them all.
Even the teh is very flavorful.
Looking forward to coming back soon to try the other dishes.
Cake Magic is a halal certified bakery selling all sorts of bread and cakes that you can typically find in a local neighbourhood bakery.
They also have a waffles station where you can choose a few different toppings for your waffles.
The only thing I go to Cake Magic to buy is their french loaves.
While it does not taste like the baguettes you get in most Western countries, this kind of french loaf is the traditional South East Asian kind which well with curries rather than jams or cheese.
I love to buy it when it is fresh out of the oven and the insides are warm and soft while the outside is hard and crispy.
On weekends, their french loaves sell like hotcakes, so get it fast.
They come out twice a day: around 8am-9am in the morning and 4pm in the afternoon.
If you're an early riser (I'm talking 6am-ish) and need some warm freshly-baked bread to fill your stomach, rest assured than Q Bread is ready for you!
It opens really early, and the delicious smells wafting out of the shop is simply irresistible.
Early commuters at the nearby bus stop will almost definitely stop by to buy something to chew on.
The selection of bread and cakes isn't huge, but it's not small either.
You'll find the floss buns made famous by BreadTalk, little pizza-like things, hot dog buns, and more.
They also make waffles and bubble tea on the spot for those greedy moments.
It's definitely not at the level of Koi or Gong Cha, but you don't really have a choice in this area!
Also, there's a selection of those bigger cakes for special occasions such as birthdays.
Nothing fancy, but they look and taste decent.
5 stars for a great nasi lemak meal especially in the mall setting where decent food can be hard to come by due to the high rent!
The 2 basics, light n fluffy basmati rice and the sambal chilli with kick, are excellent as well as most of the other sides/ingredients offered.
Of particular mention is the bergedil (Malay style potato cutlet), always a good addon to go with this meal.
The teh tarik hot drink is also great, rich and flavoursome.
My only dislike is the extensive use of disposable ware including paper cup for hot drinks.

Sadly many other places are similar but I'm hopeful that the reusable wares are making their way back as more recent studies are saying it's much greener, safer n economical to use the proper food wares whether they are made of stainless steel, wood, or bamboo :-)
Pretty decent Nasi lemak.
Rice is very hot which is good, although I found it a little dry and not as fragrant as other places.
The sambal was rich and they gave you plenty of it which is a bonus!
No peanuts, but loads of ikan billis on this plate (which is disposable plastic unfortunately).
Fish cutlet was very standard and a bit cold and the Otah Otah was small and a little bland, but passes as the texture was great with it still being moist.
Very friendly staff who are up for a chat and obviously love what they do which is always a pleasure to see.
They have a small seating area which I imagine will fill up quickly during the peak periods.
Good place to have reasonably priced Nasi Lemak in a mall, albeit a little more than a hawker centre.
There are too many cafes and not enough bakeries in Singapore!
Luckily for us, Swirls Bake Shop opened up at the very trendy neighbourhood of Rodyk Street which is very near to Kith cafe and Toby's Estate.
Serving up cupcakes in various shapes, flavours, sizes and colors, Swirls Bake Shop was opened up by a charming couple who decided to start a business together.
Very brave I must say.
The lady boss came from a fashion background so the shop had design influences from that.
They then embarked on a cupcake tour of USA to taste all the cupcakes for RESEARCH purposes.
Isn't that fun?
They specialized in tasting red velvet cupcakes as well, which is coincidentally my favorite.
I heard mixed reviews about Swirls.
Some say good, some say bad.
Timeout magazine said it was "possibly the best-tasting cupcakes we've ever had".
It is quite a small but cozy space that is divided into the kitchen and the shopfront.
There are 4 chairs inside along a small counter, and more chairs outside.
All the cupcakes sold do not have swirly icing which is ironic since the shop is called Swirls.
We found that that is because the icing is 'handswirled' with a flat knife instead of piped from a bag.
That's why every cupcake is unique.
Well.
The taste testing around all of the States did not go to waste.
I tried the Red Velvet and found that it was really delicious!
The cake was soft and fluffy, adequately moist and looked so good with the red coloring.
It was not too sweet and all together just very enjoyable.
For the rest of the cupcakes I found them rather average.
The problem I have with cupcakes is that they tend to be very very sweet, so much so I will normally just scrape off most of the icing and eat the cake with a thin layer of it.
It paled slightly in comparison to Plain Vanila Bakery's cupcakes, but on its own it does pretty well.

Though this is the first time I am trying Thye Moh Guan's Tau Sar Piah since it became a part of Breadtalk Group, they are still as delicious and no wonder it has been so popular over the years =D There are a total of five flavours, in addition to the traditional teochew mooncake.
The classic versions are of course their sweet and savoury piah.
The mung bean filling which was made from scratch is so aromatic and smooth.
I was surprised to find salted egg yolks in both flavours!
Another interesting flavour is the Double Delight: red bean paste and a sticky winter melon filling with melon seeds & dried orange peel.
The white sesame seeds added a nice crunch to this mild-savoury piah that reminded me of lao po bing (wife's biscuit).
But my favourite was the Spicy Pork Floss (aka Yuan Yang )!

Paired together with the savoury mung bean and salted egg yolk, this novel invention is also highly suitable for those who can't take spicy food because the spice level has been balanced out by the tau sar.
I am a Teochew but this is my first time having this Traditional Teochew Mooncake.
Made with white sesame, dried kumquat, five-spice powder, this has a light citrusy taste with quite firm, chewy texture due to the maltose.
Not everyone may like this old school sweet so perhaps it's an acquired taste.

Luckily the tau sar piah is available in regular size all-year round at their outlets and in various flavours such as cranberry, etc (the mooncakes are medium size) It's time for me to make a trip down again and stock up supplies at home!
Had to have the Singaporean Dish of chili crab - so chose this place to stop.
Food was excellent, wait staff friendly but was more interested in visiting with each other.
I recommend the chili crab!
A very intimate setting by Marina Bay, may not have the best view of the Bay Area because it is partially blocked by Clifford pier and The Fullerton Bay.
Unfortunately they didn't have any happy hour promotions, so things were pretty pricy, but they did mix some really yummy drinks!
We had the wagyu crostini and some scallops on cheese.
The wagyu was extremely well done, with the garnishes sautéed perfectly.
The scallops were pretty okay, although the fried cheese was too dry for my liking.
Overall, I'd recommend this place for the drinks, and well oysters.
always yummy no matter which outlet i go.
my favorite on the menu is the golden squid head; it's hard to resist even when piping hot.
it's decently priced at $4.90 per serving.
I like the chewy texture and the spiciness that comes with it.
you can choose to have it mild, medium or super hot.
warning: possible distortion of face when consuming item
Don't quite get the long lines.
Ok, it is a better than average kind of fishball noodles.
I would love eating it but not if I need to line up for 30 min.
The fishballs are not big, bouncy and yet soft.
I had the dry noodle version and the chilli is very spicy.
It is not oily though so that is good.
Most people ordered the soup version or the kway teow-mee version.
Maybe next time.
The stall only opens at noon.
So don't expect to have fishball noodles for breakfast.
Brightly lit bakery with plenty of options.
My friend specially recommended the Belgium dark chocolate bread roll and it did not disappoint.
Buying 4 pieces together is cheaper than buying each piece separately.
Since it was my first time trying I decided to get 1 piece first.
1 piece was actually quite satisfying as the bread was pretty dense and the filling was creamy.
The dark chocolate flavour was strong and not too sweet.
Probably one of the better bakeries in Kallang Wave Mall.
Swissbake breaks my heart.
Their recent collaboration with Toblerone (YES that triangular Swiss chocolate bar) - Toblerone chocolate puff, it was... as my 2 star rating indicates, MEH.
The centre was pretty hollow, and the chocolate just laced the walls thinly.
HOW CAN!?
Such an incredible chance to wow the public and it falls short of people's chocolate fantasies.
In their regular line though, the chocolate rolls are good, the distinct texture and thick chocolately filling satisfies your cravings.
The cheese straws are good too, firm and cheesy, it's an easy snack to chew on during "working on deadlines" times.
I don't know much about European pastries, but most pastries in Swissbake are super flaky, drops everywhere like snowflakes, best to eat them from that paper bag.
I was recommended to Swissbake by one colleague, who enthusiastically told me that Swissbake was started by a Swiss pastry chef who has had 30 years of mastery.
My colleague loves their chicken mushroom pie, claiming that it is a must-try.
The pie is huge, bigger than my palm; it's rich with filling and looks like it will fill up a hungry stomach in no time.
Oh and they always have samples of their new pastries to try at the counter.
It's useful especially if it involves something risky like spinach puff.
When you ask me where to find one of the best chocolate strawberries in Singapore, I'll say go to Chocz!
They sell chocolate strawberries from small to big sizes and charges them accordingly.
I will usually go for the big strawberries as they are quite sweet and melts very well with the chocolates!
It's a definite must try when you are in the area and feeling peckish!
Esplanade used to be a major hangout spot for my friends and I back in the day, and I do remember one of them getting a skewer of strawberries covered in chocolate... they were pretty good!
Though I recalled the price to be anywhere from $4.50 - $6.50 (whoa mama!
that's way too much for 4 medium-sized strawberries encrusted in semi-deluxe choc).
Affordable, friendly helpful staff.
I tried the roti prata with onion for breakfast 1.70 Delicious grab a coffee next door to go with it
I tried it out of curiosity.
Despite the ample samples, I took a gander at a loaf that had figs, red wine and rye amongst other things.
Wasnt too sure if it was any good and considering it was pricey ($6 for the said loaf), I wanted to just experiment with one.
Soft and chewy and awesome figs in that loaf!
I loved it.
The bread was soft and I bought it around 8pm...imagine what it must taste like hot and fresh.
Gasp gasp.
I had to control myself not to finish the loaf and to save it for breakfast.
Should've bought two eh.
Will try the huge donut thingies and pesto bread next time round!
Time for some carbo loading!
Proudly home-grown, BreadTalk is one of the most popular bakeries in Singapore.
With many outlets islandwide, the bakery stall provides one of the best variety of bread and buns to customers.
Some of my favourite products, which happens to be their best sellers include the floss bread, the cheese cake and the chocolate buns!
Also, during special occasions and festivals, you can see BreadTalk naming their products accordingly, and sometimes even creating new buns to cater to the occasion!
Such as Christmas, Chinese New Year and even the upcoming latest movie!
The outlet at Harbourfront Centre is always crowded, even in the morning as many working adults buy their breakfast there.
So fret not for you morning meal is settled.
This bakery is located in the Clementi 4 Food Loft.
It has only about 10 or so choices of buns.
They also have cheese tarts and mung bean cakes (tau sar pneah).
I wouldn't identify their buns as elegant because they are large pieces but they definitely give you enough bites for a light breakfast.
Their flavor are generally good, except for their cheese buns which I thought are too oily.
While it is not the best bakery in town, it is located at a convenient place for the surrounding residents who wants to grab a quick bite before boarding the bus.
They are also open as early as 7 am.
They bake their buns in batches of 24 so you are sure to get a fresh one.
Plus, for the same price as more mainstream brands, you are getting 3-4 more bites.
Was hankering for a snack to munch on and happened to pass by this bakery.
I pulled my buddies in to look around.
At first glance, the buns don't look that different from those at Swee Heng Bakery.
Then we discovered cake rolls, marble cake and waffles, which aren't available at my bakery of choice.
I settled on a cranberry muffin and a banana walnut muffin.
A sign said buns were priced at 3 for $3, so I picked a durian bun, black pepper chicken and a cranberry cream cheese bun.
Yeah, all five for me.
I can eat you know, it just doesn't show.
The buns were blehh.
I have never seen a mustard yellow banana walnut muffin (and it was topped with such a miserable amount of walnuts).
I sensed no real fruit, but lots of food flavouring.
Plus, the muffins were so dry!
The durian bun didn't fare any better - it tasted bitter.
Swee Heng's durian buns are still king, for me.
Black pepper chicken bun, so-so lah.
I had the cranberry cream bun afterwards.
It was tooth-achingly sweet and stuffed with so much cream cheese, I felt like puking out everything I consumed before, so I decided to keep the other two items for breakfast the following day.
Lesson learnt: Next time, cross the road and grab something from Swee Heng Bakery instead.
Then strangers won't give me weird looks if I walk around clutching at my bloated tummy.
Came by here and heard from my friend that their cheesecakes were nice!
It didn't take long to find it since it's just above the Dhoby Ghaut MRT.
Went with the classic cheesecup that I had bought on the sugar app.
For $3.30 it's Abit pricey for such small cheese cake in a tiny cup.
But it did taste like how original cheese cakes taste like but as you scooped the cheese cake, I wasn't able to scoop up the biscuit crumb base.
It was too hard and had stuck to the bottom of the cupcake sheet.
I do like the idea that they sell cheesecakes in a smaller package rather than a slice.
It's definitely easier on my daily calorie limit but at $3+ for just a mouthful of cheesecake?
This reminds me of paying a lot more for less!
Nonetheless still a great place for that cheesecake cravings!
It's pricey.
$3.30 for a plain churros.
The dough was half cooked on the inside though the outside is completely crispy and brown.
I'm guessing it's because the oil temperature was too high.
The sugar was coated evenly on the surface and you will bite into lumps.
Very good cool refreshing soft tofu desserts.
I had the almond ($1.50) and the chocolate ($2).
The texture is soft smooth and amazing.
Superb quality at a great price.
Mr Bean's logo is just an adorable soy bean.
Just Soya pudding taste just as cute and cozy as the logo.
It is made with 100% freshly brewed soya milk and it taste soft and silky.
Just the perfect lunch desert!
I'm not really a fan of the other items they serve like the soybean cheese pancakes or the Strawberry Soya Smoothie or Strawberry Cream Cheese Pancake, that's just a bit too much for me.
I prefer to have a simple and pure soya product.
The staff at this outlet is a bit impatient and not so friendly, I guess it is because the long queues and they get agitated and stressed.
Or maybe they know they don't have to try hard because their business is successful anyway.
Ice cream Flavors available: quite a good selection of the common flavors and some premiums.
Texture of ice cream: not smooth enough as there is ice blocks inside Price: rather expensive for the rough textured ice cream.
But overall good enough place for me to hide out from the hot afternoon sun as the aircon is super strong, lighting is good.
Not yet try out the Belgium waffles though....
Expectations weren't high since they were one of few places open past midnight but I must admit I was delightfully surprised by Ruyi.
Think of it as a fast casual Chinese spot.
I appreciate the take-out packaging that keeps the soup and noodles separate till you're ready to eat.
We ordered the BBQ pork & shrimp dumpling noodles (dry), the shrimp dumplings noodle soup, and the stewed minced pork rice with soy egg.
The noodles had a wonderful texture and the dry noodles in particular had great flavor between the dark sauce and chilli.
The shrimp dumplings were plump and delicious with a silky skin.
All in all, a great late night eat.
The fact that Ruyi is open 24 hours is a huge plus.
The fact that the food happens to be quite tasty is a nice surprise to boot!
Swee Heng does one thing really well: serve up fresh bread at an affordable price.
Granted, bread in fancy flavours these days aren't hard to find, but Swee Heng frequently has promotions which let you bring home a number of bread for a price, such as three piece of bread for S$4.
It's located very close to Boon Keng MRT, so it makes for a great quick fuss-free breakfast before your morning commute.
As far as competition with the Q Bread across the street goes, I don't think there's much of a difference, just how convenient it is.
The neighbourhood is big enough for two bakeries anyway.
But I visit Swee Heng more because it's closer to me.
Little Wimbly Lu is the sister store of Wimbly Lu.
This dessert place is a stone's throw away from the Chomp Chomp Food Centre and has limited seating (both indoor and outdoor).
It was packed on a Monday night.
I got the waffle with salted caramel ice cream.
I had the ice cream served in a separate cup.
The waffle came in 2 pieces of a quadrant.
The waffle texture was good.
Crispy on the outside and soft in the inside.
It came with a small cup of maple syrup which gave the waffle most of its taste.
Without it, the waffle was pretty bland.
The ice cream I got was ok - too buttery for my liking.
All in all, it was an ok after dinner experience.
Not a bad breakfast place especially if you have a hankering for the local.
It appears their speciality is their thick-cut toast although I have yet to try their non-breakfast dishes.
Had their peanut butter on thick toast which was pretty good.
Wouldn't mind a repeat visit.
Best bites ...... is a eatery which locates at science park 1.
The name sounds good ya ....
There is not much eatery around this vicinity and the other nearest eatery is located at DSO.
This eatery serves different kind of food ranging from Western, Indian,  Chinese food and the price is around average hawker centre price.
This eatery has indoor and outdoor seating, therefore you can have a choice to choose.
The vendor of chicken rice and wanton Mee stall got relocate here from NUH staff canteen.
It's great to see familiar faces but of cause the price still remain the same.
During peak hour this eatery is full of people, so normally I will just ask to take away as it's crowded.
There are juices and fruit stall as well as a small minimart just around the corner.
If you happen to be around this area, do pop over to have a meal here......
Surprisingly, the ramen wasn't too shabby.
I had the cha shu ramen and the broth was thick and flavorful and ingredients fairly substantial.
My only gripe is that the noodles get a little soft when left soaking for too long - I haven't quite acquired the slurping skills of a bona fide Japanese ramen slurper yet!
Not without splashing all over, that is.
There are also gyozas in the menu, and strangely there are a couple of options that made me go 'eh?
', namely the homemade gyoza, and the crispy gyoza.
So we were wondering.. hm.. perhaps the crispy one isn't homemade then?
And so we opted for the homemade one, since pan fried gyozas all come crispy right?
WRONG.
The homemade gyozas weren't crispy, and the verdict - mind blown.
Filling was rather porky, so if you ask if I'll order it again, here enters my favourite bear meme - HOW ABOUT NO complete with raised paws.
I'd go for the noodles again though!
First time here visiting a friend after church.
Small establishment, if you don't stay nearby, I'm sure you would not even noticed this place.
Ordered standard stuff but Ikan Assam Pedas is not bad.
Local alley food, interesting and must try for the full Singapore experience.
The black thick 3 cup sauce was yummy with especially with the sesame oil porridge.
The food is good but the service and cleanliness is questionable.
We ordered water and coke and it was a battle to try to get drinks.
May not come again unless bring friends along.
This outlet of Muthu's is probably the one that still tries to maintain the high standards it was once renowned for.
The one at Dempsey is just a poor excuse to overcharge people for simple dishes.
The fish head curry over here is still as good as it was when I had it as a little kid, while the rest of the dishes have not really been consistent.
Now, this review is solely on the food.
We came a little after lunchtime and the service was slacking for an almost empty place.
However, food was great.
We had a few dishes - the fish cutlet, the fish roe and the fish head curry.
Fish cutlets and fish roe were...meh..to say the least.
But the fish head curry was nice and fresh.
I devoured all the gloriousness of the fish's cheek and jaw and eyes!
Yum!
I loved the addition of pineapple in the curry; almost a palette cleanser.
I'd say skip everything else and get the fish head curry.
Worth it!
I have been told that this restaurants' standards had dropped in the past 1-2 years, but I still wanted to try it with my family.
Unfortunately, we were disappointed.
We had fish head curry, the dish was quite disappointing.
The fish was hard, over cooked, not fresh and had a hint of an off-putting fishy smell.
The fish was placed on a big deep bowl with plenty curry sauce, but the strong curry spice couldn't cover the fishy smell.
The fish head curry was so disappointing!
When we told the waiter the fish was not fresh, he replied, the fish was cooked to order.
My point is, cooking a fish that wasn't fresh in the first place doesnt make it any fresher!
Another dish is the lamb dish.
It was very chewy.
Since they had a buffet in the afternoon that included this dish, I was wondering if they just gave us the leftovers.
Additionally, one of my family members and I got bitten by a mosquito.
My friend already made a reservation  in this restaurant, and after my dinner I immediately told them to cancel it.
This restaurant was a disappointment.
OMG YUM!!!!
Not only was the food good, but the service was great as well.
I got the Mutha's Chicken Chuuka and it had a wonderful spicy taste to it.
I will definitely be back for more of that!!
Definitely get the mixed appetizer as well.
I left so full that I needed to be rolled out of there.
Lol.
Their cheese naan is great also.
Heard so much about this place and finally tried it out yesterday while in Singapore and I tell you it was amazing.
The food was great and you just can't say enough about this place.
Service was top notch and Narayan was awesome.
He took such good care of me and my family.
You have to try this if you are ever in Singapore.
Ordered the waffles and utterly disappointed!
Do not come for the waffles.
Hard as rock and when requested for a new piece.
They came back with a melted ice cream.
This is about a 2.5 star place.
Espresso no good.
Same stuff you'll find at Starbucks.
The moelleux citron framboise was ok.
I like that it wasn't overly sweet.
I do like the venue.
It's nicely decorated and hearing la vie en rose in the background is very nice.
But then that bubble is popped by the cutlery.
Am I in prison?
The fork is so thin and pre bent like a child was playing with it or an amateur magician.
Cheapens the experience.
Maybe I'm nuts.
Ho hum food at the restored colonial buildings near Seletar airbase.

Wheeler's Estate is one of four newly opened restaurants located at "The Oval", a set of restored colonial buildings formerly occupied by RAF servicemen who worked at the Seletar Airbase right up till 1971.
Hipsters and instagrammers, rejoice.
There is that "cool" atmosphere, with spacious surroundings, mood lighting and conservation buildings that hint of an era gone by.
However the same cannot be said of the food...
The menu is a little pricey, with the usual steaks, fish n chips and pastas.
I went for the S$99 T-Bone and a grilled octopus starter, which I almost instantly regretted the minute it arrived on the table.
It was plated immaculately, but was chewier than an eraser and definitely overcooked.
The steak wasn't much better, rather bloodless and dry, without much flavor.
It was placed on a gas grill (smelled of gas) and the sauces overpowered the steak.
Perhaps I ordered the wrong menu items?
For me, food quality comes first.
I guess it's 4 stars for the atmosphere but 2 stars for the disappointing food.
I'll most probably be back for a drink or dessert, but will definitely skip the food.
To be fair, we came here only because of a bad experience at Wildseed Cafe (I waited for 20 minutes, only to discover by chance that my name had been struck off).
The food were generally not bad.
I only would say (1) i didn't quite enjoy the crab benedict that was served cold (the crab salad part was fridge cold) (2) the breads across all 3 dishes were the same brioche toast.
maybe different bread options would be good to keep this from being so monotonous.
biggest gripe was the prices.
we spent $120 for these 3 mains and 3 coffees.
Quite a hefty sum for a place that is so far out and need some form of public transport or taxi to get to.
service was all youngsters who are inexperienced.
Is a gem in the neighborhood.
I love their cakes especially Chocolate Bomb - heart melting chocolate indulging experience.
Strawberry shortcake - the sweet aroma of vanilla will send you to cloud nine.
And the fluffy sponge cake is so soft.
Sakura tea - Now then I realize how good Sakura smells.
And it is refreshing.
Love it.
Staff are friendly and beautiful.
Cupcakes bought in the morning or earlier in the day were definitely much better than those bought later in the day.
This would probably be true of all baked goods where they would taste better when they were not left out in the open for too long.
Prices have increased a little.
It used to be $3 for a cupcake (regular flavors) and it is now $3.20.
Add 50 cents to the specials of the day.
The cupcake has a cake texture, a bit moist and soft (when bought in the morning).
It gets a bit drier and harder when eaten in the evening or next day.
The frosting is creamy, some has a buttery taste.
I like that it is not overly sweet and that the frosting is not too much.
Though some would prefer a bit more frosting as the proportion was more of 1/5 to 1/4 frosting to 4/5 or 3/4 cake.
So some of the cake will not get the frosting.

I am still not a huge fan of Twelve Cupcakes but since they seem to open up near the MRT entrance/exit, they will do in a pinch when I need to bring something to a party or when I want something easy to eat on the go as a quick fix dessert or just to get it for friends.
Convenience is a huge factor for purchasing cupcakes here.
Plus the mini cupcakes make a great party gift or for days you want to try all the 12 flavors without the major guilt of indulgence.
I don't go for traditional soya bean so if that's the kind you like, skip this.
This is in the style of "Lao Ban" and it was a nice surprise.
It was similar but it tasted a bit different, perhaps a touch more "beany" and less sweet.
No queues, $1.50 for the soya beancurd original.
Sweet but not cloyingly so, the slippery soft coldness was perfect for this very hot day.
Plus this is a dessert which is very easy to eat when you have a mouth ulcer.
I've had Lao Ban a number of times and my regular soya beancurd shop is Yummy Soy which is even more similar to Lao Ban and near my place.
Compared to those 2, I detected a very slight powdery texture at times in this.
Not enough to stop me from enjoying it.
But that coupled with the plastic spoon they gave me being seriously very rough on the edges and of a very low quality.
Seriously, I bit myself already, I don't need to slice my mouth open next with a plastic implement.
Rating is therefore 4 star.
I will be happy to buy if I'm craving beancurd and am in the area.
They had other flavours like durian and also a mango sago that I would like to try next time.
Chendol is this amazing Malaysian dessert made of shaved ice, palm sugar, coconut milk, pandang, and other goodies like fresh fruit.
Not that many places serve it or serve it well, so when I saw a long line here, I thought it must be amazing.
It was good, but not mind blowing.
The service is quick, and the portions are big.
It's one of the more popular Malaysian food stalls at Changi Village Market & Food Centre.
Aside from that, though, I have had better Chendol.
It will hit the spot if you've got a serious craving nonetheless.
It's a smaller stall within a larger Malaysian food stall.
Chendol is a desert.
Coconut milk.
Coconut 'sugar' or colloquially known as gula Melaka.
Shaved ice.
It's 2 bucks a serving!!
What a bargain.
;)) Basically, what this is is a little bit of food orgasm in your mouth.
The combinations of authentic gula Melaka and coconut milk and other ingredients makes this such a wonderful desert.
I have friends who drive from distances to have this.
Amazing!!
Have been a favorite of mine for years and I suspect will continue to be so.
Just wish I didn't know the caloric count on this :pp Ps.
The kuehs or nonya cake is also very good.
Very well made
What an amazing place!
Just off the shopping Malls of JB and You are in a mini oasis.
Incense burns on the counter offering a sweet smell to the gods of liquor as you swig away crude and yet oddly refined glasses of fermented coconut from tiger beer glasses.
I love it.

The shop was a flurry of activity on a Saturday afternoon - there was a queue in front of a lady standing at a rack of assorted pastries, another behind the lady solely in charge of doling out tau sar piah, and a third one at the cashier's.
People were outside the shop working on adding the finishing touches to mooncakes whilst surrounded by trays of bean paste fillings that had been laid out to cool.
It was a little chaotic, but everyone seemed to know what they were doing.

As I made my way around trying to make sense of the way things were ran, a frazzled looking man emerged from the kitchen holding a tray of newborn mooncakes, moving swiftly to slot it into one of the holding racks outside the shop.
What I loved about this shop was how unabashedly Teochew it was.
I know this is Hougang and I know we're talkin' old school bakery here, but I was still caught off guard by the aunties speaking to me in dialect.
Dude... that almost never happens in Singapore.
The aunties didn't even seem to register my surprise, like it never crossed their minds that I might not be able to understand what they were saying.
I was very pleased to be considered one of them.
Never mind that I actually am.
I then proceeded to flex my, ahem, linguistic muscles by replying in Teochew.
A little stilted due to years of non-use, but perfectly comprehensible, if I may say so myself.
Cue tears of pride and joy.
Tau sar piah, $20.80 for a box of 10 - For all the humble and homely qualities that Soo Teck Lim so effortlessly embodies, it must be said that their pastries don't come cheap.
At a little over $2.00 per piece (assuming you buy a box of 10), the price point places the tau sar piah here as one of the most expensive I've come across.

Don't be a wuss and let that stop you; just think about how illogical it would be to willingly fork out $4.00 for that ridiculously tiny lavender bundt cake from Carpenter & Cook yet refuse to part with $2.00 for a notoriously hard to make tau sar piah.
I got a mix of flavours for the 10 tau sar piah: Salty, sweet, pineapple and black sesame.
Those flavours are listed in order of preference, post-tasting.
Let's start with the not-as-good.
Notice I didn't say not-so-good.
That's because all the tau sar piah were, objectively speaking, brilliant.
In spite of the conspicuous absence of lard in their Teochew pastries - I'm sure you see the word vegetarian in the shop name right - the tau sar piah crusts were both flaky and crisp.
I didn't take very well to the black sesame flavour because it was quite peppery (??
), and I would've preferred a pineapple filling with a chunkier texture as opposed to the smooth jam that was used here.
The sweet and salty flavours were, on the other hand, faultless.
The sugar level in the bean paste used for the sweet tau sar piah was nicely reined in, allowing for the texture of the freshly and finely ground bean paste to shine.
As for the salty tau sar piah, the crumbly mung bean filling with its subtle notes of five spice powder and just the slightest dash of pepper, was so, friggin', amazing.
Teochew yam mooncake, $11.30 each - The yam mooncake here was decent though not mindblowing.
The filling, in line with Soo Teck Lim's philosophy of keeping things "not so sweet" (it's even printed on their paper bags), was where the absence of lard was keenly felt.
It was devoid of the depth of flavour that the Eater Palace mooncakes possess, what with the latter's shallot-y orh nee fillings.
Crust-wise it didn't fare so well either.
Truth be told I was expecting quite a lot more for an eleven-dollar mooncake, but I suppose they've done as well as they can for vegetarian mooncakes.
As you can tell I am a firm believer of the necessity of meat in one's diet.
Would I go so far as to call the tau sar piah sold here the best tau sar piah in Singapore?
I'd argue that it's definitely up there with the big boys in the Balestier area, but returning to Soo Teck Lim isn't going to stop me from craving the buttery tau sar piah from Loong Fatt.
Them's apples and oranges, and sometimes a pig just wants to have it all.
Everyone loves chocolate including yours truly especially when presenting it as a gift for a special someone.
Chocolate come in various qualities depending on the brand.
Luxurious brand of chocolates provides greater satisfaction in consumption due to good quality ingredients used.
However, cheaper brands can still hold their own weight in giving reasonable quality of taste.
There is a shop called 'Red Hot Deal Chocolate Sale' that offers competitive prices for any brand of chocolate that can be easy on the wallet.
The place lacks the frills of a stylish store selling good quality chocolates.
Instead, the shop comprises of a decent cashier counter and product displays surrounded by four blank walls.
However, its plain setting doesn't reflect the quality of the chocolates on sale because most of the brands are top notch.
Anyone can get good quality chocolates on a budget at this store as a treat or gift.
Red Hot Deal Chocolate Sale's opening hours: 10am - 9:30pm.
A typical Asian bread bakery with the addition of cakes, fresh lava cheese tarts, and freshly made waffles as well!
Review is based on lava cheese tarts and waffles :) I've never had their breads before but people seem to buy them often from what I've seen.
Definitely part of the fad of cheese tarts here in Singapore and Prima deli does a decent job at them.
Lava cheese tart original flavor is tasty.
Not overly sweet.
I've tried them warm as well as cold and both are good.
They are $2.40 which is pricey but around the normal for cheese tarts that I've seen around Singapore.
They make waffles right in front of you and have many waffle irons.
They actually are so fresh they smell up the first floor with a good smell.
I like their plain is my favorite.
But they have peanut, kaya, chocolate, etc.
Their plain waffle is $1.40.
Gin Thye's website has this opening statement: Few things bring people together like good food.
Yelp should become friends with Gin Thye.
Whenever I walk past this bakery, it's the aroma of waffles that makes my head turn.
At peak periods there's always a tiny queue - usually made up of students - they know that a mean waffle equals to a fluffy yet crispy waffle, generous heavy filling, and has to come CHEAP.
A heartwarming waffle like that can make a tired student's day.

The location's at the blocks of HDB flats next to Bishan Junction 8, it's one of the more prominent bakeries, look for the one with the waffle station on the left, though it has a sign attached to it saying: 'WAFFLES MAKE THE OTHER SIDE'.
Gin Thye is good at their cakes, after all they've been making it since the year 1964.
You can pre-order cakes from them for various occasions.
