The name Emicakes has always sounded really cute to me.
I usually drop by the Plaza Singapura outlet for some mini desserts.
I really like how their mini desserts and cakes are served in plastic cups; really cute and innovative.
Last year, my friend ordered a really gigantic chocolate cake (fit for 35 to 40 people) called Ultimate Brownie Addiction and it was absolutely delicious.
It stays true to its name with a brownie-like texture that is rich in chocolate goodness.
Products at Emicakes are neither cheap nor pricey, with mini delights that go from $2 onwards.
For the mini desserts, the eggless mint chocolate is my favourite because it's both healthy and moderately minty.
If you like the lovely combination of mint and chocolate, then you have to try their mint choco items here.
I've tried the D24 Durian Delight here but it's not really up to my liking.
The durian puree inside is a tad too sweet and the pudding cream doesn't really burst with durian flavour.
If you need something more durian-y then try their durian puffs, which have authentic and chunky durian filling.
If you don't want to pay for all the attractions on Sentosa, there isn't so much you can do.
We took a break at Tastes of Asia, and it was nice to stop for a cool dessert.
The place was completely dead around 5 pm on December 26th though, so it was kind of eerie sitting in a huge restaurant with only one other table filled.
The chendol for 3.00 was delicious, shaved ice with red bean jelly, coconut milk and palm sugar syrup.
The chng tng (cold) was also very good, with dry longan broth with barley, white fungus, jelly, ginko nuts, and rice pearls.
Both desserts were really sweet though.
I felt sorry for the young staff, who tried to look busy in the empty restaurant.
There were about 4 servers with not much to do, so they kept walking by our table to ask if everything was ok.
Normally that would have bugged me, but I let it pass this time so it would give them something to do.
Actually, they probably could have cleaned the restaurant better, but perhaps they couldn't do it in front of customers.
A dried piece of rice fell from the top of the booth when we sat down, which was kind of weird and also disgusting.
Big chunks of fried chickens.
That's what you'll get here in Texas Chicken.
I got a 2 piece spicy chicken meal and a dessert, which consist of a honey biscuit and a scoop of vanilla ice-cream, drizzled with chocolate sauce.
NOTE TO SELF: Next time, just get a one piece chicken meal!
This outlet is quite cram if you ask me.
The ordering counter is right at the entrance.
You will need to go through a small corridor at the side to get to the back where all the seats are located.
I have seen other Texas outlets, but this one was quite reclusive in a way.
Most of the seats at the other outlets are opened to the public eye.
Taste wise...
I don't know.
I personally feel KFC is still the best where fast food / fried chicken franchise in Singapore is concern.
Although, one thing I felt they succeeded in ousting KFC is their soft honey biscuits.
They taste so much better.
Kinara at Holland V is an Indian restaurant that's been around here for ages.
Food is not cheap, but its very good.
Service is great and you can chose to eat indoors or outdoors.
We opted for outdoors, and it's nice to people watch while having your meal.
We ordered a lot of food, but it was all so great we finished almost all of it.
The tandoori fish was very good, as was the palak paneer.
The buttered naan was also really great.
Again its not a cheap and you can get cheaper Indian food for the same quality elsewhere, but it is a nice splurge for Indian food, if you want to dine a bit classier.
At Mumbai Magic, for $12 you get the Mumbai Magic thali, with a free flow of rice, chapati, dishes for them, buttermilk and dessert (cardamon milk when we were there).
My partner's Indian colleague says the food here reminds her of home cooking.
Make of that what you will.
As for my evaluation, some of the dishes were very good, some were good and some were okay, but all were unlimited and it was only $12.
Oh, this restaurant only serves vegetarian food, but hey you can't have everything.
We also tried some other drinks on top of what was included (for one because butter milk is an acquired taste, but mainly because I'm greedy).
The badam milk was not that sweet, and the nut taste was alright - not as strong as I'd expected.
However the mango lassi was super concentrated and thick and had a great mango taste .
Both were only $4; this restaurant is a steal!
Sher Indian Garden is the Indian stall inside Bar Bar Blacksheep on Bukit Timah Road.
Like the Thai stall, it is also pretty pricey for a food stall, but it is also very good.
One of the best Indian places in Singapore.
They sell mostly Northern Indian cuisine like naan, briyani, curries and tandoori.
Their butter naan is amazing and their curries are so flavourful and tasty.
The staff is very nice and service is very fast and reliable.
Ok, it' me ranting again, and even though I'm going get shouted down by the fans of Sher, but the truth, my truth, must out.

In a landscape of outstanding Indian cuisine, especially southern indian cuisine, which by the way is uniquely ubiquitous in Singapore by sheer coincidence of immigration, Sher must in my book be given a single star.
The food if considered on it's own merits will likely get 3 stars, it is after all serviceable and edible and recognizable as Indian and even Northern Indian cuisine.

But placed in close physical proximity to Forture Seafood's Chili and Salt Egg Crab and Blu's unfettered awesomeness in the realm of Hellenic cuisine, Sher's 3 stars quickly fade into the one twinkling light in a night of big bright stars and streaking comets.
So it's not that Sher is bad, but that there are so many other better choices and so close by that Sher is certainly a one star choice in such august company.

This is really utility Northern Indian characterized by much the same pedestrian offerings that I associate with the all you can eat "Indian" restaurants of the Western Pennsylvanian heartland, which if you think about it is likely to be one of the only remaining places where Indian food can be considered "exotic" or "oriental".

There will certainly be a naan, which is a doughy bread-food, something dry, cordy and colored red and on the menu as a Tandoori Chicken, and usually something grossly cuboidal in a desultory green sauce passing as paneer.
In Youngstown as here at Sher, Indian is offered up almost as a Hobson's choice, this is what we've got and you can take it or leave it.
But unlike in Youngstown, you DO have a choice here, especially here in Singapore you are spoiled for choice!

And asserting your right to food that begins with a quality ingredient and is prepared to showcase just how important, fresh and awesome that ingredient is, is I believe your fundamental right as a human being, if not a Yelper!
Live Proud, ye Yelper, say no to mediocrity!
No Sher, not tonight, not any night, you and your one bright star can go softly into that good night.
We ate at this Indian buffet restaurant thanks to a 50% discount.
It was ok.
Nothing fantastic to shout about.
4 vegetarian dishes & 2 non-veg dishes + basmati + free flow of plain and garlic naan.
I liked the dessert which was typical of Indian dessert and was really sweet.
I don't know too much about Indian food, but they say in America if you see a Chinese restaurant patronized by Chinese then the food must be good.
In this case, on this day, this Indian restaurant was patronized mostly by Chinese.
Hock Lam Beef just opened up it's 4 outlet in SIngapore in Alexandra Retail Centre.
They are know for there 98 year old beef kway teow recipe in Singapore, which is handed down two generations since 1911.
The owner of the store was crowned Singapore's Beef noodle King in 2002.
Locals recognize the quality of the labour intensive, homemade 24-hour boiled gourmet soup, the homemade gourmet chilli sauce with 13 ingredients, and Hand sliced beef cuts.
Personally the soup and sauce has a complex lasting flavour, but the beef is ok only.
If you don't mind waiting in queue for 15 min, please visit between 12:15 and 13:30.
For fast food, the prices are a bit high.
As expected, the food is very greasy.
Although the crumb bits are tasty and the fish is decent, the overall experience is so-so.
You might only come here if you are specifically craving for it or if you have vague memories of long lost Long John Silver's from years ago in the US, where it is now all but extinct.
This Indian shop stands on its own and there are a few things I like about it.

1) Yummy biryani 2) Killer fried chicken 3) a few choices of not the oiliest vegetables 4) affordable 5) good teh tarik 6) strong fans 7) pleasant service 8) provides tissue at the cashier's Items 3, 4, 6 and 7 are why it wins out over the always crowded Shah Alam nearby.
I like the biryani rice which is cooked in the dum style.
Ie it's lightly fragrant and spiced and not flavoured from having poured curry gravy over it.
If it wasn't so unhealthy I would come more often but even when I've eaten elsewhere, I often stop here for a teh tarik!
How can you ignore these pastries.
Tai Sar Piah .
also known as bean paste biscuits, similar to filfipino hoopia, except thinner.
This joint is a one of the best where I tasted these pastry.
It was done in very traditional way and they offer sweet and salty flavors.
A good snack on the go or for breakfast with coffee.
They are also cheap from SGD.60 to SGD.80.
Or you can buy it for 3 for SGD 1.00 .
Thats a deal.
A must try in Singapore food scene and dont forget to take some with you.
Perfect late night food - greasy, spicy, cheap and quick!!
Wish there was a joint like this is San Francisco.
We had masala dosa, masala chai and plain parota - total bill $6.50 - beat that!
Really tasty Indian and mamak food right next to Mustafa.
The location also means you might pay slightly more for food, but this really only means $0.50 - $1 so the food is still great value.
We had a mutton set meal and a fish set meal.
Both portions were very generous and the fish was not as dry as you'd find in some places.
We asked for extra papadum and they obliged at no extra cost.
A big meal will cost you around $8-$9 per person here.
This used to be one of my favourite local curry puff brands, but like so many other popular brands, the skin tends to be doughy and oily instead of dry, crisp, and light.
The curry potato chicken filling is still of very good quality and flavour and worthy of 4-5 stars but the skin is an essential part and really disappoints and bring the whole rating down :-(
Coming from America, I thoroughly enjoyed this!
This was also the only exciting place in the entire terminal which was a little disappointing.
Curry Laksa was delicious and they added some extra spicy sauce which was the cherry on top.
Also, service was good!
I usually expect some eye rolls and rude tone because I'm not a native.
Only thing, wish their chicken was crispy
I was looking for a light snack before my flight and I love curry puffs, so happy that I found this place!
Their curry puffs are the best!
My favorite was the salty egg and beef rendang.
They were all good actually.
Not too bad price wise too!
I recommend buying a few before your flight and then some extra for your flight incase you get hungry.
I munched on these from my flight from Singapore to Japan to LA.
I have read slightly about Curry Times but never did I know that it is run by the our famous curry puff brand, Old Chang Kee.
I have always enjoyed the Old Chang Kee's curry puffs more so than Mackenzie's or Rolina's, not because of the pastry skin but it's spicy curry filling with a fiery kick.
But do not expect the same degree of heatiness from the Signature Curry Chicken ($7.90) here.
Designated as a healthier curry, this was made with fresh milk, not coconut milk.
Yet the consistency is not lost, creamy and fragrant with spices.
The tender flesh of the chicken drumstick added galore to simplicity, making this a comforting bowl to go with the traditional old-school Chinese "baguette".
In fact, one can have the curry along with rice or prata.
I was impressed by the hand-pressed Prata, which is crispy, light and airy.
I thought it heard the "Pa-Pa" sound just like its Chinese name 派派饼 as I teared apart the layers with ease.

I wanted something sweet but the Butter and Sugar ($1.90) was not an ideal choice for the slab of butter disintegrated into a pool of yellow oil in few seconds, not quite different from eating prata with oil.
The Sambal Petai ($6.90) sets itself apart from the usual as one can taste the gritty bits of Hae Bee in the chilli paste.
Perfect to go with a bowl of rice.
The Crispy Fish Cutlet Rice was delicious too; tender moist fish encased in a thin, golden-crisp shell.
The curry is served separately in another bowl thus non-spicy eaters can dig in without worry.
MUST TRY Buns!!
The buns made freshly in house are perhaps the softest buns I've ever had.

Struggling to carry the heavy filings, the dome-shaped virtually collapsed and lost its shape the moment it was split into halves to reveal the filling, an indication of delicateness and the sheer amount of filling.
The curry version wasn't spicy too and the coconut version was aromatic but too sweet.
And the ending for a curry-licious meal?
Traditionally Asian style desserts of chendol and bur bur cha cha.
Thanks to an article shared on social media recently, this place was made known.
Hawker fares and great food are what Punggol residents have been yearning for for years.
There is no centralized hawker centers but scattered coffee shops and food court all over made tracking good food difficult.
However, this Hokkien is a pure delight to residents here.
It is prepared by the distinct looking 70 year old uncle.
Kudos to him because opening hours start from 11am to 11pm.
He takes a break between 2-5pm.
It's no easy feat, plus it's opened on most days of the week.
This hokkien mee is sure not to be missed if you like the wetter version.
This is really wet, stock is really flavorful and it really combines very well with the noodles.
The wok hei (wok taste) is also very much apparent, yet not overpowering (which could make it tastes like chao tah (burned).
Very light and comforting wok hei.
That takes skills man!
Chilli is the light orange kind of color.
I'm not sure if they make their own chilli or get it from a supplier, but the chilli is well made, well blended to the noodles and has a kick.
The lime, the chilli and the noodles are a very good combination.
Queues can be long on the weekends and during lunch.
Do try it after 7pm or for a supper.
The let down is probably the food court's ventilation isn't very good and it can get pretty stuffy even in the night.
This is pretty near my place an usually after football on Sundays, I'll drop by Alina's for lunch before heading home.
The food is what draws me back there almost every week.
They serve nasi padang, seafood and prata as well.
Some of the dishes I usually order are the beef rendang and curry chicken.
The service there is also pretty good.
I would recommend this place for quick and affordable lunches/dinners if you;re around the bedok south area and craving some decent malay food.
This is a great place to have late meals.
As far as I know it never closes, so be it after a night out, a sports match, or if your simply feeling peckish at home, this is a great place for you!
For those residing in the East, Alina's Kitchen is conveniently located on Bedok South Avenue 3.
The Roti Prata comes at very reasonable prices and is of the best quality.
The service is great as well, very friendly people!
If you come late enough you will be able to park your car just on the side of the road, the Traffic Police won't bother you at all.
Its a nice atmosphere, a very light ambiance, fantastic for a quick meal, or hang out with friends.
Discovered this place whenever I was having supper around the area.
I was passing-by and saw a banner saying drinks at a low price.
One day (2 months later), I decided to give this pace a try.
What the banner says was really true, low priced drinks.
3 Heineken for S$13.
Certain bottled liquors were cheaper then most places.
Look at the drink/wine list for the prices.
Food wise were quite good.
But I was there for their cheap drinks....
The staff are friendly & quite attentive.
Overall, it's a good place to chill out without burning a hole in the wallet.
Definitely will drop by next time.
Peck is a sort of gourmet bakery in the heart of the city with very affordable prices for very good snacks.
There's a lot on show, but there are always a few I go back to.
My favourite would be a ciabatta filled with bacon and cheese.
The bun is crispy on the outside yet pillow soft on the inside, and we all know what combination bacon and cheese is.

The slight chewiness of the bacon adds a great contrast in texture too, making this a good bite at all times, with a size large enough to have for breakfast (which I do on many occasions - it still tastes great the morning after if you run it through the oven).
Another undeniably good item is their peach pastry, the pastry having a perfectly crisp croissant-like texture, the custard and peach combination again a winning one, despite not being outstanding.
A most delicious fruit pastry if I've ever had one.

I've also had their calzone with sausage and mushrooms and peppers in it, which is very hearty and filling - they are very generous with their ingredients - but I'm not the biggest fan of peppers, and the calzone for me tastes a little too chewy for my liking, especially when you don't pick this up fresh from the oven.
Overall, such good value!!
Just like all the other BreadTalks, but it's a refreshingly cheap option for i12 Katong Mall.
In a place where most things are pricey, and a bit fancier and upmarket than Katong is used to, BreadTalk keeps things casual.
You can tell by the pretty long queues that Katong people are all just heartlanders by heart; we don't need to fancy malls or expensive pastries found throughout the mall.
I like how BreadTalk is one of the first things that you encounter when you head into the main entrance.
It's just where Awfully Chocolate used to be before all the renovation took place!
Of course, as with all BreadTalks there are always new things with strange, funny names for a couple of bucks; it's no different here.
There's quite a bit to explore on Katong Mall so grab a bun of sorts on your way in and go explore the rest of the mall, laughing at how you're eating for cheaper than everyone else.
:P
think this bakery deserves 4 star since i like it so much i had it 3 days in a row!
do not be deceived by how old and unfurnished this place looks, its really just a fuss free bakery.
order and go.
e loaf of white bread i had was really soft and with every bite, keeps you wanting more BUT its only as good as it taste for about 24 hours.
not as nice after a day.
try to have it within e day.
1. pick e kind of bread you want.

2. choose from e 4 kinds of spread they have (butter, peanut butter, green kaya, orange kaya) 3. they will spread it on e spot for you 4. pack and go im not sure what the opening hours are, e lady who was serving me couldnt really give me a time which is really odd.
good thing was when i went there at 8am they were already open and when i went there again at 7pm its still open!

*rap to e tune sir mix a lot ~ baby got back* i like soft white bread and i cannot lie you other yelpers cant deny that when a loaf of bread comes out from e bake and e smells goes to your face you get high /end
SwissBake is founded by a true Swiss Mr Xavier Baumgartner who has been a pastry chef for more than 30 years, winning numerous awards in his pursuit of culinary excellence.
A couple of years later there are now more than 20 cafes, retail outlets and bread corners across Singapore.
Bread Corners are always located within a Cold Storage and this one is located in the Holland Village Cold Storage, you can miss it because it's right next to the entrance.
They have a large variety of pastries (my favorite is the apricot croissant), breads and a few cakes.
You can also order cakes from them if the selection doesn't suit you.
Swissbake is really the only place to buy good european bread in Holland Village.
They are freshly baked in the morning and if you come early they are still warm.
Baguette's they back throughout the day.
At the end of the day most breads go on discount.
Vegetarian bakery in Fortune Centre, with a wide range of freshly baked breads, cakes, cookies.
I like how everything is marked if it has eggs in it (or not).
Items with cheese are self-explanatory.
I don't like their cakes because I bought a slab of banana cake here and found it to be chock-full of banana flavoring.
I do however love their pumpkin buns, made with pumpkin bread and pumpkin mash without any added sugar.
This bakery is for people who are vegetarian not for health reasons, but perhaps religion reasons.
After having dinner, my friends and i wanted to hang out more.
So we went to plaza singapura to search for dessert.
We came upon Ji De Chi.
As there is 7 of us, we waited quite long for the seat.
We placed our order and dessert is served shortly.
I ordered mango strawberry flavour snow ice.
It does not reflect the image in the menu.
Tasted pretty alright.
My friend ordered mocca flavour, and to my surprised, it was way better than what i expected from it.
When we were eating halfway, waitress came and hurry us off.
She said they were closing.
We were pretty upset over it.
How does she expect us to finish our dessert 10mins.
Moment later, another waitress came over and asked us to finish off our dessert.
In the first place, the waitress should have warned us about the closing time.
If not, we won't enter into the dessert stall.
Afterall, this is rather a bad experience for me.
Fish & Co has been in Singapore for as long as I can remember.
But haven't been back since my college days, when we would go to the Fish & Co glasshouse!
They have expanded their menu to cater to the health conscious, they even have a menu for 500 calories and under!
They jumped on the "high-tech" wagon and now hand customers an iPad so that the customers do the ordering themselves.
Sadly, as someone who is familiar with UX best practicies.
This user-interface needs some work.
It requires alot of drill down to get your specific order done and the only way to get back to the main menu, is to drill back up.
The table we were seated at was meant for 12 and it was a square shaped, rather a long table whereby people on both ends can't even see each other.
For a weekday lunch hour, it wasn't packed, in fact, it wasn't even half full, in comparison to swensens on the other side of NEX, which would have a snaking queue outside.
Both serve similar western fares for about $20 (after GST + service charge) with main course and ice cream desserts.
Grilled White Fish with Ebiko $16.95++ Instead of the typical fried fish and chips, I tried to go with something "healthier", or at least I was convincing myself that it was indeed healthier.
The fish tasted okay, nothing special.
The grilled cheesey topping with the ebiko was nice, although the ebiko had a dark orange exterior and was definitely frozen for a long time.
The sides were beancurd and coleslaw.
I loved the coleslaw as it had raisins in it!
I was very full from this main course alone!
Clam Chowder soup Somehow they forgot to serve everyone their soup, so after I was done with my main course, they served me the soup.
Which I barely finished.
It was thick, didn't taste like it was straight out of a can.
Nothing great, nothing bad.
Tiramisu ice cream I was almost at my limit after the soup and here comes the ice cream!
There was only one flavour, tiramisu.
It had nuts in it and it tasted like the normal king's ice cream.
The lunch menu also came with a drink which I had an earl grey tea, you can pick fizzy drinks as well.
Now I know why people flock to swensen's for lunch instead.
You get so much more value there, especially if you order a sundae.
However, here at Fish & Co, you do get a drink and a soup as well.
If you are a roti prata lover and have been searching for healthier prata, this is it!
The prata chef does not add extra oil into the making of the prata and he does not fry it.
He toast it until it's cooked.
So it's not oily when you eat them.
And they are so delicious!
The dal & curry sauce are yummy!
And you have to try their vadai (Indian donut).
They are super yummy - crunchy on the outside and soft on the inside and yes, not oily too!!
I don't feel that I need a major workout after eating it!
Most of all, the couple that works on their food are super friendly and helpful.
The chef took his time to explain how he made it such that his food are healthy and not oily.
I'm definitely bringing more friends there!
Hairloom de Jardin is a unique two-in-one shop - with one side being a cafe (Cafe de Jardin) and the other side being a hairdressing saloon (Hairloom de Jardin).
While I have yet to patronize the saloon, I love the decor of the cafe.
The whole place is filled with an eclectic mix of furniture and accessories - very Alice in Wonderland Tea Party kind of feeling.
They sell mainly cafe food: pasta, salads, sandwiches and drinks (both hot and cold).
The food is nothing spectacular although edible.
I do quite like their yakult soda drink though.
Go for the atmosphere, not for the food.
65-6295 2088 (Hairloom) 65-6295 2188 (Cafe de Jardin)
I love these Chinese desserts.must try whenever you are in town.
Located almost everywhere.
The mango w sago is popular.Not too sweet and made just right.
Um.
Supposed to be an icy soup not just completely frozen.
Even the ice cream seems icy like it's been sitting in a freezer for a long time.
This particular location is not up to the usual standards.
The staff doesn't understand me.
Bengawan Solo at Nex offers some local dessert treats as well as some lovely cream cakes.
Although staff here always seems "busy" and queues might be a little long sometimes, they sure make some decent tasting kuehs.
The Bingka Ubi (Baked Tapioca) is soft yet chewy while the Talam Hijau boasts a nice blend of pandan, coconut milk and orange sugar.
My favourites from Bengawan Solo are the kueh lapis, which come in plain, prune and cranberry.
Prune and cranberry are absolutely lovely mainly because I generally love both fruits.
The lapis cakes are really soft.
Kuehs are generally not overtly sweet so if you're looking to fill your sweet tooth craving, try their cream cakes instead.
I love their mango and pandan kaya cakes.
The former bursts with mango cream and small chunks of fruit while the latter further highlights just how tasty the marriage is between pandan and kaya.
This store is in the canteen on 9th level of SKYTECH, Blk 2 Bukit Batok Industrial Park A building.
The store used to be in Bukit Batok Community Centre, which now shifted to this place.
I only come here when I'm nearby this area and best is that they open everyday till 5pm.
What I most like about are their Roast Pork and Duck.
The roast porks' skin is roasted to a perfect crispy skin which you can hear the crunchiness while biting it.
The meat has just the right thickness of lean meat, fat & skin...yummy to my liking.
(If you are there late afternoon, they usually run out of the roast pork & Duck) I've not tried their Roast Duck yet, but looks delicious hanging at the glass casing.
I will definitely come by when I'm craving for crispy pork... Oh yes, I forgot about their Char Siew.....it's so so only but still okay for a combo meat orders.
Burrppp...
Cheers.
Asam Laksa has taken its spot over the Western Stall in West Coast Square.
It was kind of mix feelings as on one hand I was sad to hear that there are only 1 option left for western food but on the other hand I was quite happy to see this unique stall out there.
Asam Laksa is a chain stalls with staff in uniform.
Hygiene is well taken care of over here with friendly servers wearing hair net.
Asam Laksa - $3.50 Noodles were thick and springy, soaking up the delicious gravy and made the bowl of Asam Laksa so appetizing.
Ingredients like pineapple and large chunks of fish were given in the serving.
Apparently, there is only 1 standard size served at $3.50.
Serving was small and it will be better if it was served in bigger size at the same cost.
Nice tangy asam and soft slurppy noodles.
I like the tangy base, with the opinions and fresh veg it adds a dimension to noodles, like the way Vietnamese Pho brings to our local palate.
Nice addition to the local scene.
One of the best roasted pork noodles I have eaten in a hawker centre.
The meat was fleshy and the noodles were cooked in Hong Kong style.
At $3.50 a plate, it was very value for money.
There were plenty of condiments/sauces at the side so you could add as much or as little as you like.
The char siew rice was not as great though.
The char siew slices were rather hard.
Nevertheless, I would definitely return for the roasted pork noodles.
Fei Zai Fried Kway Teow is a relatively new stall in the S11 Coffeeshop right next to Bukit's Batok Interchange.
This stall has been featured in the Singapore Food Map and has received award.
Beside Char Kway Teow, this stall sells other popular Singapore delights like Fried Hokkien Prawn Noodle and Carrot Cake.
Fried Kway Teow - $3.50 Char Kway Teow is moist, smooth and sweet with adequate amount of black sauce coated on it.
It has generous amount of bean sprouts and smell of wok flavour.
Even though the portion is of right size to the price that I'm paying for, such delicacy is still addictive and leave me wanting for more when I have cleared the plate.
Food is cook upon order, thus ensure the freshness and heat on these scrumptious delights.
Not the best kway chap around, but possible the only one around this neighborhood.
The kway is not thin as the best out there, the meats not as flavorful.
It is ok only lah.
Andhra Curry is located next to Clover Springs at of the Comtech foodcourt on level 1 / basement / same level as the carpark.
There are 2 Indian stalls at the Comtech, but this one is vegetarian and the other one is not.
That's about the only difference.
Comtech has a large indian working population and they form around 30% of the diners at the foodcourt.
Since there are only 2 stalls and Indians do like to eat Indian food, you can guess the queues are pretty long.
And because of the laid back Indian attitude they don't really move fast, but nobody cares, I guess that's a good thing :) People behind the counter are friendly and patient.
Plenty of choice of over 10 dishes and they never run out of something.
Sometimes you just crave for Indian flavors or having a large plate of biryani rice.
They won't let you down.
The veggie somosas are great!
The molikofta is very good .
The saag paneer is boring and bland.
I  have to give up on saag in this country.
This stall is an extremely popular stall among the Indian, Chinese and Malay population in NTU despite it being an Indian stall.
Their hot favorite is their naan, prata and biryani.
I actually enjoy all 3 dishes from them.
The curry is pretty standard and not too spicy.
But if were to pick one of my favorite, I've got to say that it's the prata.
The prata is more of the soft and flaky type rather than the crispy type you see at Prata House (thomson).
Queue wise, this stall has a really really long queue that extends even to the food stall behind.
Their service is pretty fast as most of their food is already precooked (yes that includes their prata, so you have to be lucky to receive prata from a fresh batch).
I think this is the first time I've started a listing for a casual dining establishment because it was so...bad.
Without intellectualizing the whole rationale of starting a business, I am always supportive of small business owners, especially local ones trying out new concepts in Singapore.

I've yet to come across a savory waffle chain here and I do love a mean fried chicken and waffles from my days in Virginia; so when the dude said he saw a row of waffle pans as we were waiting for our soft shell crab po boy at another shop, we were game on.
Well here's what happened.
First, there is nothing gourmet about the food at Griddy.
The waffle batter is similar to the stuff you get at a cheap neighborhood bakery where the grouchy aunty splats on dollops of sweet peanut butter for $1.20.
The fish fillet that was stuffed in my Ocean Catch sandwich was caught in the ocean via the delicious factory flash frozen route.
Just putting it out there because when I paid $5.90 for what I thought was gourmet fast food, I was left debating with the dude which part of our meal was refined.
Now we are simple people.
We ordered an Ocean Catch sandwich as mentioned and an ice lemon tea.
Going with the aforementioned theme, my tea came first and it was of the syrup variety.
Our waffle arrived and I took the picture you see on this review.
Sliced it in half and oh...the waffle wasn't cooked through.
The batter was still mushy and was slopping onto the plate.
We sent it back and pointed out the problem.
The "corrected" sandwich arrived and I guess they solved the undercooked waffle problem...by really browning it on the outside?
When I sliced this sandwich in half, I realized the fish meat looked barely cooked in some sections.
So what did I do with a sandwich I've already paid for and sent back once?
I picked the wilted lettuce leaves out, ate the slices of tomato, bits of cooked fish and the waffle.
To conclude, this is really a quick service joint aimed at students who with too much pocket money and weened on corn syrup, with a kitchen run by students and no quality control.
If you ARE a student, I'd suggest going to Coronation plaza or something for fool proof excellent after school food.
Otherwise, we had far better food elsewhere in the area (Isetan, meticulously assembled (I wouldn't call 'em) po boys).
Ordered the Mix platter that came with bacon, chicken chop, beef patty, egg and waffle fries.
Hawaiian waffle burger, $8.90.
Followed by blueberry cheesecake waffle as dessert.
Blueberry cheesecake ice cream tastes so-so, no cheesecake texture/taste.
The food was really good tho, except price didn't include GST and service charge so it summed up to be pretty pricey.
About $35 for 2.
Service was really nice and friendly!
Pleasant trip!
Operated by the Select Catering people.
Decent edible fancy food?
An attractive alternative for kids, probably looks good enough for IG.
Taste average, quality average, pricing above average for average but interesting food.
Ok to try, but I doubt anyone would fall in love.
Probably good ideas for trying variations at home.
Not Too Greedy for Griddy's Griddy's really caught my eye when I first walked by.
Since waffle town, I haven't seen a restaurant fully dedicate itself to specializing in Waffles and fried chicken.
It's one of those comfort, sinful food that we've all heard in stereotypical Hollywood movies but after having a taste, you know what all the fuss is about.
Located at the basement of Westgate, Griddy was filled with students.
Essentially because their price was pretty reasonable and the fact that it's the ultimate junk food.
Looking at the menu, I was excited by the local flair they added to it.
I imagined the sweetness of the waffles, mixed with the savory fried chicken, topped with its luscious sweet and salty laksa sauces.
Unfortunately.......
It was all part of my imagination.
Battered Chicken with Waffles topped with  Laksa Sauce.
It all tasted very one dimensional.
The laksa sauce wasn't fragrant or sweet while the chicken was well...... A piece of fried chicken.
On top of that, the waffles lacked that crispiness and sweetness that we've all come to enjoy soon a whole, the dish didn't come quite come together for me.
It felt a lot like those great dishes you thought of when you were a kid, only to put it together and having it fall short of your expectations.
Mid Wings with Salted Egg Sauce and Laksa sauce.
Sadly, another let down for us.
The midpoints were small, cooked till a little dry and while the laksa sauce was again lacking any form of a pinch, the salted egg sauce was an even bigger disappointment.
It was thin, lacking flavour and tasted like a yellow sauce with a hint of salted egg yolk in stead of being A SALTED EGG sauce.
Spaghetti with Grilled chicken and salted egg sauce.
This dish was well...... Meh.
Pasta a bit overcooked and blend, chicken was grilled beyond grilled and to top it off, it came with the same diluted salted egg sauce as the chicken wings.
Overall?
Highly disappointing.
If this was meant to be soul food made locals than....
I'm afraid I may have just lost my soul.
This is the express dining version of the Sankranti Group of restaurants.
Most of the seating are outdoors and they only have a small kitchen for the preparation of food.
Thus, do not expect the type of variety you have from the other Sankranti branches in Singapore.
However, it is good enough for a nice meal - whether you are craving for naan, thosai or rice with a few dishes.
The restaurant serves mainly Southern Indian food and can be quite spicy for people with a weaker stomach who nonetheless love Indian food (like me).
Their milk tea is also nicely done, and very good to calm a raging stomach (from the spiciness).
During lunch and dinner, be prepared to wait a bit for your food as they have limited manpower (I only saw max.
2 people preparing food at any one time).
PRICE: OKAY $4 each for the Mee Goreng & Nasi Goreng Ikan Bilis which is okay for me because the serving is quite large but there is no form of meat in the two dishes i ordered.
Drinks are pricey.
$2 for iced milo.
ATMOSPHERE: OKAY A little cramp because the tables are very close to one another and there a couple of flies here and there but otherwise okay.
FOOD: NOT BAD The portion was very filling and the food smelt really good & taste was great!
Not alot of ingredients though, only vegetables, egg and the carbohydrate for the dish.
No fancy seafood / meat / fish.
OVERALL: OKAY Might come back if i feel like eating something different from what i usually eat.
But the queue during lunch time is long so do be prepared to wait about 20min for your food!
This is one of my favorite Indian eateries in Singapore.
I've tried multiple things on their menu and it's all good.
The mutton curry is one of my favorites, served with the biryani.
They are known for their prata, which is good, but they only serve it at certain hours of the day.
The place can be a bit intimidating if you don't know what you're asking for, but the food is laid out in front of you, and the staff are very receptive to pointing.
It's also the few places where I've walked in in Singapore, asked what they recommend, and get a very straight response.
Basically they just started piling my plate up with food.
This place isn't fancy, but there are usually open tables, and it's air conditioned.
You can get a great meal and a drink for under $10.
This place is one of the few places that look clean and is air conditioned.
However, the food is sub par at best.
Got the dossa, it wasn't crispy and did not have much taste.
The 3 dipping sauces all tasted the same but were all different colors.
Maybe my palate isn't trained for it.
The mango lassi was cool, creamy, and refreshing.
Service was nice and efficient.
The place accepts credit cards but it's a 20 dollar minimum.
I was quite excited when one of my ex-colleague mentioned that there is a new eating place in Rail Mall that is worth a try out.
Springleaf prata is tuck in the quiet corner of the mall facing the abandoned railway tracks.
I came to realize its existence recently even though it was opened since last Novemeber, serving an extensive, unique and delicious Indian Cuisine in its menu.
In fact, this Halal Certified Indian food Chain has opened up one more food option to the Muslim pals staying nearby.
Drinks accompany our food will be none other than Teh O Limau Ice & Rose Syrup.
Teh-O-Liamau & Rose Syrup - $1.80 & $1.40 Being curious with alot of unfamiliar item out of the usual Indian Cuisine Menu, we ordered the Murtaburger which name sounds like Murtabak and Burger to me.
2013 Murta Burger - $7 Taste was amazing and I only come to know about that this is actually a good marriage of prata with our well-liked "Ramly Burger".
Ingredients include mutton patties, mayonnaise well hidden inside the usual squarish egg prata.
It was a moment of joy to see plenty of my favourite sticky mozzarella cheese while tearing up the prata.
Not only was it delicious,  its crispiness of the prata had make me feel delighted.
Filling up part of our stomach with Maggie Goreng that looks plain and uninteresting.

Taste wise, it was nothing out of the ordinary but the dish came with generous chunks of chicken cooked together with eggs, beansprouts and vegetables, couple with cucumber and chilli as appetizer on the side.
Maggie Goreng with Chicken - $5 $1.10 for a piece of prata?
What's the market rate nowadays given for the price from a air-conditioned shop in a mall?
I bet this pricing is relatively acceptable especially when its plain prata is so crispy and goes well with the curry gravy.
Yummy!
Plain Prata - $1.10 Service and food serving speed is acceptable.
With a few well known prata places in the vicinity.
the stood up among the rest with their specialties.
I forsee myself coming back for more.
Frolick is an yogurt ice cream stall.
According to my friends, it's famous for having hot girls manning the counters at their store.
Whether this is true or not, well, it's up to you to see and decide for yourself.
For me, I was just there to try out their yogurt ice cream as I was looking for guilt-free ice cream to munch on.. and yogurt ice cream seems to be it.
One thing that put me off was the price of the ice cream.
I gotta tell you, it's not exactly cheap (if you compare the price with say, Yami Yogurt which is $2.30 for the smallest cup).. even if you order the plain yogurt flavour.
Another issue I noted was that the ice cream melted pretty quickly...which was quite interesting since I was sitting in the stall munching on it.
However, one thing I give it credit for is the concept of the stalls which is very adorable and the taste of the yogurt ice cream.
There is just something addictive about its taste that makes it stand out a little bit from other stores.. but I can't quite put my finger on it.
Another thing that caught my attention was the adorable flowery marshmallows.. this was something new.. haha, definitely a store catered to ladies.
Hee Kee Desserts has been in operations recently after a long renovation period.
Ever since her novelty (a few days back), it had been drawing curious consumers' attention like me.
Thus, I quickly fixed a date with my pals to check out his Hong Kong desserts together.
Her interior design had displayed the style of a modern dessert cafe where you can find in Hong Kong.
Steamed Milk & bird-nest were seen as well, featuring those popular Hong kong Desserts.
Specializing in Hong Kong dessert, I would say that their variety is way lesser than its competitor which is located about 100m away, Ji De Chi (记得吃).
Perhaps the only starring item they had over them is its Custard Egg Yolk Rice Balls and Bird Nest Menu, other than that, the desserts items were very typical.
Sesame paste was a total letdown.
Firstly it was not warm enough then it was not that smooth and was rather watery.
A vast difference from what we had expected.
In the end we had almost the whole bowl left untouched.
This had caught the person In-Charge's attention and she had confronted us to take our feedback.
Service wise is still average and she had offered us for another bowl of dessert but we rejected.
Sesame Paste - $3.80 Mango sago with pamelo is top in my dessert list whenever I see them in the menu.
It was kind of disappointing when the pulps of pomelo tasted bitter and mango tasted raw.
Sweet taste is very lacking, it did not give the right punch into the stomach to someone who love such dessert.
Mango Sago with Pomelo - $4.50 Mango Sago with Pomelo and mango - $6.50 One of its signature desserts, Custard Egg Yolk Rice Ball in Osmanthus Soup.
Soup was not really warm with hints of ginger and Osmanthus smell was not very obvious or close to none.
Liu Sha Tang Yuen in Osmanthus Soup (Hot) - $3.80 The combination of the mushiness from glutinous rice balls with the sandy texture of Custard Egg Yolk did not appeal to me.
Perhaps this had marked my first and also the last trip to Hee Kee.
The replacement of Lucky Dessert Stall to Hee Kee doesn't really turn things out well.
Little Moo is going back to patronise Ji De Chi.
GOOD AIRPORT FOOD This is a nice little sit-down restaurant.
I had the Salmon Bento Box and, I must say, it's one of the best I've ever had.
Service - 4 stars Food - 4 stars Location - 4 stars Ambiance/Decor - 4 stars Don't leave a tip.
They automatically add in 10%.
got this through my lounge membership and was blown away by the set meal, grilled fish.
if you have the option just go here instead of another lounge.
staff is good and food delivered.
Nothing is worse than the feeling of utter regret as you're flying 40,000 feet above the ground after eating a greasy, fast-food meal.
That's why when I'm traveling, I prefer to eat food that is as simple and as "clean" as possible.
The Green Market, located on the 2nd floor of Terminal 2, fit the bill pretty well.
4/5 Ambience: The restaurant has a modern Japanese design that'll have Instagram gals/guys going gaga.
Eating there is also much more peaceful compared to the hubbub of the food court just down the hall.
3.5/5 Food: My first time stopping by, I ordered the chicken donburi.
It didn't taste anything remotely Japanese.
It was more like a bland version of a Hong Kong chicken clay pot dish.
My second time, I ordered the sashimi bento box and I liked that so much better.
It came with 6 slices of sashimi, rice, miso soup, fruit, okra, and salad.
Tbh, not the best sashimi I've had, but it was a simple and filling meal, so I left happy.
4/5 Service: Multi-lingual servers who are attentive but not intrusive.
Overall, definitely not the best Asian food I've ever had, but for airport food, it's not bad at all.
This is one of those moments I wish I had been boring.
I've been craving roti john from this place since coming here a couple of weeks back.
It was crispy, bread was fresh, egg was fluffy and meat was tasty.
Yum...
But then when I was about to order, I saw someone else's mutton chop, looking all glazy and rich... Mmm...
I wish I had stayed on the straight and narrow because it was very mediocre.
I was tempted to reduce this review to three stars.
But they're nice guys, and I haven't even tried their specialty yet - mee goreng.
So 4 stars for great roti john.
Next time, I'll be flipping between mee goreng and roti john.
Damn.
This has recently become my fav place to eat!
Love their noodle and dim sum items.
Dessert is good too!!
Definitely something for everyone.
This is a chain dessert and HK style food casual restaurant, several outlets around Singapore.
It serves wanton noodles, braised meat rice, fried carrot cake, fried dumplings, liu sha bao (salted egg yolk custard bunds) etc for proper food/snack.
It also the traditional HK desserts such as mango pomelo sago, peanut cream, black sesame cream, almond cream, glutinous rice balls in ginger soup....
I had the mango pomelo sago dessert which was refreshing and icy (shaved ice did not melt), perfect for a hot weather.
The mango cubes hit the spot.

Located at the end of Holland Village's main thoroughfare, Lorong Mambong, this particular branch of Coffee Club has a nice and relaxing ambience with mainly brown hues, and gives customers a choice of either the air-conditioned interior or outdoor al fresco area.
I spend more than 2 hours here every time I visit, either chatting away with friends or chilling with a book.
You can have your choice of coffee or tea here, but you definitely can't miss the dessert.
There's a good selection of cakes, gigantic macarons, and pastries and they come in generous portions.
Those with a sweet tooth will love it.
You can order main courses too, but I'm not a fan of the food at coffee houses.
It probably won't be bad, but if you're in the area you might as well check out the other bars and restaurant in Holland Village.
We walked through the mall after lunch to get to the other side of the street so we can get picked up by the company shuttle.
We walked by this fried food heaven and I couldn't help but salivate.
My colleague from Singapore, Linda said if I like spicy food then the potato puff is a must try.
Looked in my wallet.
I have cash.
Yes!!!
I ordered 1 but I should have ordered 2.
Think of a super spicy pork empanada or wonton-shaped Hot Pocket.
Hmmm, I haven't had a hot pocket in years but yeah.. if you cannot handle spicy then this item is not for you.
The potato and pork was puréed and I can see some bits of carrots in them.
I don't know what they used to make the shell red (food color, I am assuming) but overall this satisfied my hunger cravings and I was left wanting water and more.
It was spicy.
Definitely something I am looking to replicate at home.
This place is legit for muffin lovers.
If not, this place will win you over.
As the store name eludes to, Muf Muf specializes in freshly baked muffins.
They offer an enriching variety of muffins in terms of size (regular or mini) and flavors (i.e., sweet, savory, healthy, etc.).
Muffins are their core products but if you're in the mood for cheesecakes, they have a limited offerings of mini-cheesecake pans (think Chinese egg tarts).
Have not tried the cheesecakes but the muffins are delicious in flavor and texture.
Moist and yummy muffin tops making them great with a glass of milk or cup of Joe.
I grew up in the east, not far away from this shop, and my mom used to bring me here every now and then when she had to bake a cake.
Their comprehensive array of items is probably the reason I was infatuated with baking and became a pastry chef.
The shop is quite small, but they've maximised the space very well.
You can find things on display, literally, everywhere.
As you walk in you'll see pretty cupcake and soufflé cases above you.
They have everything from dry ingredients to sugar work tools and even favour packaging supplies.
They take up two units, but only one is fully accessible to customers - part of the other is used for storage.
Don't expect neat shelves of goods in this shop.
While most of the things are displayed prominently, you may have to dig a little deeper if you're looking for tools, tins or utensils.
If you want something specific, ask for help.
If you're not looking for anything specific, decide on something specific and ask for help.
You could probably get some goods cheaper here in comparison to the supermarket, but bear in mind this is a speciality shop so some prices are steep.
Generally, they charge more than Phoon Huat (baking-supplies chain with stores around the island) by a few ten cents.
Creations café is a small yet cosy café situated in the first level of Shaw Towers.
I have been patronizing this café since 2008 and i would strongly recommend all pasta lovers to try their pasta selection.
Their pasta selections ranges from the tomato based to the creamy based.
I personally do not take cream and can't comment much on that.
However, one seafood marinara is already enough to keep me coming back for years!
The seafood that they use are all very fresh and includes salmon, scallops and mussel.
Of course, choose your favourite pasta type to go with it.
For me, I definitely love their linguini the most.
The pricing of their menu is also considered value for money.
They serve set lunches (which comes with a main dish, a bowl of delicious soup & a drink of your choice) at $10.50 and dinner (with an additional dessert) at $15.90.
However, do avoid the busy lunch hours as you might have to wait 15-30mins to get a seat.
I didn't know about this place until a fellow Yelper mentioned about it.
As a busy person, I have no time to explore new places, and usually if I do, I spent my time overseas so since this came in my discussion with the other two Yelpers, we decided to try out this place.
This cafe is located at Shaw Leisure Gallery - I have no idea of this location until that day and you can find it easily as it's located near the entrance.
There were a few vacant tables so we were lucky to get a place.
We ordered set meals which consists of a soup, drink and our main course.
I had the Chicken Curry pasta and to be honest, it was average, I tasted better ones elsewhere.
As for the soup and garlic, I didn't like it.
So overall, I find this to be average, I can't give this more than 3 stars, I would give this 2 and a half stars if it's possible.
As for the service, it was ok.
Slow due to manpower shortage but the staff were polite.
Overall, nothing to shout about.
Located at Shaw Towers, it is another food place you can drop by before heading to Tom's Palette.
Came here with two Yelpers and we each ordered set A (drink + soup).
The three interesting dishes' flavors on the menu are seafood laksa cream sauce, chicken java curry sauce and seafood thai cream sauce?
(need to double check) and we have to choose the pasta types (Spaghetti, Linguine, Rotini).
You could also choose the drinks (lemon tea, sodas, etc).
After deciding on what each one of us wanted to try, we filled up our orders on a paper-based menu.
The drinks came first then our foods and lastly our respective orders.
Our orders came switched.
I wanted to order rotini with seafood thai cream sauce but it ended up with linguine.
Portion came bigger than expected for a reasonable price.
Verdict, among the three dishes I tried, I enjoyed what I ordered more.
The cream was lighter and it has the spicy and sour flavors in it.
Overall, I am glad that one of the Yelper recommended this place.
Affordable pricing and generous portion is getting rarer these days :)
As of May 2016, the Vivocity branch is having a promotion of $5 for each slice of cake.
I got the strawberry shortcake.
The cake box was very pretty.
The cake had fresh cream and just the right amount not to be overwhelming.
The sweetness was also just right and the strawberries were fresh.
I would be interested to try out the other cakes in future, if they taste as good as they look!
Now this, is my absolute favourite store for mooncakes during the mid-autumn festival season.
Having ordered this for more than 16 years consecutively (and still counting), I can vouch that the taste, quality and even size of the mooncakes remain largely consistent throughout the years.
The mooncakes come in traditional packaging of a plain white cardboard box with" (Tai Tong) printed in red on it.
None of those fancy artsy-fartsy designs that we see nowadays.
I know it may not be the best reasoning, but I like to think that the best stuff always come in the most basic of packaging.
Simply because they spend less on the gimmicks and more on the ingredients.
Once you sink your teeth into these mooncakes, you'll definitely know that it is really authentic and quality food.
The lotus paste is smooth and silky, so thick that it appears to be slightly chewy.
It provides an interesting texture that is a joy to chew and consume.
The baked skin is a rich brown that is thin yet strong enough to hold in the fillings and retain its shape.
The flavours become more distinct and fragrant the more you chew it, and sometimes, I leave the skin for last just so I can slowly savour its goodness.

After a hard day of shopping groceries and thinking about the cooking that has to be done once they get home, a lot of housewives and house husbands could not resist the temptation to take a breather at this small dessert shop.
They sell both traditional desserts like peanut soup, almond paste, tang yuan, etc and more innovative shaved ice dishes to appeal to the younger crowd.
They also have a small selection of traditional dim sum for those who are hungrier.
A nice, unpretentious place for afternoon tea and a nice chat with friends.
I had a taste of some soya food at a store called 'Jollibean' namely soya milk and pancakes.
Too bad, no soya jellybeans were in sight for me to sample but 'Jollibean' is usually known for its rich flavoured soya milk drinks.
The pancakes were delicious filled with peanuts and chocolate but no different from any other similar pancakes sold by competitors.
However, its soya milk seemed to be richer in taste unlike the diluted version found in neighbourhood drink stalls but on par with the ones from Mr Bean.
In any case, its drink served as good thirst quenchers especially for me being a soya milk fan since young.
However, I have cut back on its consumption recently due to some recent studies found.
Nevertheless, I do like to drink Jollibean soya drink on some occasion in moderation.
It's noteworthy that more food choices are available in Jollibean store than before.
I just hope that soya jellybeans are included as well to commemorate their namesake!
Then again, soya flavoured jellybeans may not be anyone's palate.
Jollibean's opening hours: 11am to 9pm.
It is ok.
Typical food court standard at best.
It gets quite busy at lunch time but I suspect it is because there is no fish soup choices anywhere around here.
Ample seating, so that is a plus.
Confession: I'm a durian addict.
Despite Singapore's humid temperament, I can't help but indulge in the King of Fruit ever so often.
Imagine my excitement when I saw Four Seasons Durians located on Level 3 at Nex.
Unfortunately, my hopes of getting a good Durian fix were extinguished far too soon.
Although the Durian Pancakes were reasonably packed with fresh Durian mix, the other products such as Durian Puff and Durian Crepe were mediocre at best.
(Of course when it comes to Durian crepes, nothing beats Angie The Choice's thick and generously filled Durian rolls!)
Most disappointing of all from Four Seasons Durians had to be the Durian Mochi, which came in a box of 4 pieces.
The Mochi skin was somewhat tasteless and stiff, with a bland Durian filling that made it almost impossible to enjoy.
Four Seasons Durian is not the best Durian food stall out there but at least prices are not too steep.
Durian lovers could definitely settle for better!
Located in East Point Mall, Curry Hopper immediately stands out because of its clean, bright look amidst the more homey feel of the rest of the mall.

A good crowd can be found on most nights, although it is probably novelty more than anything else that keeps people coming; the East is the perfect place for better, cheaper options of the same cuisine.
The menu isn't very extensive, and unlike most Indian restaurants, vegetarian options are not immediately apparent.
A quick check with the staff reveals that they often get requests for vegetarian options, which they easily provide.
The Mee Goreng with veggies and tofu is a good option; a generous serving of red chilli and lime add that zing to an already tasty dish.
Other options like prata and other Indian breads, however, are way too overpriced.
I'm not paying $6 for a prata, and I'm certainly not doing it in the East.
It might be worth checking out if you're looking for creative, meat-based Indian fusion.
The selection and variety of coffee here always leaves me spoilt for choice.
From Tarte Tatin Latte to Choco Stout Royale and more, it really leaves you lingering and wanting to try all those delicious flavours.
It is awesome that they keep their menu constantly updated, by introducing new food/drinks to the menu.
For starters, I would recommend New England clam chowder or the Hearty Clam soup.
The mains are equally satisfying.
My favourite of them all is the Mentaiko spaghetti with salmon tataki ($20.50).
The sunny side up egg is perfectly paired with the salmon which is slightly seared, yet partially raw for the added oompf.
Further the sauce has bits of white roe and is tastefully tossed together with a sauce that is balanced with the right amount of savouriness to keep you wanting more.
If you like your food slightly spicy, you'll fall in love with the Baby Crayfish Spaghetti!
The sauce which has little green balls that taste like the mini roe you get in sushi sometimes is skillfully mixed with the mildly spicy sauce.
The crayfish is bite sized - it looks like prawns but tastes like crayfish - and makes it very enjoyable to feast on.
As for desserts, they are all so prettily done that I don't even have the heart to eat them anymore.
What I love about the TCC joints is the comfortable environment to just have a good, decently priced meal.
With such a wide selection of food and beverages, I totally understand they are able to keep their regular customers coming back for more.
TCC often has promotions such as 1-for-1 set meals, so keep your eyes peeled for that.
If you ask me about this place, I personally feel that with the amount you pay for the meals, somewhere else is much better.
Why?
Because my salmon sandwich which was around $15 excluding GST was quite meager.
It only took up like 1/3 of the plate and the other 1/3 was vegetables.. that was it.
Drinks wise,  their smoothies are not that bad.
Service for me was quite slow that day as well.
Other than that, if given the option, I don't think I will go back for their main courses.. if any, probably just go back for their desserts and their drinks.
If you are looking for an alternative to the usual starbucks, you might want to consider this quaint joint along Orchard road.
The Connoisseur Concerto or commonly known as TCC has both indoor and outdoor seating.
Despite being located in the city, the entire place still managed to keep its cozy feel, away from the busy city.
We opted for this place to meet up with another friend.
It's fresh, shabby, country style decor was more than enough for me to soothe me after a walk.
Being a big fan of mint chocolates ( I know, only a few are fond of this chocolate class) so I opted for the Mint-Cho Frappe.
It was already ice-blended but the minty hint added that refreshing and cool feeling.
I would be coming back to this place just to have a drink and recharge.
And maybe have a meal when everything else is quite crowded, but I wouldn't be consistently going back mainly because dining in here is basically a splurge.
And we don't always splurge right?
Seriously?
$1 for a tub of flavored douhua?
Saw the long line so I decided to dive in and try some.
Was pretty excited to try the soft bean curd here but after a couple of spoonfuls, eh, it's wasn't to my liking.
I don't know how to explain it better except it had a weird combination of really bland douhua and a very sharp sweet taste in the syrup.
Like I said, I don't know how else to explain it.
I prefer a more smoother combination of the both.
But hey, for a dollar, why not?
Also, ordered a grass jelly soy milk drink.
Just average.
It's a bit of an institution in the Marine Parade scene.
Stalls with huge tanks full of lychee, longan, and mixed fruit drinks.
It's strange how the fruits always taste so different to what you're used to, and they're even better because of the attapchee (attap seed) that surprises you every now and then.
If you're friends with these guys, ask for more and they'll gladly fish some out for you!
There's no shortage of such drink stalls in this food centre, but head along the outside (towards Parkway Parade and McDonalds) and the 2nd last stall is the one you're looking for.
Spend $1.20 for a huge cup of mixed fruits and other magic - take it away if you must, but there's something special and nostalgic about the huge fishbowl-like mugs you're served with.
These guys have been around since forever, so visit them, or chat with them, or get to know them.

They've probably been running this stall since before you were born, and beyond the nasi padang and famous kway teow and amazing vegetarian stall, they win my award for legends of Marine Parade Food Centre.
This stall is good for two things; herbal tea (duh) and chinese desserts.
I was having a sore throat and decided to stop here to get a drink while walking around Nex.
I chose the Chrysanthemum with American ginseng which was just $1.60 a bottle.
As soon as I stood at the cashier, a swarm of middle-aged women loomed behind me.
They were talking excitedly in hokkien about the desserts here.After i got my tea they proceeded to order a whole bunch of things and the desserts were prepared on the spot.
I thought this was interesting because in most stalls I've been to, they pre-pack desserts and leave them in a fridge or warmer.
I figured if these ladies thought they were good, they must be.
My throat was too sore for me to be in the mood for any dessert though.
Perhaps next time.
I don't mean to be offensive to this place, i really don't, but there are some places where you feel like there is no love put into the food.
It's just made for the sake of making food as a living.
That's how the food tastes here for me.
It's just a bit dry without much character or flavor.
The maggie goreng here was not memorable at all.
Maybe i tried the wrong dish or got the chef on the wrong day.
However i left this place feeling like if i had to come back it is probably safest to order a prata.
The ambience is not too exciting and the staff aren't friendly.
It's great that places like these still exist - the old school biscuits that used to be sold by the tins are almost a thing of the past.
Enter Biscuit King and you'll see tin boxes of what else, biscuits, lined up to the ceiling.
You can choose to order the biscuits in portions of 500g, 1kg, by the tin or by the tub (cheapest option).
I always get the Sultana - the biscuit with a chewy dried grape interior.
The store also sells sweets and preserved fruits.
If I were a student living in the area, I'd come here everyday after school!
It's a candy and biscuits wonderland.
Check out their website too - most of their products are online now so you can order your nostalgic biscuits in the comfort of your bed.
Stepping into this store is like stepping back into childhood.
All the old school candies that I used to love are found again.
Tidbits that I thought are already obsolete are found here.
Biscuits in old tins that you can buy by weight.
Candies, wafers, Popsicles, etc.
check out some of my photos and you will get what I mean.
Love nostalgia!
I love mangoes, the Mango Paradiso is THE cake I would order again and again.
Last year I bought one, took a picture and sent it to a friend.
I told him I got it for his birthday; however since he was not around to receive this cake, I would eat it on his behalf, haha!
The Mango Paradiso was a cake with layers of mango mousse and creamy jello on top.
This is probably the most expensive individual cake in the case but worth every penny.
The rest of the cakes are decent but this Mango Paradiso just stands out among the rest.
As for bread, the very popular floss bun is my favorite.
I have once saw an imposter at Sweet Hut (outside Atlanta); the one at Sweet Hut tasted funky and looked nothing like the one at Breadtalk.
I also like the chocolate swirl bread, reminded me of those served at the Executive Lounge at Conrad Tokyo.
Staffs are nice and friendly.
Breadtalk is my go to bakery in Singapore.
Gayatri in Telok Ayer St is open 7 days a week and its great as it can be hard to find a place open everyday in the CBD.
The food here is very authentic and very good.
Be prepared to shell out a bit more than a hawker stall though, but it is worth it.
Try the vegetarian briyani, served with vegetarian side dishes.
Portions are huge here and hard to finish, so I think its worth the price.
In the mornings, they have traditional Indian breakfast foods like dosai, prata and idli.
T he staff is very nice and know you by face.
A must try in Singapore.
Edit update 9 March 2013: You know, we've gone back here many many times since my first visit and 2 star review and there's more to Gayatri than my first impressions.
It's my wife's favorite spot now so we go there pretty frequently.
Their masala dosa is so delicious and a bargain at $3.
Egg Prata is fantastic.
Their veggie dishes are also good.
Their meat dishes are over-priced but if you don't mind eating vegetarian, the prices are reasonable.
I had a fantastic take-away vegetarian lunch for only $5.50 (see picture).
Old Review: Nothing memorable.
I've yet to find out of this world Indian food in Singapore which is surprising.
Someone help!
Gayatri looks very nice on the outside, it's clean and well kept on a corner across from Amoy Food Centre.
Everything looks delicious and the prices are a tad higher than what you'd normally get at a hawker stall.
The food was average.
I don't remember it being anything special.
My search for good Indian food in Singapore continues...
On a whirlwind trip to Singapore for work, I hadn't had a chance to eat any dumplings, so I wanted to get my fix as I was leaving.
I know airport food is usually terrible but at the newer section at Changi I had previously had some great dumplings at a restaurant recommended by a local.
I was at the older budget terminal this time.
I headed to Hong Kong Sheng Kee Dessert, and I ordered some Shumai (prok dumplings) and some Liu Sha Bao (salted egg custard buns).
The Shumai looked like it had been made and cooked 3 months ago so I didn't even touch it.
I gave the salted egg custard buns a go, but they tasted pretty stale too.
I would not recommend this eatery.
This is our go to restaurant for Roti Prata whilst in Singapore and we'll quite often dine at Prata Wala on a couple of occasions in our short time there.
I'm a big fan of the Roti Prata and Garlic Naan with Butter Chicken to dip in.
Of all the times we've been I've only had one prata come out that wasn't that perfect crispy on the outside and doughy on the inside that I so love.
The service won't set the world on fire and it's not as cheap as some of the hawker stalls you might find but the quality in the food is definitely there and I'd say you get good bang for your buck.
I don't usually enjoy the Murtabak as much as the roti or naan as it can be soggy and too rich for me but the roti and naan is as good as I've had anywhere and I'd highly recommend Prata Wala.
A great place to take the family for dinner - its relaxed, the food comes out fast, and everything is tasty (as its name suggests :P).
Their dishes are all pretty good - but their hor fan, shrimp paste chicken and fish head curry are a must have for every trip that I make there.
Don't expect too much and you won't be disappointed - its really your local zhi char place in a restaurant setting, but without the service charge and gst!
Plus points for that :)  Also, their sambal chilli is really really yummy too - so make sure you ask for some.
I've always been a fan of Different Taste and my favourite dish of all has got to be their penang kway teow.
its got the right amount of chilli and the kway teow noodles are fried perfectly.
The fish head curry is also another killer dish.
the fish meat is tender and its soaked up all that beautiful curry flavour.
Pair that with a plate of white rice and you're all set.
The ha chiong kai is also very good.
as is the foo yong omelette.
One fo the best zi char restaurants around.
Having done well in their first outlet at Ang Mo Kio, Soi 19 Wanton Mee in Singapore has decided to open another outlet at a coffee shop just a few minutes walk from Jurong MRT.
I haven't tried this before at all and decided give it a go today.
I literally just finished eating and decided to give my review on this immediately - I got here about 1:15pm on a Friday afternoon and joined the queue.
Took me about 10mins to receive my order?
They're pretty fast as they take your order whilst you're still in the queue.
I ordered the jumbo portion since I don't live anywhere near both their outlets and felt I probably wouldn't come here often anyways.
Now on to the food!
The portion of $6 (jumbo) is pretty huge, even for a big guy like me.
Don't really need to order this size unless you're like super starving as it seems pretty generous.
All you need to do is help yourself to the chilli as they serve the bowl to you.
As Thai wanton mee goes, the choices of chilli are the chilli flakes or the green chillies like your usual local wanton mee.
Choose either or both.
The bowl of noodles comes with a small bowl of wanton soup, again the usual standard.
Here's the part about the noodles.
It is QQ as everyone says, quite generous with the ingredients which includes fried dumplings, charsiew and pork lard.
All quite generous.
The noodles I felt was a little dry and slightly clumped together.
I had to pour some soup into the mix to loosen up the noodles slightly.
Taste wise, I felt if they had removed the name "soi19", I wouldn't have know its Thai in any way.
The Charsiew was pretty average and so were the wantons.
They also add Chinese sausage slices inside.
Pretty interesting.
They aren't BAD by any means, just that I guess it was probably very overhyped.
Do bear in mind that my only reference from Thai wanton mee is the one at Alibabar at katong called Baan by Rochor Thai.
THAT wanton mee in particular tasted "Thai" to me.
This one was just a VERY handsome portion of noodles with quite a variety of ingredients unlike the usual.
3.5 Stars
Dean's cafe was featured on a channel u food programme on interesting zhi char stall.
The 3 dishes that were featured on tv were the crispy duck, the cai por (preserved radish) hor fun and its been hoon with crab.
The missus and I decided to give it a try after watching the TV feature.
Took us a while to find the place.
The 3 dishes featured were now extra popular and there were signs everywhere featuring the 3 dishes.
Dean's Cafe is essentially a chinese restaurant, in a coffeeshop setting and prices.
The cai por hor fun is super nice and value for money.
The hor fun is cooked like and has the texture of carrot cake.
The cai por hor fun is supposedly now a very rarely-found dish in Singapore.
The crispy duck was a little disappointing mostly because we bought it to go, so by the time we reached home, the duck may not taste as good.
Would recommend eating it on the spot.
A feel of al fresco eating ambience, especially after sun set.
Tables n chairs are quite tightly spaced though.
Their crispy duck n cai por hor fun are unique and are their signature dishes to try.
This is my first time coming here.
For my family moat have been here many times.
Firstly if you have a big group in type party, be sure to get there early or you'll be hard pressed to find a big table.
Their signature dosh is the herbal crispy duck.
We had a half portion for all 13 to share.
It war good.
The duck was tender.
The flavor wasn't over powering.
Other dishes were just the usual good food standard.
Because my time here is limited, i will have to give this place a miss even though i think it is really quite good
When it comes to prata, I always believe the best ones are from stalls in old hawker centres.
Of course, there's also the ones along Jalan Kayu.
But if you find yourself in Jurong Point for whatever reason and have a craving for roti prata - avoid prata wala at all costs.
More appalling is their claim to be the best Singapore Indian restaurant.
I dunno about their other outlets but this one at Jurong Point is definitely disappointing.
Too expensive for prata and briyani, food is too oily and service is poor.
The cleanliness of the place also leaves much to be desired.
This is a food truck parked in the newly renovated food area of NTU.
Let's keep this short.
The service is poor and disorganized.
The food takes 20 minutes to come out, which defies the laws of food trucks as well as the local hawker climate.
On top of that, the food isn't made to order or freshly prepared, so we were all wondering what was going on back there.
The quality of the food is similar to a poor airline meal: dehydrated eggs with a soupy consistency, soggy waffles, uncooked bacon...
Skip this place for sure.
This little bakery in Old Airport Road Food Centre serves up awesome muffins; not your usual type of hawker food but these m uffins are absolutely yummylicious.
The muffins are divine, soft buttery and great when warm.
They've got a whole range of flavours, I favour the chocolate ones (chocolate chip, double chocolate chip, chocolate rice...) but the others are quite good too (raisin, cornflake...).
they also serve up pretty good and large egg tarts, all freshly baked on site in the morning, so if you're in the mood for snacks, this is where you should head.
Walked past this place every now and then as it is located at the J-walk area on the 2nd level linking Westgate and JEM.
Decided to try this out since it had quite a bit of queue when I went there.
Ordered plain prata, curry bun and dry laksa for myself as they are the recommended list of foods according to the menu.
The environment seemed to go back in time - Chinese heritage and the servers were wearing the olden clothing which looked a little like pajamas in my friend's eyes.
Food came out pretty fast.
The plates really bring me back to the days when I was younger.
The food presentation was very well done especially for the dry laksa as it looked very appetizing.
Tried the curry bun first.
It was good but the curry wasn't a lot to have that wow-ing factor.
Then the prata.
It was crispy at the bottom part of it.
The curry was also very flavorful.
For the price, it was worth it.
It is one of the best prata in town.
The dry laksa had three prawns on it and I had to place it on the side as I am not really into steamed prawns and I am allergic to shellfish.
I tried the dry laksa, it was not as good as the food presentation.
But the portion was big (or maybe I ordered too much).
Might try other food besides the famous dry laksa next time round.
At the counter, there are papers which can become a cup and a container of snacks that you could enjoy after you pay your bill.
I love that tidbit that I was eyeing on it when other people serving themselves.
Overall, this place is on the pricier end and I might only come here to eat the prata.
Will probably try other foods when I am back here.
The place was empty when we walked in, but it was packed when we left.
The food dishes all tasted different.
A great sign of a good restaurant.
Mostly chicken and vegetarian dishes.
The nann was hot, fresh, and had a unique flavor - really good too!
We had the buffet with folks from work.
Very comfortable and a good price $15 which included a drink, tax, and service changes.
I will be coming back.
Pros: Vegetarian food Quick service Cons: Pedestrian flavors Only one option for set thaali When you have North Indian food on the menu why not have a North Indian thaali option?
There are 22 Indian joints in the area and this one doesn't cut the mustard.
The revolutionary pudding-like bean curd from Lao Ban has definitely sparked many tau huay makers to come up with similar cold desserts.
One of the most successful competitors in my opinion would be Yummy Soy!

Compared to Lao Ban that has only two flavors, namely original and almond, Yummy Soy has creatively come up with many savory flavors, such as caramel, matcha, vanilla, almond, macadamia nut, hazelnut, strawberry, blueberry, toffee nut... and the list just seems to go on.
It may be hard to imagine some of these flavors put together with bean curd, but Yummy Soy has made it possible!
