There is quite a good balance between the savory flavor and the soy taste, which makes you want to try out the other flavors.
The cold silky smooth bean curd is a truly a perfect cold dessert to go along on a hot afternoon.
If you are in a hurry, they also have flavored bean curd in a cup!
That is something that is not ordinarily offered at other tau huay stores too.
So if you fancy something that will excite your taste buds, Yummy Soy is not to be missed!
This is a small outlet so the selection of bread is not as wide as other places.
You will still get the favorites - chocola cheese, raisin and walnut, cranberry walnut, pizza onion toast..... Another difference I noticed is there are no tasting basket for every type of bun/bread.
Only a few will get the sampling basket and there is a staff member holding a tray with a few samples for customers to try.
The bread is still very good.
Chewy, light and packed with flavor.
Compared to other bakeries, the prices are a bit on the high side with most bread starting from $3+.
But the bread is much bigger and when you get a bit of cheese, chocolate, nuts in every bite, I think it is quite alright.
I am just glad there is finally an outlet in the Orchard Road shopping belt area.
Speaking of deli-counters, everyone knows which is their heart's desire.
I seldom frequent a pâtisserie, at most a boulangerie.
Most commonly seen these days, are either tagging a European heritage or a Japanese label, anchoring at some malls - majestic or humble.
Another group will hole up at some remote or bustling hotels, sometimes an extension of the main restaurant while others are stand alone without parentage.

When the now-defunct Something-To-Go at Regent Singapore finally vacate itself from the lobby, the unit is quickly replaced by another gourmet Italian pastry shop; serves artisanal bakeries/pastries "bites-on-the-GO" from Basilico kitchen - the Italian buffet restaurant on level 2.
Confession I must, I have never been to Regent Singapore, at best, driving past.
So, when others mentioned about the takeaway deli over at the hotel, I couldn't visualize where and how to get to it.
Until today, I finally left FOODprints at Dolcetto after a trip to St Regis, Singapore.
Once you enter the hotel main entrance, head towards the lobby at 12o'clock, until you reach the far end which is walled in glass panels.
Dolcetto is just on your 9 o'clock - sit tightly in a corner.

With a few round tables and long sofa in the lobby, one simply shop in the deli - scan the display, place your order and make the payment before pulling your tray of items off the cashier to any available seats.
Barely any soul, except a few in-house guests waiting to check into their rooms.
The time was 2.30pm, a Friday.
I found myself a decent table to interrogate my subject, though I wish it has been a date.
Spoilt with choices, I cherry-picked the elegant looking mini tart - Forest Berries.
This beautiful treat enchants you with its sweetness that was meant for the faint heart - mild and calming.
A very thin layer of delicate custard was seen cushioned between a bushel of huge plumpish strawberries & its cousins and a less buttery crisp shell.
Though the silkiness of the custard won me over, I still prefer they rubbed in more butter for a richer tart shell.
Perhaps a few more scoops of fillings to satiate my greed.
Prior to that, I think it has been overpriced for its content, $9 a piece.
Then comes the savory.
Less attractive, something that you wouldn't care for a second look probably.
Many may pace up and down the display and thought it was just another sweet mini French burger treats - Macaroon.
Stay close and read those tags which spelled their names in flowing strokes, you will realized that they ain't all sweet treats.
I asked the lady for a Smoked Salmon classic, and the dusky cookie make it to the plate, alongside the jeweled tart.
A complete contrast between a beauty and the beast from afar!
Instantly, prejudice sets in when confronted with visual appeal but it turned out to be an unfair judgement.
If you think a sweet shell is at odds with salmon fillings, reconsider that please.
I am surprised by the unconventional making, the mixture of mellow sweet crisp cookie embodied a dollop of silky creme wrapping some melting salmon with a rich savory & smokey finish.
No overbearing fishiness was seen marring the light, gently crackling almond meringue shell, heavenly.
For once, I tasted a refined French treat which didn't put me off with its immeasurable sweetness but one that was light and playful.
A $2.25 per piece is so reasonable to ask for another.
To wash down my tea treats, I had a dose of cappuccino that smoothed my throat but less lingering.
I am glad that this cup was worth $5.60 instead of $15 that was charged by mistake for 3 doses at first.
Please do check your bill if it sounds unbelievable, I was happy that I did.
Do not be misled by my choices, there are plenty of artisanal breads, sweet muffins, doughnuts, mouth-watering sandwiches and even tiny sweets like cookies and chocolates on the shelves.
But be forewarned that the price is steep.
If there's anything that I would bond with, the freestyle squid ink smoked salmon shall be it!
This classic arrives without confining rules - highly praised.
I will be most happy to ask for a second piece anytime soon whenever Dolcetto is call upon.
If you happen to spot a white color mousse cake studded with dried fruits called "Cassata Siciliana" at any local patisserie, don't think much, just get it.
It is such a traditional and peripheral cake that few pastry chefs in Singapore would ever think of making one.
The rarity drove me to get a slice at Dolcetto by Basilico, despite being already full to the brims.
This Italian pastry shop used to be my to-go place for takeaway pastries when it was still under the name of "Something to Go".
The interior and menu have been revamped, but the signatures like Strawberry Torte, Praline Torte and Espresso Tiramisu still stay.

In the spirit of all things Italian, all the pastries here that involved chocolate are made with Tuscany's organic chocolate brand Amedei, which is perhaps also one of the world's most expensive chocolate.
Take for example the Amedei Chocolate Pumpkin Tart ($9) that took a sinful detour from the usual pumpkin pie.
The mastery of the cacao tones is virtually undisputed, so does the crisp tart shell which not overworked and perfect in volume with the filling.

Pumpkin is one of my favorite ingredients but the taste seemed to have wandered off to elsewhere and did not meld together with the chocolate The Praline Torte ($9) is hard not to love with the appealing crunchy base.
But I was craving for something less milky, something more intense and I figured that the other option of Amedei Dark Chocolate Cake would have satisfied my lust for chocolate.
Bright juicy and sweet, the soft chunks of pineapple rested amidst the delectable vanilla baked custard in this humble Italian Crostata ($9).

But instead of being served the traditional family way in big, rustic free-form version, it has been elevated to the fine ranks of French gateaux with mild "Violette perfumes" and a touch of gold on top of the dainty raspberries.
The Espresso Marsala Cake ($9) was our unanimous pick.

It might seem like a messy pile of various textures (crunch, custard, sponge, ganache, gelee) but I loved the sweetness from the Marsala wine even though the espresso kick wasn't assertive as I had imagined.
And of course the delightful sound of the crushed chocolate pearls is music to the ears.
One can't miss the conspicuous fresh-baked pane (breads) that are stacked along the wall.
We've finally got a taste of the famous squid ink panini with fresh king crab and prawns ($13), a hearty dense and chewy sandwich that seemed a little deprived of tantalizing juices from the filling.
The Roasted Chicken & Cheese Foccacia might not be brimming with luxury ingredients but the flavors were simple and comforting.
Many may raise eyebrows at the sight of Squid Ink Salmon Macaron but it is quite a success.
In fact, a good step to convert those who usually steer away from these sugary meringue bites.
The chewy shells appeared rather flattened but the flavors were spot on, especially the Vanilla Prosecco and Cassis.
The shopfront is something out of a dream or a movie.
It is a bakery and sweet lover's paradise - even outside the entrance you can spot the mounds of pastries and breads baked to perfection, so much so that they look fake!
I was reeled in straight away and had a croisssant.
It was everything I had hoped it to be.
Flaky and crispy on the outside, and soft, fluffy and airy on the inside.
The pastries and cakes looked picture perfect and I wish I had bought one!
It is served the same style as the famed soup minced pork noodles at fengshan block 85 market, except that this is served with wanton rather than pork balls.
Garlicky soup, al dente noodles.
I found the noodles to be thicker.
Nonetheless, It is a good bowl of noodles, But it doesn't hit the spot like the one at Block 85.
However, since block 85 only opens in the evening, if you have a carving for soup minced pork noodles in the dot, this may be the only place.
Expect a wait of at least 20min on weekends.
Jiak Pa Lang?
based on the chinese characters in their signage it would mean to eat one's fill.
but there is also a similar sounding phrase which means a collection of random items?
i have only tried their lunch menu which is based on the concept of salad and rice bowls.
a localized version of the western concept or a westernized version of our local chap chye peng?
it marries the best of both worlds, in my opinion.

high quality gourmet ingredients not commonly found in the local economical rice stalls and delightfully local flavours injected into a normally boring ang mo salad or sometimes overly healthy rice bowl.
here, they strike a good balance and is neither too cheap nor too expensive.
i would get the value set additions, especially their daily soup, homemade goodness with every sip.
it can get crowded and noisy during lunch peak hours.
but they try their best to speed up the ordering process with mobile tablets and staff moving down the line of hungry diners to expedite order taking.
plentiful aircon seating within and outdoors as well.
can be very boisterous and cafeteria like indoors.
clean bathrooms and charging points aplenty but do select seats strategically as needed.
i have not tried their dinner menu yet as they are only open on weekdays.
but from what i read, their innovative creations, or remakes, of local zi char dishes will be what you can expect.
if their lunch is a good gauge then i will be in for a palate tantalizing dinner treat when i do find time for a weekday evening meal here!
"a hungry man is an angry man".
i'm writing this review while waiting for more than 20 minutes for the main course we ordered.
me and my friend decided to try this restaurant because the food looks delish.
we came in, decided to order calamari for appetizer (not bad), pesto chicken salad (tastes ok), grilled dory fish and grilled chicken.
before we decided to order the items above, we WANTED pizza.
After taking our order, we waited with so much gusto only to find out (first 20 mins of waiting) that they ran out of pizza sauce!
Seriously?
Now, into the main course, they have lots lots to choose from (which at times is a disadvantage).
You can also choose between having 1 or 2 side dish.
But on this particular day, only 3 amongst 10 or 11 choices are available!
WOW!
Now that I'm full, Id probably give this restaurant a 2nd chance.

WAITING TIME: VERY LONG :/ The salads & drinks came fast and then the first meal (aglio olio) came in about 7-10 min & but then the second meal (breaded chicken + fries) came after about 15-18 min & the longest was the third meal that only came after about 30 min after prompting the service staff.

After our meal, we asked for the free scoop of icecream that came with the lunch set and after waiting for 10-15 min we called again with the staff and yet another 10-15 min waiting & it was long after the peak hour after so much waiting (came in at around 145pm & left at about 315pm) then after raising our hand for the 3rd time for about 5 min then a walking by staff saw us from another table and finally got our 3 scoops of icecream.

HYGIENE: OKAY The tables were wet with some yellowish brown stains when i used a piece of tissue to clean & some unknown liquid was dripping from the bottom of the table & there was a weird odour but the utensils looked clean.
PRICE: NOT CHEAP 3 set lunches cost us near $50 FOOD: NOT BAD The food were not bad even though the waiting time was really long.
The spaghetti had flavour and the chicken was cooked well & the icecream was delicious.
Also the proportions were good and filling not stingy.
OVERALL EXPERIENCE: If the hygiene was cleaner / the food had a slightly shorter waiting time, i would have given it a four star without doubt as the food is good.
I will return and hopefully it will be a better experience!
Tugged away in one corner of Bukit Timah Plaza, I was first attracted by the affordable prices and wide selection of bread.
I got the green tea loaf which was a steal at 6 slices for only $2!
It comes in two sizes.
The green color was eye catching and the fragrance was great.
The red beans also complemented the taste and I found the bread good enough to eat on its own.
The next time I return, I'm going for the bigger size!
As one of the only few bakeries in the area, Swee Heng is usually my go-to shop for those fancy bread made popular by BreadTalk.
You know which ones I'm talking about: the floss buns, otah-otah buns, fish fillet buns, and all sorts of buns imaginable.
Swee Heng frequently has promotions like 4 pieces of buns for S$3, but these are inconsistent and sometimes the price changes, so I don't keep track of them.
But even on their own, the buns are affordable, usually costing less than S$2 per piece.
Besides these breads, they also sell other stuff like birthday cakes, pastries, and biscuits.
If you drop by later on at night, they might have some promotion going on where you can buy more bread at a cheaper price to finish selling everything before they close.
Designer Bakes is a really good place for specially designed Cupcakes and pies.
It's more about the design then the taste though.
The cupcakes are a bit dry and the icing is pretty hard and not delicious.
If you look at the pictures you can get a good impression of the design they do.
My favorite are the angry birds cupcakes, they look so funny, cute and happy.
Perfect to bring as a gift.
If you have special request, they can also entertain them and you can tell them your requirements.
The lady behind designer bake is very skillful, but if you have special request it can get pretty pricey.
Dropped by this small cafe for tea to catch up with an old buddy.
Neither of us have ever tried their pastries out before, so we asked the staff for recommendations.
She immediately pointed out the premium flavours.
Okay, we should have thought of that - higher price suggests better quality?
Anyway, she left us to decide for ourselves.
My friend and I shared the strawberry, blueberry and peach flavours.
We got the mini ones as they looked big enough.
The strudels were very nice, light, flaky and crispy.
I love the fact that the strudels weren't too sweet either.
The cafe was empty when we arrived, so we got to enjoy our strudels in peace.
The staff was in no hurry to chase us out either.
They don't charge GST and service charge, so okaylah, I can't  complain much.
My Singapore trip won't be complete with having pepper crab and chili crab!
We avoid the long queue and crowded popular spots and came to this Jumbo at NSRCC.
This place is far from town but it's very chilled!
Lots of greens, big koi fish pond, gold course...
Overall very relaxed atmosphere!
The seafood dishes were up to expectation!
My favorite is still the black pepper crab!
Sooo tasty!!
With NSRCC membership, you will get 10% off.
Will definitely come back next time I'm in town.
Can't resist my favourite black pepper crab so went straight from the airport to meet hubby there for dinner after being away for 3 weeks... Can you imagine the ride there...
It wasn't crowded at slightly past 8 but hubby did make the reservation so I won't be disappointed Of course I ordered my fav and hubby ordered his too!
His fav is the steamed crabs... sweetness is somewhat retained and the steamed egg white at the bottom is really smooth.
But I'm still loving mine!!!!
Pure divine with wine!
I had always been curious what all the hype is about this place so decided to come for lunch and oh boy boy boy...got there at 12:05pm and got my food at 12:45pm.
That's 15 minutes before my call so had to eat what I can and left in a hurry.
What was the reason why it took forever to bring my food when I was the only customer there?
They apparently "broke" my fish.
I don't even know what that means.
At least a server had a decency to come, apologize and explain that it will just take few more minutes and explained(?).
Anyway, the cod was but fishy and so was his excuse (no pun intended)
Floating on a former barge, this floating restaurant is offers fresh fresh seafoods as well as common Zhi char style dishes.
I had e seafood mee goreng, not the best tasting but fresh seafood none the less.
Kayak there, or boat there, a unique dining experience, ESP in city dwelling Singapore.
When I came here for a dinner, it was completely empty.
There was no one around, which doesn't bode well for a restaurant, but I thought I'd give it a try anyway.
My friend and I ordered a grilled platter to share, and some sides that were on promotion.
The sides arrived, and they were disappointing.
Oily and fried to a crisp, I could not taste the white bait.
I could only taste old oil.
Awful.
The platter took longer, understandably, and thankfully, it was slightly better.
However, the mussels weren't fresh.
Neither were the prawns, but they tasted alright at least.
I enjoyed the squid as it was well cooked, but not overly so that it was rubbery.
The fish fillet was smothered in butter, but also tasted good.
I didn't mind the rice they served at the bottom of the pan.
It went pretty alright with the seafood, but it was fairly uninspiring.
Ambience wise, this place was fairly boring.
It felt like a slightly more upmarket Long John's Silver actually.
It had the look and feel of a fast food joint, with tacky nautical decorations.
Definitely not suitable for a date.
It's probably better for larger group gatherings where you can share the items.
Service was efficient, but again, no smiles.
I've noticed this problem all over Singapore.
It really doesn't hurt to smile a little.
Nice personal afternoon coffee, if you prefer a bit sour coffee bean, it is a nice choice.
Next to the national library, at the cross of North Bridge Rd and Seah St.
There are many outside seats, and face the white building which is part of Raffles City.
I have this gut feeling that the only reason I came here was because it was a random place that I picked to have a coffee at so that I could do a write up of another place on Yelp.
Well, the fact that it has been left until I have posted all of the cool places that I wanted to post sooner rather than later suggests that this place wasn't all that fantastic.
To be honest, no, it wasn't all that fantastic.
In fact it was quite forgetable, which is probably why I left it that long.
Mind you, the fact that I did leave it probably indicates that the coffee wasn't all that bad, but it wasn't fantastic either.
Mad Jack is where you can find Halal western food, with a local twist!
The food served here is quite decent, and has a great variety for you to choose from: appetizers, finger food, salads, pastas, burgers and even desserts.
What's more, the prices are pretty reasonable and friendly to the pocket.
If you love chocolate and like it sweet, you'd love their brownie with ice cream and M.A.D & Rich cake.
Personally, it tastes a little too sweet.
If you're too lazy to get out of the house, you can also call for delivery.
Overall, satisfactory food that is value for money.
This bakery is famous for their selection of soft breads, in particular their raisin and cream cheese bread.
I'm not really a fan of soft breads and i'm not that lyrical as my colleagues about the raising cream cheese bread, judge it for yourself though!
I do like the normal freshly baked bread.
You can tell by the small display and the huge machinery that they have a very high turnover on freshly baked breaks and buns.
That keeps the quality high and the bread fresh and warm.
The cakes are not their specialty and therefore ok-only.
Okay, it's obvious from the length of the queue that the general public doesn't  think that the son fries as good a Chye Tao Kueh as the father did.
Senior had been frying for years, many, many years.
I mean as late as 2012, he was still charging $1.50 per plate, that's like 1980's pricing, man!
To me though, there's little to choose between junior's and senior's carrot cake.

Yes, junior doesn't use so much of the black sweet sauce, and perhaps isn't so thorough to make sure that the flavour infuses every single morsel on the plate, but he's more daring in allowing the carrot cake to sit a little longer in the pan and so you do get more charred bits that add another dimension to the dish itself.
To the uninitiated, the fried carrot cake we're referring here to is the white carrot or radish version.

It comes in 2 forms, the white version, which is without the darkened sweet sauce (same stuff used in Char Kway Teow) and is usually eaten with a generous dash of pepper, and the black version (ask for 'orh eh'), which is the version I always order.
So whilst I rate it a 4, because it's not quite the same as the old man's, it's still perhaps the only Chye Tao Kueh I will drive for.
And on the bright side, you no longer have to queue half an hour for this breakfast Favourite.
I've yet tasted their cookies but have placed an order with them today (explains why I only gave 3 stars.

Will be back to edit my review) - And all cookie lovers NEED to know this: Unless I've been living under a rock, they are probably the 1st cookie bakery i know in Singapore that provides home-delivery service!
Famous Amos should follow in their foot steps.
Can't wait for em to deliver my order!
I popped by The Gourmet Bakery Cafe just this afternoon for a cup of tea after some shopping at suntec city and millenia walk.
I was very happy with the service here and I ordered the Pasta.
It wasn't the best I have tasted, but it definitely was of good quality.
The sandwiches here also aren't too bad and is reasonably priced!
For a cafe in Millenia Walk it is very reasonably priced which makes all the more reason for me to pop by the next time I am in the area!
The design of the store is very welcoming and embraces warm colours.
It is never too crowded which allows you to much peace and quiet which is very rare in this city.
The staff are very friendly and will even remember your name if your frequent enough!
Great place for some coffee and tea, definitely deserving of 4 stars!
I was walking around millennia walk after going to comex.
Most of the cafes were packed and we walked around to see of there is anywhere without a queue.
We stumbled upon this rather quiet cafe tucked in a corner.
My friend ordered their pumpkin soup which was thick and rich.
It is very flavorful and we enjoyed it.
On the other hand, I was very disappointed with their ultimate chocolate cake.
The cake was very dry.
It felt like the cake was left there and had dried up.
There were a limited selection of cakes to choose from.
I like coming here for cheap birthday cakes.
A 300 gram cream cake here is priced at only $15.
It's enough to go round in my family of four, and reduces wastage.
500 gram cakes start from $22 and 1kg cakes from $32.
The fancier creamcakes will of course cost more, but the ones on display are good enough.
The quality of the cakes isn't compromised just because they're cheap.
They're soft, moist and melt in your mouth.
The durian buns here are a must-try.
They come with a very generous amount of delicious durian pulp filling - three times the amount in Four Seasons' durian pancakes and are cheaper too!
I once committed the guilty pleasure of wolfing down six in one go.
I usually wait till it's almost closing time to snap up bargains.
From 8pm to 9pm, buns go at 3 for $3.
Wait till 9pm and the remaining buns fly off the shelves at 4 for $3.
As you know, I have a knack for the sweets-hence "sweet tooth".
And Bengawan Solo never failed to satisfy my sweet cravings.
What I love about their pastries is that it is moist, and not too sweet.
Everything is just right.
From the thickness of the layers, to the toppings.
When I was introduced to this cake shop, I was hesitant at first because it has been a string of disappointments when it comes to me sampling sweet delicacies.
When I tried their sticky rice cakes, it wasn't tough and dry, it was soft, moist, and easy to chew.
Needless to say, I enjoy my sundays with anything from Bengawan Solo.
Not only they are popular for their pastries, their price tags are very likeable.
As much as their dark red boxes.
It is rare for me to like catered food but the food all come piping hot!!
Even the otah smelled fresh off the bbq pit!!
The fried Mee siam wasn't dry, and tasted pretty good!
The otah had a nice burnt taste to it and didn't taste too artificial like some others from other catering companies.
And this still comes in a leaf, most other companies have resorted to taking them out of the lead or just placing them in aluminum foil containers.
The drumlets were crispy and tasty!
I enjoyed the drumlets!
The black pepper fish had tons of mushrooms and it was not too peppery and it was savory.
The fish wasn't mushroom and almighty crispy on the edges.
The fruit cocktail for dessert was refreshing and was what we all needed after a long talk.
Sadly there was no jelly in it, but I found it abit too diluted.
Yong Tau Foo is one of my favourite meals at lunch because it can be made either very healthy or sinfully unhealthy.
If I'm craving a healthy YTF, I head to the stall at the food court at the base of Golden Shoe.
They sell generous portions of freshly made fish cake wrapped in tofu skin and the servings of broccoli, carrots and Chinese vegetables are huge.
If I'm thinking of indulging in some unhealthy YTF, Jason's is it.
Jason's is one of those old school hawkers that follows the belief that what's fried should be fried and whatever can't be fried is boiled.
You can find similar YTF at Telok Ayer St and the food court in Raffles City.

I like Jason's because they offer a balance of freshly made items and factory made junk, in particular, their tau kua squares with chili fish paste, fried fish balls and fried tau pok can't be found at other stalls.
The soup base is ordinary and the laksa soup is diluted, so I'd recommend the former and ask for the fried items to be separated.
There's an efficient system of ordering too.
One line is for customers to choose their YTF, which you then pass to the lady at the back of the stall front to pay.
She'll pass it down the line and you return to a second queue with a queue number to collect your food.
The "plating" (which really is "bowl-ing") auntie will ask whether you want chilli and sweet sauce, then give you your bowl of YTF.
So despite the long queues, ordering at Jason's is pretty smooth.
Inaugural yelpku: rice veg or porridge expensive yummy fish soup indoors aircon food
This restaurant is actually part of the Night Safari, the place where you fill up on food before joining the hideously long line to jump on the tram.
I came here because my tour group had booked up some of the tables for us, and also because it is a buffet restaurant (which seems to be common with tours - you can tell I haven't been on many).
The food is all Chinese, which is sort of odd because the name is African.
Also they didn't have chop-sticks, though they do sell reasonably priced drinks, including Singapore Slings that don't break the bank.
Four Leaves is awesome for two things: Its "Mini World" promotion and ability to whip up delicious, creamy cakes.
The "Mini World" promotion consists of selected mini pastries and baked goods.
Buy 1 piece for $0.70, 3 pieces for $1.95 and 5 pieces for just $2.95 (great deal).
You can choose from nutty brownies, sausage buns and many more!
Now it's time for me to rave on about the cakes.
Four Leaves, I believe, bakes some of the most gratifying cakes.
My top picks for cakes are Coco Exotic and Strawberry Shortcake.
Loaded with silky chocolate mousse and hazelnut flakes, Coco Exotic is the perfect enjoyment amongst chocoholics.
I favour creamy vanilla over chocolate, thus Strawberry Shortcake attains championship in my books!
Its creamy texture and natural vanilla taste brings joy to my taste buds.
The vanilla sponge layers are soft, complementing the huge strawberries and angelic vanilla cream.
A dainty and lovely cake that is best enjoyed with a cup of tea!
Smitten is a branch opened by The Patissier, a home-grown bakery that has been making some of the most delectable cakes I've had.

While The Patissier is known for good, traditionally shaped cakes to cater to occasions like birthday parties and weddings, Smitten is dedicated to selling The Pattisier's best-selling item - the passion fruit meringue cake - in its intended form, in a roll.
The Passion-fruit meringue roll, otherwise known as Passionfruit Meringue Fame, is a must-try.
The cream in the roulade was surprisingly light and subtly sweet and the fresh fruits in it offer a refreshing burst of flavour.
The meringue sponge was slightly crisp and crumbly, with just the right amount of sweetness!
No wonder it is a best-seller!
Mango pomelo sago taste ok only but the glutinous rice w coconut Icecream was nice and thick!
Yuan yang paste - black sesame and almond - is a all time classic with its rich aroma, not too sweet.
Pretty crowded during dinner time as they serve food as well!
Look out for promotions such as '3 desserts for the price of 2' kinda thing.
Spaces between tables are few cms apart.
Nice way to dine with strangers.
And no, not much space for the strollers too.
Meh.
We came with a full tummy & ordered 2 desserts.
They serve main dishes like wanton mee, rice etc.
Price of the desserts is reasonable for its portion.
Durian sago taste kinda strange, coconut ice cream with black glutinous rice is delicious.
It may not be a good choice on your first date as the black rice gets stuck in between your teeth.
Hehe.
Try it on your second, yummy!
3 stars because its not kids friendly.
:( Edited: found baby chairs!
Seats and tables are very near each other.
Reminds me of dining in Hong Kong.
Noodles, dumplings, roast pork, beef brisket, desserts.
Noodles  with roast pork, dumplings etc.
The mushroom pow looks fantastic.
Like real huge mushrooms.
Due to the close proximity, you can makes friends without social media.
You can make small talk with strangers who sit just inches from you.
Very homely feel, like in Hong Kong.
But over there, nobody makes small talk or else they are scolding you.
Ha ha...
Walking out from the MRT station into City Square Mall today, I was greeted with the pleasant aroma of freshly baked bread.
I could not help myself but stop at the source of the smell - Mugiya.
They sell a pretty decent variety of buns and cakes and I had a taste of their cranberry cheese bun, which I heard was their specialty.
It was still warm when I bought it and was an absolute delight.
The bread was soft and light, yet not too airy.
My only comment is that there could have been more cream cheese as I was eating plain bread in some of my bites.
Their chocolate buns are brilliant and their tiramisu is not too bad.
While the tiramisu is not exactly the traditional ones you get in italy or in decent italian restaurants, it is light and has a nice coffee flavour.
Their buns and cakes are priced pretty average.
I can't remember how much the cakes cost but the cream cheese cranberry bun cost $1.50 which is pretty standard these days.
Cedele is a chain.
It has dine-in restaurants, cafe-bakeries and just bakeries.

I like this one at Jelita, because it's on the way home and it does what I need it to do without fuss and pretense, which is dispense one of my favorite sweets in the world, the caramel sea salt cheesecake.
I generally don't get very excited about anything that doesn't have pork fat in it, so sweets are a bit of a hard sell with me.
This cheesecake is good.
How good?
Well, it has no alcohol or pork fat in it and I adore it.
Ok, not an endorsement that should mean much to you, oh stranger, but just take my word as a fellow Yelper, that it's worth my time and your calories.
The caramel has a vestigial smokiness that is accentuated and rounded off by the sea salt.
In that first fresh slice, this flavor tango comes off as almost umami!
Weird, but good weird, like Kumar weird.
Of course, this is a cheesecake after all  and you get creamy and sweet and the graham crust is nice enough.
But it's that smoky-salt-sweet thing that gets me every time and keeps me coming back again and again to try and define the ethereal nature of this flavor etude.
So beguiling.
I'm almost thinking that an evil-boss garnish for this cake would be crisped bacon bits sprinkled lightly on.
To prove this hypothesis, I think I need to head out for more research material....
This place is known for gyozas but I felt like the karrage was the worthy opponent.
It was crispy and flavorful, most things fried are maad delicious though.
Their fried rice has generous ingredients, with every bite, there is a good serving of spring onion,corn and pork or chicken.
This lunch set brings a good food coma and you be satisfied with the wok hei of the rice.
Not pictured here, a peppery egg drop soup to end off the meal!
One of the few bakeries in Singapore that still sells gai zai beng, except during festive seasons like Chinese new year when they focus on making other baked goods.
Their gai zai beng is a great combination of crunchy and chewy, savoury and sweet, exactly how I like my cookies and is awesome as a TV snack.
At just $2.50 for a box of 5 or 6, it is totally worth it.
Sin Tong Nam also offers green bean cakes, ji dan gao (the big soft ones, not the kueh balus), walnut cookies and a few others.
There isn't a lot of variety but they do the few things very well.
My flight leaving for JFK put me at Changi Airport Terminal 3.
Once I went through immigration, I saw PAUL right next to the Duty Free for cosmetics & fragrances.
The best part was it seemed to me there were many empty tables & chairs.
I usually like to arrive for my flight early giving ample time to clear immigration or security checks.
I could use a pastry and some tea at PAUL before I headed to the gate.
There was no one at the front/checkout counter but eventually one staff emerged from the back.
Just said she was not very cheery and rather grumpy.
It seemed that she was the only person working.
I placed my order and tried to create conversations with her.
She was less grumpy by the end of my transaction.
I guess it would be really hard to be mean to someone who usually in good spirits and polite at all times.
After the staff placed my order on a tray, I looked around for tables.
Yep, there were many empty tables but many of them had dirty plates or empty soda bottles or used paper cups on them.
Worse, some of those chairs were really stained.
How those pretty chairs got stained that badly was beyond my comprehension.
Guess clearing & cleaning those tables are not the strongest point for this PAUL here.
And those chairs seriously need a good shampoo.
I love the fruit tartlet and the peppermint tea though.
Haagen Daz continous to win hearts of both young and old with their ice cream that takes a long time to melt.
Although they maybe just as any other ice cream, I guarantee you, you need to take a spoonful of it before confirming your decision with a gavel.
When I have ice cream, I go for the usual chocolate or vanilla.
But with Haagen Daz, I go for their strawberry fields.
It doesn't tast artificial at all.
You can taste real strawberry goodness and enjoy every last bite without that puddle of then-ice cream.
Hence, nothing goes to waste.
For an ice crea, it can be quite expensive.
But it never hurts to indulge once in a blue moon.
And by the time you decide to have a dose of Haagen, they maybe promoting a new flavour.
Looking at the store, you may think that Haagen Daz may not be good of an ice cream because of its almost deserted place.
But think about it, what time does ice cream lovers get out of school?
This version of the beloved traditional soya beancurd seems to be taking over the food scene here in Singapore.
Many stores offering this new silky, pudding-like soya beancurd have been popping up around the island at almost every food centre and to be honest, they all taste rather similar.
69 Cold Soya Beancurd is a new store recently set up in Kovan, selling soya beancurd and soya milk drinks.
I found the soya milk drink rather diluted compared to the others that I have tried.
The soya beancurd is comparable to most of the rest, very soft and silky.
They have recently introduced a durian flavoured soya beancurd and I had a go at it.
I'm not a great fan of flavoured soya beancurd so the durian flavoured one did not go too well for me.
I found the taste a little artificial and I guess I will be sticking to the original one from now on.
The name of this store brought to mine the cheesy "Coffee, tea or, me?"
pick-up line.
It occupies the former Sweettalk shop, smack in the middle of a neighbourhood shopping centre where nobody bothers to dress up to the nines, so it isn't a very romantic option for a date.
There's no coffee but plenty of flavoured bubble teas, waffles and many types of flavoured beancurd.
I got their yam beancurd and honey waffle.
They tasted pretty good.
The waffle was made fresh and isn't too thick and the yam beancurd just slid down my throat.
The shop only sells chilled beancurd though, warm options are not available.
I like mine chilled, so this doesn't bother me.
Their tau huay is also produced with a non-dairy recipe, so the lactose-intolerant ones can enjoy it too.
Sweetest Moments specializes in full month (manyue) and wedding packages for friends and relatives as well as cupcakes for all occasions.
Last year, I ordered my baby girl's full month packages, cake and cupcakes.
The full month package consist of red eggs, Ang ku kueh, bite size cakes and mochi that is nicely box up with a personalized announcement card (which can be a keepsake).
The friends and relatives who received them loved the special touch even though it may not be the most delicious.
Check out their cupcakes too.
They have one interesting item which is the tear apart cupcake cake.
It is being presented like a "whole cake" yet you can tear apart the cake for easy distribution.
New ice cream joint in Joo Chiat.
It's a little hard to notice because it's above the Shop & Save.
You'll have to look for the glass door around the back and go up the escalator to find it.
The place is a little small and I would only recommend you to takeaway your dessert because it's not a place you can have a sit and savour your dessert over a cup of tea.
Also, they don't have much flavours available so just expect the regular favourites like dark chocolate, vanilla, rum & raisin.
They also have sorbets - lemon, strawberry and mint (if i remember correctly).
I got the dark chocolate on a cone while le bf had the rum & raisin on a cone too.
The dark chocolate was pretty nice.
Doesn't really taste like dark chocolate though.
Maybe I expected a stronger flavour but it just tasted like really rich regular chocolate ice cream.
Flavour was ok and satisfying but that was it.
The rum & raisin though was a bit of a dud.
The texture was a bit sedimentary and it tasted like the flavours wasn't mixed up well enough.
Plus, it wasn't really creamy either.
Give this place a miss if you're looking for dessert in Joo Chiat.
There are plenty more which are better.
They have hot and cold desserts here, but my favourite reason to visit this place is for the Taiwan-style shaved ice desserts - solid in appearance but disappearing once you put it in your mouth.
I got myself a milo shaved ice, which was freshly ground up and topped off with milo powder and condensed milk, yum!
Not that cheap though at $4.20, but so very good especially on a hot day.
They've got other more traditional flavours like sesame, mango and green tea, but who doesn't love milo!
There is some seating at this outlet so you can enjoy your desserts freshly prepared.
This place is ok.
I had the curry chicken.
I wasn't expecting bones, but the curry itself was good :)) I'll try something else next time.
The Lao ban style beancurd.
But this version is much sweeter.
The only reason why we ate this is because it is the one that is still opened at 3am.
Great, great desserts and a yummy place to get local and Indonesian specialities.
Growing up with all the traditional Kueh - it's always nice to walk by and just grab a few - even if it's just one or 2 pieces.
From Ondeh-Ondeh to modern cream cakes - this chain offers quite a selection.

What I Love: My fave ones are the traditional options - from Ondeh-Ondeh, Talam Ubi, Kueh Salat, Dodol, Kueh Bugis, Corn Kueh, Kueh Jongkong, Sago Melaka  to Pulut Inti - it's really a plethora of flavors.
If you want something less traditional, you could get the famous Pandan Sponge Cake, Swissroll and a few other cakes.
Prices are affordable - and they'll pack it really nicely for you - depending on whether you're taking some overseas or for a party.
I brought quite a bit of Kueh to Australia - and they were totally fine!
What I Don't Love: The good ones or certain types finish pretty early - so good to buy in bulk or get down earlier in the day.
Among my friends, no one had the time to queue to check out the hype and someone has to sacrifice right?
I heard about the snaking queue and honestly was expecting out-of-the-world doughnuts.
I mean, look at the length of the queue at 4pm!
Even at this hour, I had to wait for 50 mins.
Don't get me wrong.
The original doughnuts taste good.
Something like you could get at Donut Factory (okay, I know they have closed).
Soft and fluffy.
But they are just... very ordinary.
So wait for the novelty to die down and buy.
It's really not worth the queuing time:)
For years people have been hoping to try the famous Krispy Kreme in Singapore as it's fame has travelled a long way from the USA.
Now it's finally here!
For me personally I find it too sweet and sugary.
It's nice still, don't get me wrong, but a far cry from those in the US.
I think the franchising quality has to be upped one level.
Queued up for ~15mins and bought these KK donuts as it was the craze!
My family and some friends all felt that it was waaaaay too sweet!
Personally felt like I was a step closer to diabetes with every bite... Just imagine a sugar explosion in your mouth!
Don't think that it's worth the money and time...
I will not buy these donuts again.
If you really really are curious to try it, perhaps you can when you fly to other countries where they sell it cheaper :-) *E.g.
Thailand - Bangkok (27 donuts for SGD20) 1/5 stars for me!
Frolick sports a yummy green color that pops out to attract your attention.
They have the usual yogurt and toppings.
But what I did love was the blueberry-flavoured yogurt.
The place is too small to accommodate people who want to hang around the place but if you're like me who likes walking while eating their yogurt, then this maybe a place for you.
For an average of $8 for a regular cup, you get your choice of either a regular yogurt or the blueberry one and a topping of your choice.
I opted for the blueberry yogurt and muesli toppings.
I do think both flavours went well together.
The blueberry complemented the muesli, which was mainly composed of dried fruits.
Hence, I could say that my first attempt to mix them was a success-and I'm glad I did not choose chocolate or caramel or butterscotch.
For me, Frolick was there at a perfect time when I was looking for comfort food on a different level.
So it is best enjoyed maybe on a weekly basis.
The Icing Room serves a range of desserts, such as cakes and muffins.
The waiters are dressed in pink candy-like costumes (which I always disliked) and the service standards at Compass Point are rather good.
They are friendly and helpful, giving you recommendations and whats not.
Sometimes, they can be a little pushy in selling their products though.
The Icing Room is also known for their DIY birthday cake decoration.
There are three sizes of cakes to choose from and you can purchase their decoration kit which includes pipping bags with coloured creams, some sweet decorations and all.
I've seen kids as young as 3 years old decorating the cake for their grandparents.
It's a pretty cool activity and it helps build creativity too!
In terms of cake standards, I wouldn't say its damn good.
It's just normal and can get a little too sweet for my liking.
This food treat that I'm about to share with you can be found almost everywhere in Singapore.
And frankly, this unique way of enjoying this cold dessert is so exciting; you just can't get enough of it.
You may have seen those ice cream kiosks around selling blocks of ice cream, sandwiched between wafers or bread.
This is potong ice cream.
Locals may have a different term for this, but just to make it clear to anyone non-local, I would coin it as "Potong Ice Cream" so you'd know what I'm talking about.
The first time I had a taste of this local treat is during my walk with a friend along Orchard Road.
I had cookies and cream at that time, placed between wafer sheets.
Some prefer the bread, but for me, I get to enjoy this dessert with wafers because I get the flavor and creaminess of the ice cream, and that crunchy bite along with it.
Whenever my friends would come and visit me here, I always take them to a Potong Kiosk because this is a perfect, laid back way to enjoy a local dessert while hanging out with them.
For just $1, you'll definitely be satisfied in this delicious block of ice cream with your choice of wafer or bread.
I'm not sure if the reviews of Sour Sally from Orchard share the same sentiments, but the Jurong Point outlet was disappointing for me.
I saw sour sally while walking around Jurong Point one day and decided to give it a try.
Now, while I am not a regular yogurt eater, I do feel that this Sour Sally outlet in Jurong does seem to top the list of poor yogurts in Singapore.
I ordered the small "twist" with mango toppings (twist refers to green tea mixed with original) at a student special price (10% off for students) at around $5.
Pricey was my first thought and "hopefully it's good" was my second.
I dug in and found it to be extremely watery and has poor consistency unlike regular yogurts.
At that point, I wondered if I had bought sour ice instead of yogurt.
The mango toppings seemed to be slightly over-ripe, but not a problem for me.
To commend on the green tea flavor, it does not taste much like green tea and does seem to be poorly flavored.
About 5 minutes in, I gave up as a significant part of the yogurt melted into watery consistency.
I won't come back to this place.
Ordered Kolo Noodle and Nyonya Chicken Rice.
So the Kolo noodle is way too dry and so we asked for some soup and after 3 times of reminder to the aunty, she said there is only 1 Chef and he will make ours after some customer.
Came the soup, it is hot water with some soya source, oil and spring onions in it.
You can see the soya source is not even stirred properly.
Just too ignorant and didn't know what is right or wrong, no common sense.
Located inside the Heartland Mall where we go have lunch sometimes; it was still too early for the shuttle (work provides the service) to get back so we wandered around the mall.
No storefront, it is a kiosk.
The baked goods looked enticing.
The prices are great so I justified my purchases on these points: I was still hungry, it's cheap, I ran in the morning, and I need chocolate.
Cash only.
Both of the zebra bun and chocolate / custard bun was dry and the chocolate tastes like it has been inside its flaky shell for hella long.
I did not want a refund on money but I wanted my calories back.
This is a bar and restaurant tucked away in the hollywood part of universal studios.
The service is terrible, but the only redeeming factor about this place is that it is relatively empty compared to the rest of USS, and it is nice to take a breather from the crowds.
I ordered the caesar salad (18 bucks), and it was actually surprisingly good by Singapore salad standards.
At the very least, they had anchovies, and the dressing was flavorful.
My friend ordered nachos which he really liked.
The house white wine was delicious as well.
Judging from the lack of customers, I don't think this place will be around for long, but if you are an easy spender, and want some okay food at an inflated price in peace in USS, this is your place.
'Meh.
I've experienced better' really sums up this place for me.
I had been looking forward to try their buns for awhile as the constant sweet smells that waft from this bakery everytime I walk past it are soooo tempting.
But sadly, it wasn't as good as I expected.

In their defence it might be because I imagine it to taste a certain way before I had even tried it based on the smell and the cinnamon buns that I had had in the past, but the chocolate and cinnamon buns from this place that I had were so so sweet, honestly I couldn't taste much past the sugar that was in the bun.
It really didn't do it for me, but I admit it might do it for others!
To me it was more a desert than a cinnamon bun or roll - which should be more bread than cake like.
Lady M has been on my mind for a while and I had never got the chance to taste their crepe cakes when they were in Marina Square.
Luckily, they came closer to the West and there is no reason skipping the cafe now.
Cafe is conveniently located in Westgate at the same level of Jurong East MRT station control exit.
Interior of Lady M give a comfortable feeling to diners with its white theme color and spacious environment.
Dusted with the earthy green fine matcha powder on each and every layer of the paper thin crepe with the natural bitter aftertaste.
I'm pretty impress by the thin crepe layers spread with Japanese style pastry cream on every layers and was so grateful that the texture was so good that it literally melts in my mouth.
Green Tea Mille Crepes - $9 The boutique exclusive, only available in West Gate!
The twenty thin layers of handmade crepes and refreshingly light chestnut-kissed pastry cream sandwiched in between the layers with .
Topped with powdered sugar and with good notes of roasted chestnuts, this is indeed a rare find!
Marron Mille Crepes - $9 Skipping the cold beverages, I opted for Chamomile Dream in a pot at $5.50.
It was indeed good drink for me to keep my stomach warm as I was having stomach upset.
Tea is plain and Sweetness can be adjusted with the sugar cubes given.
Chamomile Dream - $5.50 My friend order the caffe latte to pair along with the crepes.
To be frank, with just crepes and drinks, we were really done for the night, skipping the dinner.
Mille Crepe cakes are my favorite and with the choices of flavour chosen, I would say the sweetness was at right amount.
I dont mind visiting again for other flavours of cakes or even their pastries.
Before my visit to this outlet, Lady M was in my mind for quite some time, as I wanted to try out the cakes.
Most of the times I walked past this place, it was crowded so finally with another yelper, I got to visit this outlet with only 4 customers including ourselves.
You would expect service to be top notch since there was a same number of staff .
1:1 ratio, that shouldn't be too difficult right?
Instead, the staff seemed to have their mind elsewhere as they were standing at a corner most of the time chit chatting away.
Lots of waving and calling out for them, it took a while to grab hold of their attention.
A few seconds more I would have walked over to call them.
As some of you know that I am very particular in customer service and for this, this is completely unacceptable.
Imagine if this is a full house, can't imagine how worse the service is.
Even calling for the bill was a challenge.
As for the cakes, they are pretty decent.
I have tasted similar cakes in other countries, I find this to be maybe 6,5/10, the price is around $9 per slice, a bit expensive for my liking.
At least the portion is reasonable.
Overall, I am not in a hurry to return and if I do, I hope to see an improvement in the service.
Whether there are customers or not, the staff has to keep in mind that job comes first, they can leave their conversation during their break or after office hours.
The milk crepe tasted great and came in a decent portion.
I had the green tea version.
The cream went very well with each thin crepe and the top layer had sprinkling of powder.
The amount of green tea flavour was just right to satisfy green tea fans like me and also make it appealing to those who may not particularly like green tea.
The reason why I didn't give more stars is that I find the price a tad expensive even though the quality is good and the service can be improved, for e.g.
Staff can be more attentive and quicker, starting with putting a sign to indicate which side the queue starts from at the entrance!
Would agree with the low ratings many fellow Yelpers have given this one-truly overly hyped and overpriced.
Ordered the set ($35++) which came with 2 cakes, 2 drinks and 2 choux puffs.
The crepe cakes were not anything special-though we had the seasonal specials which were the chocolate raspberry and the passion fruit.
If anything, the cakes got cloying after a while and did not appeal both visually and taste wise.
The choux puffs were an ultimate disappointment, with the white chocolate shells being too hard and the pastry itself almost a rock.
The cream inside failed to impress-save for the fact that it was especially hard and left a deep impression as something one would find in the frozen section of a supermarket (on sale).
Overall, I'm glad I made the trip down to confirm the bad reviews.
Similarly, I've tried it once, but never again.
Highly questionable hygiene standards.
Overpriced and quality is 1/5.
Dropped a sandwich on the floor and I actually believe they attempted to put it back on the rack for sale.
Definitely not on my list of bread shops to visit anytime in the near future.
Once you have had Yamazaki bread, you would never eat anything else again.

Previously found only in Japanese shopping centers and supermarkets, the west-enders have now been treated to good Japanese style bread as Yamazaki opens a branch in the new JCube shopping mall at Jurong East.
It is no surprise when my mom in law exclaimed her delight at the wonderful taste and texture of the bread and questioned why she has never seen the brand before.
The bread is soft and you will find Japanese favorites - whole red bean - in your bread instead of your usual pork floss favorites.
I had cravings for beancurd and bought four bowls from Bean Basic as it was the nearest soy stall in the area.
I was too lazy to walk over to Mr Bean.
Besides soya bean drinks, they have beancurd in four flavours - plain, pandan, mango and strawberry.
Might as well try out all four, I thought.
I got them all cold because I like my beancurd chilled, not warm.
The plain  flavour was okay and slid down my throat  nicely.
I can't say the same for mango and strawberry - they came in a nice canary yellow and candyfloss pink, but there the taste didn't match up.
There was no hint of the fruits!
The owner probably just added food colouring.
The pandan was the best - fragrant and tasted good.
Strong presence of pandan.
I would come back here for the pandan beancurd, but not for the other flavours.
Had Bakerzin with my friends at Paragon a few times.
One thing I am a big fan of are obviously their desserts!
I must say their souffle which costs less than $12 is quite worth it and quite well done.
Their cakes are also not bad.

As I have already tried two of the best (Ladurée and Pierre Hermé') macaroons in the world already, my standards for macaroons are quite high and Bakerzin's macaroons may not be as awesome as Ladurée and Pierre Hermé, but it was still considered quite delicious.

Or maybe because I am a sucker for desserts, as long as it looks nice and smell, doesn't fall apart, have a balance taste of the flavor and have a nice sticky chewy center, I will consider it a good macaroon.
Their mooncakes are also quite delicious and if I am not wrong, mid-autumn festival will be coming quite soon so it's quite a good time to see what kind of mooncake they will put out this year.
Their main courses are also not bad.
I have tried their fish and pasta before and it's quite healthy and delicious.
It's a good place for a small group of friends to hang out for lunch, high tea or dinner.
Affordable place with decent Chinese food.
I like the noodle dishes.
The noodles are cooked to the right softness.
I prefer the soupy options than the ones with gravy which I find a bit salty.
I recommend the custard buns and shrimp dumplings.
You can make your meal a set by topping up $2 for carrot cake and yuan yang paste.
The branch in Clementi is open until quite late- I saw customers around 10pm too.
Late night supper/dessert, anyone?
This little Portuguese bakery in the basement of 313@Somerset artfully displays its wares behind glass for all to see.
However I didn't see much space for baking, so the goods are most likely not made onsite, which probably explains much of what I am going to say.
So far, I've tried 10 of its pastries.
First was the Ham & Cheese Panike.
It was heavy and doughy and the (chicken) ham and cheese were very mild tasting.
The crumb had a slightly buttery flavour so it was slightly better than the contents.
The (chicken) rissole (fried dough with stuffing) was alright, but the outside was a little greasy, and the interior less creamy than I would have liked (it was a little dry, actually).
The coconut bun had a tasty candied shredded coconut topping, but it was let down by its crumb which was heavy, dense and flavourless.
The chocolate "doughssant" (aka cronut) had a rich chocolate coating (whose taste had splashes of gianduja [chocolate-hazelnut]).
Its body was acceptable but was rather far from the light flakiness that croissant clones aspire to.
The strawberry doughssant was worse, with artificial tasting strawberry cream and with a stale and un-flaky body (I had it on a different day so maybe the chocolate ones were bad that day too).
I didn't even care to finish mine.
The cream eclair's body was a little stale and quite dry, though the cream topping was alright.
The pineapple cornucopia had a very heavy crumb which was hard to bite - a small drop of cream actually dropped onto my shirt as my teeth struggled to tear off a bite-sized morsel of the cornucopia.
The pineapple was very hard to taste and the cream was dry.
The Palmier was also disappointing, being obviously stale.
It probably tasted much better when fresh, and the texture would've resembled the wonderfully flaky cheese sticks that Le Cafe used to make in the 90s but doesn't anymore.
The custard that was between the pastry layers was alright, but didn't taste very fresh.
The Berlin Ball puzzled me at first, not least since it looked very different from Berliners (being filled with custard instead of jam) but I've since learned that this is the Portuguese variant.
Once again the dough was heavy (in fact many of their doughs taste like something that'd come out of a traditional Singaporean Chinese bakery - even if the filling is different).
The custard was a little too sweet and heavy, though that might be how it's supposed to be.

The Portuguese egg tart started off with a pleasant cinammon hit, and the pastry was warm (the lady took it from the back instead of one of the cold ones from behind the glass) but the pastry was rather mushy and remained flaky only at the sides.
In fact, KFC's Portuguese egg tarts have a better crust.
The custard was alright - milky and full-flavoured, but not quite silky enough and just a touch too sweet.
While the quality of the products here isn't very good, $1.20 each for mini pastries (and $3 for 3) is a pretty good deal.
And we're all tired of the Japanese bakeries and traditional Singaporean Chinese bakeries that we find everywhere, aren't we?
And we can't find Tiong Bahru Bakery or Artisan Boulangerie Co everywhere (and would like a break from French artifice occasionally).
They couldn't have come up with a more apt name for their business.
This tiny store near Bukit Gombak MRT station offers a wide variety of halal pastries, cakes and cookies to satisfy your sweet tooth.
Their mini savouries are flaky and disappear in two bites.
It would be better if they had spicier fillings!
For a small store, Indulge Patisserie has an extensive range of cakes to choose from.
There are mini cakes for those who just want to sample different flavours or have a small dessert, and bigger ones for celebrations.
Their best-seller, Chocolate Fantasy, is rich and chocolatey with a smooth texture.
Customers can also place orders for favours with the store.
It helps that while the products here are good, the prices don't break the bank.
Approximately about 2 years ago, I was introduced by my uncle to this cold and frozen taufufa.
Initially, I was a little bit skeptical for the fact that it is cold.
I don't take cold taufufa; it is just not my thing.
I always have my taufufa fresh and hot back in KL.
Since I saw a crowd of young and even old people waiting for their cold taufufa, I gave it a shot.
My mother on the other hand, was skeptical like me as well but we took a step to brave through our curiosity and tried it.
At first, I wasn't used to it as it's cold but trust me on this when I say that this is one of the best taste taufufa I ever had in my entire life!
Well at the moment, it is the best cold tautufa I ever had.
It is not too sweet nor is it too bland.
It is just nice for my liking, which is quite surprising as I never discovered this dessert joint.
The best part would be the soft beancurd and for the fact that it is organic (seriously you will never be able to taste coloring and preservatives).
I went to the point where I didn't want to leave Skudai, Johor for this taufufa.
This was how bad I wanted to consume the taufufa.
Little did I know that Kulai Lou Pan has opened many branches across Malaysia.
So, if you wish to pamper your sweet tooth, head on to Kulai Lou Pan.
In the Klang Valley, there are 2 branches which are in Puchong and Kepong!
Like any gourmet bakery, this charming little shop bakes tasty goodies, fit for a king.
You'll find perfect-looking buns & loaves of bread and pretty cakes here.
Surprisingly the prices here were not that high.
I like the scones which are 4 for $3.10.
I bought some baguettes from them once while on my way home after a meeting.
They were perfectly crispy on the outside and deliciously soft on the inside, just the way I like them.
I've been coming back here  for baguettes ever since.
Managed by Four Leaves' Group of Companies, the bakery has promotional prices for selected items from time to time, and their cakes taste good too.
My favourite is the Coco Exotic which has a little crunch to it.
YUMM!
I have been limiting my self to eating bread beside wheat bread.
So I basically never bought a bread in this shop.
But unlike normal bakeries, they have another corner selling HK style dim sum like carrot cake, chicken wing, Wife biscuit and etc.
And that's where my money goes to.
Carrot cake is another of my weak point so normally I can't resist buying carrot cake if the shop sells one.
The carrot cake they sell is not the kind I like.
They have chinese sausage inside which to me is not a good combination.
Once in awhile I will still get one to eat.
There are promotions going on everyday after 5.30pm so you will see working adults buying some bread home for breakfast the next day.
Freeze Bun are also available for own consumption at home.
It was refreshing to have a break from the usual chain bakeries in Singapore.
This bakery offers a variety of bread with an impressive number of unique ingredients and health benefits.
The loaves are affordable whereas the individual bread can be a bit pricey.
I tried the bamboo charcoal loaf and found it quite bland.
The chocolate buns fared much better.
Hope that this bakery will stay around to increase choices for consumers, especially health-conscious ones.
The egg-tarts here are to die for!
Always fresh, the tarts are made without lard and thus don't have the lardy oily taste that some egg tarts have.
Not overly sweet, the custard is smooth and light, and the pastry is flaky and crisp.
Their tarts are made without preservatives and artificial colouring and they maintain their level of freshess by having a special promotion at the end of the day to clear the remaining tarts.
They also offer soya egg tarts for the more health conscious consumer,  it doesn't taste as good to me but it should appeal to those who are a little more health conscious.

There are also durian, banana and chocolate egg tarts for variety - I prefer the traditional egg tarts but appreciate these fun additions :) Their savoury pastries are also yummy and not too oily - my favourites are the Roast Chicken Polo Bun and the Mushroom Chicken Pie.
Although a small establishment that only does take-aways, it is definately worth a try if you are in the area.
After finishing my Friday's mass prayer at a mosque, my tummy started to rumble as though it's complaining for food.
In response, I went to a nearby bakery shop called 'Swee Heng Bakery'.
Upon entering, I was greeted with a whiff of delicious pastry that sent my tummy into frenzy.
The store offers pastries of different shapes, sizes and tastes for the hungry like myself.
The area is quite spacious and well lit enough for customers to seek pastries with ease.
In short, it's a simple bakery with modest selection of foodstuff for the masses, which is savoury as well.
I made my choices of pastry that include few cakes, sweet buns and bread to bring home.
The staff was pleasant in handling my payment so the service given was okay.
I began to leave while munching on a scrumptious bun to satisfy my tummy before eating fully at home.
Swee Heng Bakery's (Halal) opening hours: 11am - 9pm.
One of my favorite restaurants in Aeon Bukit Indah.
When I get hungry, I mostly run for two things : Local dishes or fast food.
I rarely went for any Italian cuisine restaurant or others just because I had too.
It normally depends on my moods or craves.
:p Anyhow, what I love about this restaurant is its variety types of menu - basically offers every types of rice and mee.
I crave for them so much when I'm hungry.
I believe that they satisfy my tummy well instead of other cool or rare meals.
The ambiance of this restaurant is quite fancy and suitable for families.
With variety types of menu, this restaurant totally serves my family well!
The price is affordable too because it values our satisfaction and taste bud.
Feeling exhausted and hungry after my morning jog, my tummy yearned for something yummy.
As I walked past a corner of a mall, my nose picked up an aroma that was so mesmerising till I followed its trail.
Upon reaching its origin, my senses kicked in high gear as I encountered the sight before me.
My eyes captured a staff making hot waffles near a counter in a bakery shop called 'Nom's Bistro'.
As I approached nearer, my face simply got fixated on the steamy waffles like a salivating dog.
The staff looked up in surprise as I stared at the succulent pastry that she's making.
She asked for my order with a grin and I yelped my answer for two waffles.
She proceeded to make them while I looked around the place.
The bakery has a sense of chic and professionalism.
Fresh pastry aroma emanated from the back room where bakers were busy baking for the day's sale.
Baker figurines and doughnuts adorn the upper part of the store against a white backdrop for aesthetic reason.
The atmosphere was air-con cool intertwined with the steamy heat emerging from the pastries that came fresh out of the oven.
A sudden whiff of waffle aroma came up to me.
At that moment, I knew that my order was ready.
The staff put butter and strawberries on top of the waffles and presented it to me.
I paid her and got ready to gobble the waffles down.
The butter melted like lava snaking around the waffle and strawberries, which gave a distinct fragrance of dairy and berries.
I took a bite and a surge of rich flavour gripped me from top to bottom.
I shook it off like a wet dog and ravenously ate the delicious waffles to the last piece.
Once done, my body felt energised and my tummy became full.
My tiredness slowly dissipated that's replaced with renewed vigour.
What's left to do was striding off home like a happy dog with a bone.
Nom's Bistro opening hours: 8am - 10:30pm.
You will be able to spot two type of product when you walk pass the store.
They are the pineapple tart and spicy prawn roll.
The store gave me the impression that they are very confident in their products since they only sell like mainly these two pastries.
The star of the store is the pineapple tarts which has a bunch of loyal customer purchasing even when it is not Chinese New Year.
It is also a hot favourite during Chinese New Year.
Orders need to be made as early as possible as I heard there are people who are unable to reserve one on the last week before Chinese New Year.
Overall, the pineapple filling is not that sour and biscuit is not overly soft which break at touch.
One of a few outlets, Bake Inc is a cheaper alternative to 'branded' bakery outlets such as Four Leaves and BreadTalk for local asian bread.
Taste wise however, it can't compare - it just seems to be missing something.
Their mexican coffee bun for example isn't as fragrant, and the coffee on top of the bun is piled on too thick.
The bun itself also doesn't have the buttery goodness that the one at Four Leaves has.
They do however offer a few unique choices that I haven't seen elsewhere, such as the 'genie' bun - which is a hot dog bun wrapped in floss and seaweed - it isn't half bad!
Cakes aren't great either, very average.
Not bad options for pastries.
Have come here a few times to get certain select pastries, etc., though, I would think twice about certain specific options.
Some are really creamy and kinda averagey.
What I Love: It's nice to walk by in the morning, and have the smell of fresh baked pastries and cakes welcome you.
Yummm.
They have quite a few options for sandwiches, rolls, bread, cakes, pastries and local delicacies.
They even have a waffle station - where they do their own fresh waffles - based on what flavors you want.
Pretty common in certain bakeries all over the nation.
Pretty reasonable and affordable - in terms of prices.
Apart from their sandwiches, have tried their pork sausage bun, pork floss bun and pizza pastry thing.
Yummmy!
What I Don't Love: The taste of some stuff can be kinda suspect.
So, sample or buy small portions.
Not a huge fan of their cakes.
I LOVE THEIR MACARONS!!!
Okay, I can't imagine how I haven't written a review yet.
But their macarons are lovely!
Granted, I have not made a trip down to Laduree yet, or tasted a TWG macaron lately, but these are pretty good.
$2.50 is also a pretty reasonable price (given that I paid $3 for one at Patisserie G at Millenia Walk..) Having wandered around Pasar Bella today (yay for soft launch of farmers' market!)
and seen a plethora of bakeries, I was tempted to procure a sweet treat from one of those many choices.
One in particular, Bonheur Patisserie, had been so kind as to give me a sample of a mini strawberry macaron.
However, it was a little on the chewy side and lacking the crisp of a good macaron.
Hence, I wandered over to my trusty favourite macaron place!
ET Artisan is located along the Grandstand, near the end nearer to Pasar Bella.
There are some really nice relaxing armchairs near the window.
Apart from excelling at macarons, the bakery also makes the cutest cakes..
I love their decor!
There was a carousel cake in particular that I fell in love with.
And a sea creature-themed one!
I've had their yuzu and rose flavours.
Yuzu was a nice refreshing citrusy touch, while rose was certainly very strongly rose flavoured (I like it!)
and the sweetness was tempered by some raspberry jam in the middle of the buttercream.
Crisp on the outside and with a nice bite to the chewy centre, these are clouds of delight!
Just a note of warning: do NOT ever get their cheesecake (I sincerely hope they've taken it off the menu or improved on it), it was really awful and artificial/rubbery-tasting.
But I forgive them for that sad experience since they produce such awesome macarons.
:) I want to try all the rest of the flavours!!
choc hazelnut and matcha next..
This place deserves to be 5 stars because they took my cold, hard, macaroon hating heart and crushed it into a bajillion trillion million gazillion little pieces and sprinkled them into the wind.
I am now a lover of many a kind of macaroons but let me tell you, they all stemmed from these little babies right here.
Their macaroons are cold, sweet and delicious - just like ice cream.
I first tried them at a friends place and immediately took down the address and went there the next day to see if they were just as good as they had been the night before.
I even brought along my sister for double confirmation.
Could it be?
A macaroon we'd actually like?!?!
My sister was exactly the same as me and we both generally stay away from macaroons (which means a lot because there isn't many sweet things we don't like).
KABOOM.
ITS AMAZING.
MIND BLOWN.
WHITE FLAG IS IN THE AIR.
We came home we a few boxes that night and marvelled at how delicious they were with our parents.
And from that day onward it became the treats we'd bring into the house whenever we had guests visiting.
THANK YOU!
THANK YOU FOR FILLING OUR LIVES WITH YOUR DELICIOUS MACAROONS!
We are so grateful.
How soft and chewy would you want it to be?
Or would you prefer it to be at different levels of crunchy.
Famous Amos can definitely present you a variety of cookies, ranging from soft and chewy to crunchy.
I actually like it both and it's nice that I get to have the best of both worlds.
Since it's just for me, the generic packaging is expected.
But it's nice to know that they have options for gift giving.
So if I'm thinking about giving a cooking as a present, I'd know where to go.
But for me, it's all about the aroma.
It's like Famous Amos is the edible version of an Axe commercial.
I'll just be walking buy and then poof!
I'm looking into their glass case display of mounds and mounds of cookies!
We may have a cookie monster inside of us, wouldn't you agree?
This is definitely a perfect take home gift for your friends, loved ones, and especially kids on a Friday night of after they have done well in their exams.
Black carrot cake - nice, plenty of charred bits.
Could do with a bit more chai poh.
2 eggs per plate is plenty!
Could do without the egg shells though.
Popiah - Unique taste in it.
Can't place a finger on what it is.
My friends wanted to come over at my place to watch an important soccer match together on TV.
Apart from drinks and snacks galore like chips, fries and cashew nuts already available at my home, I thought of getting some cakes to sweeten the tongue.
Hence, I visited a bakery shop named 'Angie The Choice'.
It offers some selection of delectable cakes that I spotted before.
The place exhibits a modest setting against a backdrop of pastries arranged on shelves and in glass casings.
I pondered upon a display of cakes within a glass casing, which a staff approached me for any assistance.
After spending some time thinking, I decided to buy a cheesecake, chocolate cake and pandan cake.
The staff helped to put them in small boxes to carry out and I made my payments at the counter.
The service was satisfactory and the choice of available cakes was decent.
In summation, it was a worthwhile buying experience, which I don't mind returning for another pastry.
Angie The Choice's opening hours: 10am - 9:30pm.
This is one of my favourite bakeries.
There's another bakery with cheaper stuff within the vicinity, but Champion Bread products score more points with my tastebuds.
Freshly baked daily, Champion Bread offers an insane spread of bread and sweet buns.
I used to have their egg mayonnaise and chicken ham bun for breakfast every morning.
And if you love cranberries as much as I do, you'll also adore their cranberry loaves and cranberry sugar twists.
They come with a more generous amount of cranberries than a lot of other bakeries!
This branch doesn't offer whole cream cakes, only the rectangular sliced ones.
Champion Bread has a bigger branch that does sell delicious cream cakes near Bukit Gombak MRT station.
I guess they try to be different by adding curry powder to their white carrot cake.
Their black version is nothing close to the good black versions out there.
It's ok la.
Different, but if you are looking for a traditional carrot cake fix, look elsewhere.
Sometimes...I think...don't fix what ain't broken.
I never liked durian products although I take the durian fruit.
The market has been coming out with real durian meat product that is equivalent to eating the real durian.
One of them is the Durian Pancake offers by Four Season Durian.
Trust me, I didn't expect the pancake to taste like that before I tried.
The crepe is very crispy and durian meat is cold and delicious.
Very good combination.
I won't reject buying it again if there is no queue.
I observed customer buying in bulk, like 5, 10 pieces at one go and enjoy the pancake at home in comfort.
Bought a $10 earl grey chiffon cake before, it's disappointing.
The cake wasn't soft and it tastes more of orange than earl grey.
Decided to give it another chance.
This time, we bought a honey brioche and coffee bun.
The honey brioche is disappointing.
When I sliced it in half, I can see flour spots in it.
It's more obvious in the picture after I toasted it.
Hey, c'mon, this is a professional bakery.
This brioche cost a lot more than other bakeries in Tampines Mall.
Yet I'm get bread made by amateurs.
This is bread, you are supposed to knead the dough, and not cake where you might just fold in the flour resulting in unmixed flour.
The coffee bun... utter disappointment.
I would rather not comment further.
Having known for the desserts, my friends and I decided to give it a go.
Sadly, the food and service at Vivocity was disappointing.
Service staffs greeted us when we walked in, but it didn't feel sincere at all.
It was not only hard to grab the attention of the staffs to order our food, almost all our first choice on the menu was apparently 'sold out' or 'not available'.
We were there for an early dinner, about 5pm, so there shouldn't be an excuse of 'sold out'.
If so many items are unavailable, then might as well put a sticker or something on the menu to indicate its availability, instead of customers re-thinking about the next food.
