I asked for a little spicy for my pasta, and I was given something amounting to a volcano explosion.
It was nearly impossible to eat.
It was so spicy even my friends who had higher threshold couldn't take it.
Ridiculous.
Perhaps its just this outlet, but I'm not going back there again.
Bakerzin Enjoyed a slow dinner by myself and ordered my usual choice - seafood linguine.
The menu said "with a touch of spice" so I asked for more spice in mine.
Food came relatively fast and still piping hot.
Good!
Their version has cherry tomatoes in it so there's a sweetness yet tanginess blend.
Nice.
Seafood is also fresh so that's good.
Unfortunately, my 'spicier' request was not spicy at all!
Would have enjoyed it more if it's spicer I reckon.
All in all a good meal and would return again.
A little squeeze.
Weird smell within the outlet.
Alas, there are saving graces due to nice desserts.
I was looking forward to my Bailey's Soufflé but they don't serve it no more.
A little disappointed.
Saw the Mango Passion Soufflé and decided to give it a short.
Not too bad.
The Soufflé was as per their usual standard.
Fluffy, light and moist inside.
Except this time is was with mango and passion fruit to taste.
As I let my teeth cut through the already soft and fluffy Soufflé, I tasted the sugar bits and it gives it more body.
I should come back for this again when my sweet tooth beckons.
Looking for some snacks to bring home, I stumbled upon a bakery shop called 'Ecreative' that sells an assortment of pastries.
The aroma of cakes filled its ambience till it drew me to its shelves of delightful goodies.
It's a simple bakery shop no less, which is typical of those commonly found elsewhere.
Nevertheless, what differs from one another is the choice of pastries offered.
The aroma emanating from the food represents its distinct flavour that entices customers like myself to savour it.
In reaction, I took a tray and pincers in order to select some pastries.
I chose a couple of buns that contained fillings of tuna, custard, vanilla cream topped with chocolate rice, sweetened butter and other food flavours.
Once done, I paid for them at the counter before they're being stuffed into bags for me to bring back.
The pastries were delicious and the service given was okay.
Ecreative's opening hours: 11am - 9pm.
Awfully Chocolate is famous for their chocolate cakes.
My favourite has got to be their Chocolate Banana cake.
I also like to take away their Hei Ice Cream which is great for a lonely night with a good book or a movie.
I also tried their Cold Poached Chocolate which basically tastes like chocolate mousse with flavoured alcoholic whipped cream served on top.
Their dark chocolate truffles may be a little expensive (since I paid $2 for ONE piece once) but the quality of the chocolate justifies the price.

Definitely a must try place for chocolate lovers, the only reason why I gave it 3 stars is because their stores often lack enough seats so it's quite depressing to always go and find a spot to sit down and savour their chocolate.
I wish I didn't have to remove a star as I do want to like this place.
My earlier 4 star review on the food still stands, but is averaged down to 3 stars because of 2 star service: Cedele needs more wait staff who don't act like clueless high school part timers.
And despite a fair number of staff standing around, it was difficult to get their attention to take our orders.
It's almost like they're trying to avoid eye contact without looking like they're doing it on purpose; and even after being asked multiple times, our waters did not get refilled.
Tables were left empty for too long even with a growing queue of customers waiting to be seated.
Never been a fan of Breadtalk and their overly fancy and overly priced breads.
I also blame them for infecting the bread industry as even local neighbourhood bakeries jumped on the Breadtalk styled bandwagon.
So when I came across Baker Talent, I was initially skeptical and put off by the ridiculously long queues.
Yet, we should never slam anything unless we tried it, so one fine day when the queue wasnt too bad, I decided to give it a try.
Impressed is what I can say.
They do not bombard you with too many different varieties or overly complicated bake choices.
Instead, you have a few basic flavours that are all very very good.
Cranberry Cheese, Mushroom, Pineapple or Chocolate Bolo buns, etc.
Simple good flavours at very very reasonable prices.
Nothing is over $1.
Goes to show, you can still offer simple yet delicious food at reasonable prices.
Something some of the bigger food companies seem to have forgotten.
There's always a bit of a queue here, but that's probably because they take an extremely long time to make just one bubble tea.

Besides the array of baked goods, which I hear from friends are quite good, I go there occasionally for the bubble tea, and mainly because it's conveniently located next to Foodfare, where you might be for lunch.
It's good bubble tea, but it's hardly worth the wait.
Imagine having to wait 10 minutes, when you're the only person waiting for bubble tea, and there are 3 people making it.
The service isn't great either, so I'm unsure why there are always lots of people here.
The pastries must be really good, so I guess you should try them, though they're usually filled with custard, cream or other really unhealthy things.
If you really must, go for the fruit based bubble teas.
Lychee, peach and passionfruit are amongst the best they have.
Basically, meh.
I've stayed in Choa Chu Kang for more than 7 years now, and this shop space has changed hands at least once a year.
Baker Talent has been here for quite awhile now, and there is always a queue, no matter the time of day.
I used to think it was popular for their bubble teas, but after trying one that was average I realised it was the buns that were luring the crowd.
I decided to try their custard and butter ones.
Both actually tasted good, but not good enough that I would jump in line every time I walk past.
The buns are quite cheap, often below $1.
The staff is friendly earlier in the day, and not so when they are tired or busy.
For most people, when it comes to egg tarts, its the HK style dim sum ones or Portugese style ones that comes to mind.
Yet, a local shop decided to give it a delightful Singapore twist.
The result are cuter and colorful tarts with 16 different flavors.

Their main shop is located in Lorong Kilat just off Jalan Jurong Kechil, fast becoming another foodie enclave like Holland V. I must admit when I first came across them I wasnt too impressed, after all I'm not really an egg tart fan.
Maybe its because its smaller.
Maybe its because the pastry is thinner.
But I think its probably because there's a lot more filling compared to pastry.
I find the fruit flavors ones which are popular a bit icky but thats just me.
I prefer the cheese, mushroom and chicken ones which taste like mini quiches.
Not bad at all.
They also have kiosks in IMM, City Square Mall, Marine Parade and NEX.
Located near the first floor car park entrance is this bustling Crystal Jade My Bread bakery.
Famous for their dim sum, Crystal Jade's bakery is also no less famous.

The staff here all speak Cantonese and are very polite and pretty much encourage you get as many buns as possible after 8pm when their Point-of-Sale (POS) Systems automatically give you a 20% discount.
The staff will be able to tell you how much each item costs after the discount.
I love their char siew polo buns.
It is sweet on the outside, but fluffy AND NOT DRY on the inside.I also absolutely love egg white egg tarts.
Alot more milky and creamier than the normal egg tarts I feel.
I've been an absolute fan of the cupcakes for years.
I put them in the fridge overnight and the next morning, they taste just like Sara Lee Pound cakes you get from the supermarket.
Of course, with a hard chocolately top layer!
My parents love the wife biscuits (lau po bing) and they are usually packed in boxes of 3.
Although you can ask the shop staff to get you individual ones too!
At just 96cents after the 20% discount, it's cheap!
All in all, my favourite bakery that sells all our favourite cantonese breakfast goodies that are still fresh even at 8pm!
I've seen them pull out new trays of egg tarts from their oven at 8pm!
Based on the two pastries I purchased here, it was a measly 2-stars.
This location is in the food court floor in the Raffles shopping mall.
In the early morning hours, it was busy with business people looking for their breakfast fix before heading out to work.
I bought one savory pastry which contained chicken and mushroom.
It sure looked good based on appearances, but it was chewy, stale, and bland.
The other one was a little better, as there were tater tots baked into this piece of bread, then covered with nacho cheese and green onions.
Again, chewy and stale.
Perhaps I'm spoiled by the constant turnover and freshness of the "fresh bread" from 85C, but there was no soul to this bread and pastry chain.
Breadtalk started in Singapore, but now has locations all over Southeast Asia.
I suspect they put out unsold bread the next day.
At any rate, check out Breadtalk only if you have no other alternative.
This stall sells biscuits of varying shapes and sizes, many of which you would recognise if you were a child or teenager in the 1980s and 1990s.
Biscuits are stored in metal cans, stacked one on top another and displayed around the outside of the stall.
Apart from offering you a chance to revisit the past and indulge in some nostalgia, the stall sells a variety of market produce.
I was walking around Tamp 1 one day and something told me to head inside this bakery.
The first thing I saw - gorgeous little mochi cheese buns.
I knew i had to get a couple...or maybe 20.
I probably looked like a burglar, grabbing bun after bun and stacking them on my tray.
I suppose there were many pairs of eyes wondering whether this boy was going to eat all 20 mochi cheese buns.
WELL, YES.
But not in one go of course.
Made for a good afternoon snack the day after.
Yeah...didnt last me till the day after that.
Hmmmm.
Yamazaki bread was my favorite.
Yeah, you spotted that, it's a past tense.
The bread here is tasty, has a nice and soft texture, and is quite affordable.
But ever since another bakery at the same level opened, I kinda switched sides.
I feel that the cakes and puffs here are really disappointing.
They looked so awesome on display, so I actually bought whole cake and the cream puffs.
But when you actually eat it, you'll be so disillusioned.
For the puff, the cream is just a tad too much, and doesn't go very well with the puff.
For the cake, the strawberries are too sour and overall taste bland.
Whoever said 'looks are deceiving' is so right.
Okay well, with all that said, this is still the place to be if you would want to get the mini breads.
The kues here are decent - its good that its giving Bengawan Solo who otherwise pretty much monopolises the retail kue scene in Singapore a competitor!
My favourite kue here is the 'Onde-Onde'.
Orange in colour rather than green which most of us are used to, their Onde-Onde is soft and chewy with silky liquid gula melakka that gushes out when you bite into it.
Their pandan cake loses Bengawan Solo's by far though, very sweet and I couldn't taste enough of the pandan flavour.
